EOS THEIR CONVERSATION,           AND THE INTELLIGENCE THAT INTERRUPTS IT        L  THE PURSUIT AND ESCAPE       LI  AFFORDING AN EXPLANATION OF MORE MYSTERIES THAN ONE, AND           COMPREHENDING A PROPOSAL OF MARRIAGE WITH NO WORD OF SETTLEMENT           OR PIN-MONEY      LII  FAGIN'S LAST NIGHT ALIVE     LIII  AND LAST     CHAPTER I  TREATS OF THE PLACE WHERE OLIVER TWIST WAS BORN AND OF THE CIRCUMSTANCES ATTENDING HIS BIRTH  Among other public buildings in a certain town, which for many reasons it will be prudent to refrain from mentioning, and to which I will assign no fictitious name, there is one anciently common to most towns, great or small: to wit, a workhouse; and in this workhouse was born; on a day and date which I need not trouble myself to repeat, inasmuch as it can be of no possible consequence to the reader, in this stage of the business at all events; the item of mortality whose name is prefixed to the head of this chapter. EOS Although I am not disposed to maintain that the being born in a workhouse, is in itself the most fortunate and enviable circumstance that can possibly befall a human being, I do mean to say that in this particular instance, it was the best thing for Oliver Twist that could by possibility have occurred. EOS The fact is, that there was considerable difficulty in inducing Oliver to take upon himself the office of respiration,--a troublesome practice, but one which custom has rendered necessary to our easy existence; and for some time he lay gasping on a little flock mattress, rather unequally poised between this world and the next: the balance being decidedly in favour of the latter. EOS Now, if, during this brief period, Oliver had been surrounded by careful grandmothers, anxious aunts, experienced nurses, and doctors of profound wisdom, he would most inevitably and indubitably have been killed in no time. EOS There being nobody by, however, but a pauper old woman, who was rendered rather misty by an unwonted allowance of beer; and a parish surgeon who did such matters by contract; Oliver and Nature fought out the point between them. EOS The result was, that, after a few struggles, Oliver breathed, sneezed, and proceeded to advertise to the inmates of the workhouse the fact of a new burden having been imposed  upon the parish, by setting up as loud a cry as could reasonably have been expected from a male infant who had not been possessed of that very useful appendage, a voice, for a much longer space of time than three minutes and a quarter. EOS As Oliver gave this first proof of the free and proper action of his lungs, the patchwork coverlet which was carelessly flung over the iron bedstead, rustled; the pale face of a young woman was raised feebly from the pillow; and a faint voice imperfectly articulated the words, 'Let me see the child, and die.' EOS The surgeon had been sitting with his face turned towards the fire: giving the palms of his hands a warm and a rub alternately. EOS As the young woman spoke, he rose, and advancing to the bed's head, said, with more kindness than might have been expected of him:  'Oh, you must not talk about dying yet.' EOS 'Lor bless her dear heart, no!' EOS Think what it is to be a mother, there's a dear young lamb do.' EOS Apparently this consolatory perspective of a mother's prospects failed in producing its due effect. EOS The patient shook her head, and stretched out her hand towards the child. EOS The surgeon deposited it in her arms. EOS They talked of hope and comfort. EOS They had been strangers too long. EOS 'It's all over, Mrs. EOS Thingummy!' EOS said the surgeon at last. EOS 'You needn't mind sending up to me, if the child cries, nurse,' said the surgeon, putting on his gloves with great deliberation. EOS 'It's very likely it _will_ be troublesome. EOS He put on his hat, and, pausing by the bed-side on his way to the door, added, 'She was a good-looking girl, too; where did she come from?' EOS 'She was brought here last night,' replied the old woman, 'by the overseer's order. EOS She was found lying in the street. EOS The surgeon leaned over the body, and raised the left hand. EOS 'The old story,' he said, shaking his head: 'no wedding-ring, I see. EOS Ah! EOS Good-night!' EOS The medical gentleman walked away to dinner; and the nurse, having once more applied herself to the green bottle, sat down on a low chair before the fire, and proceeded to dress the infant. EOS What an excellent example of the power of dress, young Oliver Twist was! EOS Oliver cried lustily. EOS If he could have known that he was an orphan, left to the tender mercies of church-wardens and overseers, perhaps he would have cried the louder. EOS The hungry and destitute situation of the infant orphan was duly reported by the workhouse authorities to the parish authorities. EOS The parish authorities inquired with dignity of the workhouse authorities, whether there was no female then domiciled in 'the house' who was in a situation to impart to Oliver Twist, the consolation and nourishment of which he stood in need. EOS The workhouse authorities replied with humility, that there was not. EOS The elderly female was a woman of wisdom and experience; she knew what was good for children; and she had a very accurate perception of what was good for herself. EOS So, she appropriated the greater part of the weekly stipend to her own use, and consigned the rising parochial generation to even a shorter allowance than was originally provided for them. EOS Thereby finding in the lowest depth a deeper still; and proving herself a very great experimental philosopher. EOS Everybody knows the story of another experimental philosopher who had a great theory about a horse being able to live without eating, and who demonstrated it so well, that he had got his own horse down to a straw a day, and would unquestionably have rendered him a very spirited and rampacious animal on nothing at all, if he had not died, four-and-twenty hours before he was to have had his first comfortable bait of air. EOS Unfortunately for, the experimental philosophy of the female to whose protecting care Oliver Twist was delivered over, a similar result usually attended the operation of _her_ system; for at the very moment when the child had contrived to exist upon the smallest possible portion of the weakest possible food, it did perversely happen in eight and a half cases out of ten, either that it sickened from want and cold, or fell into the fire from neglect, or got half-smothered by accident; in any one of which cases, the miserable little being was usually summoned into another world, and there gathered to the fathers it had never known in this. EOS Occasionally, when there was some more than usually interesting inquest upon a parish child who had been overlooked in turning up a bedstead, or inadvertently scalded to death when there happened to be a washing--though the latter accident was very scarce, anything approaching to a washing being of rare occurrence in the farm--the jury would take it into their heads to ask troublesome questions, or the parishioners would rebelliously affix their signatures to a remonstrance. EOS But these impertinences were speedily checked by the evidence of the surgeon, and the testimony of the beadle; the former of whom had always opened the body and found nothing inside (which was very probable indeed), and the latter of whom invariably swore whatever the parish wanted; which was very self-devotional. EOS Besides, the board made periodical pilgrimages to the farm, and always sent the beadle the day before, to say they were going. EOS It cannot be expected that this system of farming would produce any very extraordinary or luxuriant crop. EOS But nature or inheritance had implanted a good sturdy spirit in Oliver's breast. EOS It had had plenty of room to expand, thanks to the spare diet of the establishment; and perhaps to this circumstance may be attributed his having any ninth birth-day at all. EOS Be this as it may, however, it was his ninth birthday; and he was keeping it in the coal-cellar with a select party of two other young gentleman, who, after participating with him in a sound thrashing, had been locked up for atrociously presuming to be hungry, when Mrs. Mann, the good lady of the house, was unexpectedly startled by the apparition of Mr. Bumble, the beadle, striving to undo the wicket of the garden-gate. EOS 'Goodness gracious! EOS Is that you, Mr. Bumble, sir?' EOS said Mrs. Mann, thrusting her head out of the window in well-affected ecstasies of joy. EOS '(Susan, take Oliver and them two brats upstairs, and wash 'em directly.) EOS Mr. Bumble, how glad I am to see you, sure-ly!' EOS Now, Mr. Bumble was a fat man, and a choleric; so, instead of responding to this open-hearted salutation in a kindred spirit, he gave the little wicket a tremendous shake, and then bestowed upon it a kick which could have emanated from no leg but a beadle's. EOS 'Lor, only think,' said Mrs. Mann, running out,--for the three boys had been removed by this time,--'only think of that! EOS That I should have forgotten that the gate was bolted on the inside, on account of them dear children! EOS Walk in sir; walk in, pray, Mr. Bumble, do, sir.' EOS Although this invitation was accompanied with a curtsey that might have softened the heart of a church-warden, it by no means mollified the beadle. EOS 'Do you think this respectful or proper conduct, Mrs. Mann,' inquired Mr. Bumble, grasping his cane, 'to keep the parish officers a waiting at your garden-gate, when they come here upon porochial business with the porochial orphans? EOS Are you aweer, Mrs. Mann, that you are, as I may say, a porochial delegate, and a stipendiary?' EOS 'I'm sure Mr. Bumble, that I was only a telling one or two of the dear children as is so fond of you, that it was you a coming,' replied Mrs. Mann with great humility. EOS Mr. Bumble had a great idea of his oratorical powers and his importance. EOS He had displayed the one, and vindicated the other. EOS He relaxed. EOS 'Well, well, Mrs. Mann,' he replied in a calmer tone; 'it may be as you say; it may be. EOS Lead the way in, Mrs. Mann, for I come on business, and have something to say.' EOS Mrs. Mann ushered the beadle into a small parlour with a brick floor; placed a seat for him; and officiously deposited his cocked hat and cane on the table before him. EOS Mr. Bumble wiped from his forehead the perspiration which his walk had engendered, glanced complacently at the cocked hat, and smiled. EOS Yes, he smiled. EOS 'You've had a long walk, you know, or I wouldn't mention it. EOS Bumble?' EOS 'Not a drop. EOS Nor a drop,' said Mr. Bumble, waving his right hand in a dignified, but placid manner. EOS 'I think you will,' said Mrs. Mann, who had noticed the tone of the refusal, and the gesture that had accompanied it. EOS Mr. Bumble coughed. EOS 'Now, just a leetle drop,' said Mrs. Mann persuasively. EOS 'What is it?' EOS 'It's gin. EOS I'll not deceive you, Mr. B. EOS inquired Bumble, following with his eyes the interesting process of mixing. EOS 'Ah, bless 'em, that I do, dear as it is,' replied the nurse. EOS 'No'; said Mr. Bumble approvingly; 'no, you could not. EOS You are a humane woman, Mrs. EOS Mann.' EOS Mann.' EOS Mann.' EOS (He stirred the gin-and-water.) EOS 'I--I drink your health with cheerfulness, Mrs. Mann'; and he swallowed half of it. EOS 'And now about business,' said the beadle, taking out a leathern pocket-book. EOS 'The child that was half-baptized Oliver Twist, is nine year old to-day.' EOS 'Bless him!' EOS 'And notwithstanding a offered reward of ten pound, which was afterwards increased to twenty pound. EOS Notwithstanding the most superlative, and, I may say, supernat'ral exertions on the part of this parish,' said Bumble, 'we have never been able to discover who is his father, or what was his mother's settlement, name, or condition.' EOS Mrs. Mann raised her hands in astonishment; but added, after a moment's reflection, 'How comes he to have any name at all, then?' EOS The beadle drew himself up with great pride, and said, 'I inwented it.' EOS 'You, Mr. EOS Bumble!' EOS We name our fondlings in alphabetical order. EOS The last was a S,--Swubble, I named him. EOS The next one comes will be Unwin, and the next Vilkins. EOS 'Why, you're quite a literary character, sir!' EOS said Mrs. Mann. EOS 'Well, well,' said the beadle, evidently gratified with the compliment; 'perhaps I may be. EOS Perhaps I may be, Mrs. EOS Mann.' EOS He finished the gin-and-water, and added, 'Oliver being now too old to remain here, the board have determined to have him back into the house. EOS So let me see him at once.' EOS 'I'll fetch him directly,' said Mrs. Mann, leaving the room for that purpose. EOS Oliver, having had by this time as much of the outer coat of dirt which encrusted his face and hands, removed, as could be scrubbed off in one washing, was led into the room by his benevolent protectress. EOS Oliver was about to say that he would go along with anybody with great readiness, when, glancing upward, he caught sight of Mrs. Mann, who had got behind the beadle's chair, and was shaking her fist at him with a furious countenance. EOS He took the hint at once, for the fist had been too often impressed upon his body not to be deeply impressed upon his recollection. EOS 'No, she can't,' replied Mr. Bumble. EOS 'But she'll come and see you sometimes.' EOS This was no very great consolation to the child. EOS Young as he was, however, he had sense enough to make a feint of feeling great regret at going away. EOS Hunger and recent ill-usage are great assistants if you want to cry; and Oliver cried very naturally indeed. EOS Mrs. Mann gave him a thousand embraces, and what Oliver wanted a great deal more, a piece of bread and butter, less he should seem too hungry when he got to the workhouse. EOS And yet he burst into an agony of childish grief, as the cottage-gate closed after him. EOS Wretched as were the little companions in misery he was leaving behind, they were the only friends he had ever known; and a sense of his loneliness in the great wide world, sank into the child's heart for the first time. EOS Mr. Bumble walked on with long strides; little Oliver, firmly grasping his gold-laced cuff, trotted beside him, inquiring at the end of every quarter of a mile whether they were 'nearly there.' EOS To these interrogations Mr. Bumble returned very brief and snappish replies; for the temporary blandness which gin-and-water awakens in some bosoms had by this time evaporated; and he was once again a beadle. EOS Oliver had not been within the walls of the workhouse a quarter of an hour, and had scarcely completed the demolition of a second slice of bread, when Mr. Bumble, who had handed him over to the care of an old woman, returned; and, telling him it was a board night, informed him that the board had said he was to appear before it forthwith. EOS Not having a very clearly defined notion of what a live board was, Oliver was rather astounded by this intelligence, and was not quite certain whether he ought to laugh or cry. EOS He had no time to think about the matter, however; for Mr. Bumble gave him a tap on the head, with his cane, to wake him up: and another on the back to make him lively: and bidding him to follow, conducted him into a large white-washed room, where eight or ten fat gentlemen were sitting round a table. EOS 'Bow to the board,' said Bumble. EOS Oliver brushed away two or three tears that were lingering in his eyes; and seeing no board but the table, fortunately bowed to that. EOS 'What's your name, boy?' EOS said the gentleman in the high chair. EOS These two causes made him answer in a very low and hesitating voice; whereupon a gentleman in a white waistcoat said he was a fool. EOS Which was a capital way of raising his spirits, and putting him quite at his ease. EOS 'What's that, sir?' EOS 'You know you've got no father or mother, and that you were brought up by the parish, don't you?' EOS 'Yes, sir,' replied Oliver, weeping bitterly. EOS 'What are you crying for?' EOS inquired the gentleman in the white waistcoat. EOS What _could_ the boy be crying for? EOS 'I hope you say your prayers every night,' said another gentleman in a gruff voice; 'and pray for the people who feed you, and take care of you--like a Christian.' EOS The gentleman who spoke last was unconsciously right. EOS 'Well! EOS You have come here to be educated, and taught a useful trade,' said the red-faced gentleman in the high chair. EOS 'So you'll begin to pick oakum to-morrow morning at six o'clock,' added the surly one in the white waistcoat. EOS What a novel illustration of the tender laws of England! EOS They let the paupers go to sleep! EOS He little thought, as he lay sleeping in happy unconsciousness of all around him, that the board had that very day arrived at a decision which would exercise the most material influence over all his future fortunes. EOS And this was it:  The members of this board were very sage, deep, philosophical men; and when they came to turn their attention to the workhouse, they found out at once, what ordinary folks would never have discovered--the poor people liked it! EOS It was a regular place of public entertainment for the poorer classes; a tavern where there was nothing to pay; a public breakfast, dinner, tea, and supper all the year round; a brick and mortar elysium, where it was all play and no work. EOS 'Oho!' EOS They made a great many other wise and humane regulations, having reference to the ladies, which it is not necessary to repeat; kindly undertook to divorce poor married people, in consequence of the great expense of a suit in Doctors' Commons; and, instead of compelling a man to support his family, as they had theretofore done, took his family away from him, and made him a bachelor! EOS There is no saying how many applicants for relief, under these last two heads, might have started up in all classes of society, if it had not been coupled with the workhouse; but the board were long-headed men, and had provided for this difficulty. EOS The relief was inseparable from the workhouse and the gruel; and that frightened people. EOS For the first six months after Oliver Twist was removed, the system was in full operation. EOS It was rather expensive at first, in consequence of the increase in the undertaker's bill, and the necessity of taking in the clothes of all the paupers, which fluttered loosely on their wasted, shrunken forms, after a week or two's gruel. EOS The room in which the boys were fed, was a large stone hall, with a copper at one end: out of which the master, dressed in an apron for the purpose, and assisted by one or two women, ladled the gruel at mealtimes. EOS Of this festive composition each boy had one porringer, and no more--except on occasions of great public rejoicing, when he had two ounces and a quarter of bread besides. EOS The bowls never wanted washing. EOS Boys have generally excellent appetites. EOS Oliver Twist and his companions suffered the tortures of slow starvation for three months: at last they got so voracious and wild with hunger, that one boy, who was tall for his age, and hadn't been used to that sort of thing (for his father had kept a small cook-shop), hinted darkly to his companions, that unless he had another basin of gruel per diem, he was afraid he might some night happen to eat the boy who slept next him, who happened to be a weakly youth of tender age. EOS A council was held; lots were cast who should walk up to the master after supper that evening, and ask for more; and it fell to Oliver Twist. EOS The master was a fat, healthy man; but he turned very pale. EOS He gazed in stupefied astonishment on the small rebel for some seconds, and then clung for support to the copper. EOS The assistants were paralysed with wonder; the boys with fear. EOS The master aimed a blow at Oliver's head with the ladle; pinioned him in his arm; and shrieked aloud for the beadle. EOS The board were sitting in solemn conclave, when Mr. Bumble rushed into the room in great excitement, and addressing the gentleman in the high chair, said,  'Mr. EOS Limbkins, I beg your pardon, sir! EOS Oliver Twist has asked for more!' EOS There was a general start. EOS Horror was depicted on every countenance. EOS 'For _more_!' EOS said Mr. Limbkins. EOS Do I understand that he asked for more, after he had eaten the supper allotted by the dietary?' EOS 'He did, sir,' replied Bumble. EOS 'That boy will be hung,' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat. EOS 'I know that boy will be hung.' EOS An animated discussion took place. EOS Oliver was ordered into instant confinement; and a bill was next morning pasted on the outside of the gate, offering a reward of five pounds to anybody who would take Oliver Twist off the hands of the parish. EOS In other words, five pounds and Oliver Twist were offered to any man or woman who wanted an apprentice to any trade, business, or calling. EOS 'I never was more convinced of anything in my life,' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat, as he knocked at the gate and read the bill next morning: 'I never was more convinced of anything in my life, than I am that that boy will come to be hung.' EOS As I purpose to show in the sequel whether the white waistcoated gentleman was right or not, I should perhaps mar the interest of this narrative (supposing it to possess any at all), if I ventured to hint just yet, whether the life of Oliver Twist had this violent termination or no. EOS CHAPTER III  RELATES HOW OLIVER TWIST WAS VERY NEAR GETTING A PLACE WHICH WOULD NOT HAVE BEEN A SINECURE  For a week after the commission of the impious and profane offence of asking for more, Oliver remained a close prisoner in the dark and solitary room to which he had been consigned by the wisdom and mercy of the board. EOS It appears, at first sight not unreasonable to suppose, that, if he had entertained a becoming feeling of respect for the prediction of the gentleman in the white waistcoat, he would have established that sage individual's prophetic character, once and for ever, by tying one end of his pocket-handkerchief to a hook in the wall, and attaching himself to the other. EOS To the performance of this feat, however, there was one obstacle: namely, that pocket-handkerchiefs being decided articles of luxury, had been, for all future times and ages, removed from the noses of paupers by the express order of the board, in council assembled: solemnly given and pronounced under their hands and seals. EOS There was a still greater obstacle in Oliver's youth and childishness. EOS He only cried bitterly all day; and, when the long, dismal night came on, spread his little hands before his eyes to shut out the darkness, and crouching in the corner, tried to sleep: ever and anon waking with a start and tremble, and drawing himself closer and closer to the wall, as if to feel even its cold hard surface were a protection in the gloom and loneliness which surrounded him. EOS And so far from being denied the advantages of religious consolation, he was kicked into the same apartment every evening at prayer-time, and there permitted to listen to, and console his mind with, a general supplication of the boys, containing a special clause, therein inserted by authority of the board, in which they entreated to be made good, virtuous, contented, and obedient, and to be guarded from the sins and vices of Oliver Twist: whom the supplication distinctly set forth to be under the exclusive patronage and protection of the powers of wickedness, and an article direct from the manufactory of the very Devil himself. EOS It chanced one morning, while Oliver's affairs were in this auspicious and comfortable state, that Mr. Gamfield, chimney-sweep, went his way down the High Street, deeply cogitating in his mind his ways and means of paying certain arrears of rent, for which his landlord had become rather pressing. EOS Mr. Gamfield's most sanguine estimate of his finances could not raise them within full five pounds of the desired amount; and, in a species of arithmetical desperation, he was alternately cudgelling his brains and his donkey, when passing the workhouse, his eyes encountered the bill on the gate. EOS said Mr. Gamfield to the donkey. EOS Mr. Gamfield growled a fierce imprecation on the donkey generally, but more particularly on his eyes; and, running after him, bestowed a blow on his head, which would inevitably have beaten in any skull but a donkey's. EOS Then, catching hold of the bridle, he gave his jaw a sharp wrench, by way of gentle reminder that he was not his own master; and by these means turned him round. EOS He then gave him another blow on the head, just to stun him till he came back again. EOS Having completed these arrangements, he walked up to the gate, to read the bill. EOS Mr. Gamfield smiled, too, as he perused the document; for five pounds was just the sum he had been wishing for; and, as to the boy with which it was encumbered, Mr. Gamfield, knowing what the dietary of the workhouse was, well knew he would be a nice small pattern, just the very thing for register stoves. EOS 'This here boy, sir, wot the parish wants to 'prentis,' said Mr. Gamfield. EOS 'What of him?' EOS 'If the parish vould like him to learn a right pleasant trade, in a good 'spectable chimbley-sweepin' bisness,' said Mr. Gamfield, 'I wants a 'prentis, and I am ready to take him.' EOS 'Walk in,' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat. EOS 'It's a nasty trade,' said Mr. Limbkins, when Gamfield had again stated his wish. EOS 'Young boys have been smothered in chimneys before now,' said another gentleman. EOS Boys is wery obstinit, and wery lazy, Gen'l'men, and there's nothink like a good hot blaze to make 'em come down vith a run. EOS The gentleman in the white waistcoat appeared very much amused by this explanation; but his mirth was speedily checked by a look from Mr. Limbkins. EOS The board then proceeded to converse among themselves for a few minutes, but in so low a tone, that the words 'saving of expenditure,' 'looked well in the accounts,' 'have a printed report published,' were alone audible. EOS These only chanced to be heard, indeed, or account of their being very frequently repeated with great emphasis. EOS 'Not at all,' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat. EOS It was very unlike their general mode of doing business, if they had; but still, as he had no particular wish to revive the rumour, he twisted his cap in his hands, and walked slowly from the table. EOS Mr. Gamfield's countenance brightened, as, with a quick step, he returned to the table, and said,  'What'll you give, gen'l'men? EOS Come! EOS Don't be too hard on a poor man. EOS What'll you give?' EOS 'I should say, three pound ten was plenty,' said Mr. Limbkins. EOS 'Come!' EOS Say four pound, and you've got rid of him for good and all. EOS There!' EOS 'Three pound ten,' repeated Mr. Limbkins, firmly. EOS 'Come! EOS I'll split the diff'erence, gen'l'men,' urged Gamfield. EOS 'Three pound fifteen.' EOS pooh! EOS nonsense!' EOS 'He'd be cheap with nothing at all, as a premium. EOS Take him, you silly fellow! EOS He's just the boy for you. EOS Ha! EOS ha! EOS He had hardly achieved this very unusual gymnastic performance, when Mr. Bumble brought him, with his own hands, a basin of gruel, and the holiday allowance of two ounces and a quarter of bread. EOS 'A prentice, sir!' EOS said the child, trembling. EOS 'Yes, Oliver,' said Mr. Bumble. EOS As Mr. Bumble paused to take breath, after delivering this address in an awful voice, the tears rolled down the poor child's face, and he sobbed bitterly. EOS 'Come,' said Mr. Bumble, somewhat less pompously, for it was gratifying to his feelings to observe the effect his eloquence had produced; 'Come, Oliver! EOS When they arrived at the office, he was shut up in a little room by himself, and admonished by Mr. Bumble to stay there, until he came back to fetch him. EOS There the boy remained, with a palpitating heart, for half an hour. EOS Oliver stared innocently in Mr. Bumble's face at this somewhat contradictory style of address; but that gentleman prevented his offering any remark thereupon, by leading him at once into an adjoining room: the door of which was open. EOS Behind a desk, sat two old gentleman with powdered heads: one of whom was reading the newspaper; while the other was perusing, with the aid of a pair of tortoise-shell spectacles, a small piece of parchment which lay before him. EOS 'This is the boy, your worship,' said Mr. Bumble. EOS The old gentleman who was reading the newspaper raised his head for a moment, and pulled the other old gentleman by the sleeve; whereupon, the last-mentioned old gentleman woke up. EOS 'Oh, is this the boy?' EOS 'This is him, sir,' replied Mr. Bumble. EOS 'Bow to the magistrate, my dear.' EOS Oliver roused himself, and made his best obeisance. EOS 'And he _will_ be a sweep, will he?' EOS inquired the old gentleman. EOS 'And this man that's to be his master--you, sir--you'll treat him well, and feed him, and do all that sort of thing, will you?' EOS said the old gentleman. EOS 'When I says I will, I means I will,' replied Mr. Gamfield doggedly. EOS 'You're a rough speaker, my friend, but you look an honest, open-hearted man,' said the old gentleman: turning his spectacles in the direction of the candidate for Oliver's premium, whose villainous countenance was a regular stamped receipt for cruelty. EOS But the magistrate was half blind and half childish, so he couldn't reasonably be expected to discern what other people did. EOS 'I have no doubt you are, my friend,' replied the old gentleman: fixing his spectacles more firmly on his nose, and looking about him for the inkstand. EOS It was the critical moment of Oliver's fate. EOS If the inkstand had been where the old gentleman thought it was, he would have dipped his pen into it, and signed the indentures, and Oliver would have been straightway hurried off. EOS But, as it chanced to be immediately under his nose, it followed, as a matter of course, that he looked all over his desk for it, without finding it; and happening in the course of his search to look straight before him, his gaze encountered the pale and terrified face of Oliver Twist: who, despite all the admonitory looks and pinches of Bumble, was regarding the repulsive countenance of his future master, with a mingled expression of horror and fear, too palpable to be mistaken, even by a half-blind magistrate. EOS 'My boy!' EOS said the old gentleman, 'you look pale and alarmed. EOS What is the matter?' EOS said Mr. Bumble, raising his hands and eyes with most impressive solemnity. EOS 'Well! EOS of all the artful and designing orphans that ever I see, Oliver, you are one of the most bare-facedest.' EOS 'Did your worship speak to me?' EOS 'Yes. EOS Hold your tongue.' EOS A beadle ordered to hold his tongue! EOS A moral revolution! EOS 'I hope,' stammered Mr. Limbkins:  'I hope the magistrates will not form the opinion that the authorities have been guilty of any improper conduct, on the unsupported testimony of a child.' EOS 'The magistrates are not called upon to pronounce any opinion on the matter,' said the second old gentleman sharply. EOS 'Take the boy back to the workhouse, and treat him kindly. EOS The board, in imitation of so wise and salutary an example, took counsel together on the expediency of shipping off Oliver Twist, in some small trading vessel bound to a good unhealthy port. EOS This suggested itself as the very best thing that could possibly be done with him: the probability being, that the skipper would flog him to death, in a playful mood, some day after dinner, or would knock his brains out with an iron bar; both pastimes being, as is pretty generally known, very favourite and common recreations among gentleman of that class. EOS The more the case presented itself to the board, in this point of view, the more manifold the advantages of the step appeared; so, they came to the conclusion that the only way of providing for Oliver effectually, was to send him to sea without delay. EOS Mr. Bumble had been despatched to make various preliminary inquiries, with the view of finding out some captain or other who wanted a cabin-boy without any friends; and was returning to the workhouse to communicate the result of his mission; when he encountered at the gate, no less a person than Mr. Sowerberry, the parochial undertaker. EOS Mr. Sowerberry was a tall gaunt, large-jointed man, attired in a suit of threadbare black, with darned cotton stockings of the same colour, and shoes to answer. EOS His features were not naturally intended to wear a smiling aspect, but he was in general rather given to professional jocosity. EOS His step was elastic, and his face betokened inward pleasantry, as he advanced to Mr. Bumble, and shook him cordially by the hand. EOS 'You'll make your fortune, Mr. Sowerberry,' said the beadle, as he thrust his thumb and forefinger into the proffered snuff-box of the undertaker: which was an ingenious little model of a patent coffin. EOS 'I say you'll make your fortune, Mr. Sowerberry,' repeated Mr. Bumble, tapping the undertaker on the shoulder, in a friendly manner, with his cane. EOS 'Think so?' EOS said the undertaker in a tone which half admitted and half disputed the probability of the event. EOS 'The prices allowed by the board are very small, Mr. EOS Bumble.' EOS Mr. Sowerberry was much tickled at this: as of course he ought to be; and laughed a long time without cessation. EOS 'Well, well, Mr. Bumble,' he said at length, 'there's no denying that, since the new system of feeding has come in, the coffins are something narrower and more shallow than they used to be; but we must have some profit, Mr. Bumble. EOS A fair profit is, of course, allowable.' EOS 'Of course, of course,' replied the undertaker; 'and if I don't get a profit upon this or that particular article, why, I make it up in the long-run, you see--he! EOS he! EOS 'Though I must say,' continued the undertaker, resuming the current of observations which the beadle had interrupted: 'though I must say, Mr. Bumble, that I have to contend against one very great disadvantage: which is, that all the stout people go off the quickest. EOS The people who have been better off, and have paid rates for many years, are the first to sink when they come into the house; and let me tell you, Mr. Bumble, that three or four inches over one's calculation makes a great hole in one's profits: especially when one has a family to provide for, sir.' EOS As Mr. Sowerberry said this, with the becoming indignation of an ill-used man; and as Mr. Bumble felt that it rather tended to convey a reflection on the honour of the parish; the latter gentleman thought it advisable to change the subject. EOS Oliver Twist being uppermost in his mind, he made him his theme. EOS 'By the bye,' said Mr. Bumble, 'you don't know anybody who wants a boy, do you? EOS Liberal terms, Mr. Sowerberry, liberal terms?' EOS 'Gadso!' EOS You know--dear me, what a very elegant button this is, Mr. Bumble! EOS 'The die is the same as the porochial seal--the Good Samaritan healing the sick and bruised man. EOS The board presented it to me on Newyear's morning, Mr. Sowerberry. EOS Mr. Bumble grasped the undertaker by the arm, and led him into the building. EOS Mr. Sowerberry was closeted with the board for five minutes; and it was arranged that Oliver should go to him that evening 'upon liking'--a phrase which means, in the case of a parish apprentice, that if the master find, upon a short trial, that he can get enough work out of a boy without putting too much food into him, he shall have him for a term of years, to do what he likes with. EOS When little Oliver was taken before 'the gentlemen' that evening; and informed that he was to go, that night, as general house-lad to a coffin-maker's; and that if he complained of his situation, or ever came back to the parish again, he would be sent to sea, there to be drowned, or knocked on the head, as the case might be, he evinced so little emotion, that they by common consent pronounced him a hardened young rascal, and ordered Mr. Bumble to remove him forthwith. EOS He heard the news of his destination, in perfect silence; and, having had his luggage put into his hand--which was not very difficult to carry, inasmuch as it was all comprised within the limits of a brown paper parcel, about half a foot square by three inches deep--he pulled his cap over his eyes; and once more attaching himself to Mr. Bumble's coat cuff, was led away by that dignitary to a new scene of suffering. EOS For some time, Mr. Bumble drew Oliver along, without notice or remark; for the beadle carried his head very erect, as a beadle always should: and, it being a windy day, little Oliver was completely enshrouded by the skirts of Mr. Bumble's coat as they blew open, and disclosed to great advantage his flapped waistcoat and drab plush knee-breeches. EOS 'Oliver!' EOS said Mr. Bumble. EOS 'Pull that cap off your eyes, and hold up your head, sir.' EOS Although Oliver did as he was desired, at once; and passed the back of his unoccupied hand briskly across his eyes, he left a tear in them when he looked up at his conductor. EOS The child made a strong effort, but it was an unsuccessful one. EOS exclaimed Mr. Bumble, stopping short, and darting at his little charge a look of intense malignity. EOS 'Well! EOS I am a very little boy, sir; and it is so--so--'  'So what?' EOS inquired Mr. Bumble in amazement. EOS 'So lonely, sir! EOS So very lonely!' EOS 'Everybody hates me. EOS Oh! EOS sir, don't, don't pray be cross to me!' EOS Then once more taking his hand, he walked on with him in silence. EOS The undertaker, who had just put up the shutters of his shop, was making some entries in his day-book by the light of a most appropriate dismal candle, when Mr. Bumble entered. EOS 'Aha!' EOS 'Ah! EOS I dare say he will,' replied the lady pettishly, 'on our victuals and our drink. EOS However, men always think they know best. EOS There! EOS Get downstairs, little bag o' bones.' EOS I wish some well-fed philosopher, whose meat and drink turn to gall within him; whose blood is ice, whose heart is iron; could have seen Oliver Twist clutching at the dainty viands that the dog had neglected. EOS I wish he could have witnessed the horrible avidity with which Oliver tore the bits asunder with all the ferocity of famine. EOS There is only one thing I should like better; and that would be to see the Philosopher making the same sort of meal himself, with the same relish. EOS 'Then come with me,' said Mrs. Sowerberry: taking up a dim and dirty lamp, and leading the way upstairs; 'your bed's under the counter. EOS But it doesn't much matter whether you do or don't, for you can't sleep anywhere else. EOS Come; don't keep me here all night!' EOS CHAPTER V  OLIVER MINGLES WITH NEW ASSOCIATES. EOS An unfinished coffin on black tressels, which stood in the middle of the shop, looked so gloomy and death-like that a cold tremble came over him, every time his eyes wandered in the direction of the dismal object: from which he almost expected to see some frightful form slowly rear its head, to drive him mad with terror. EOS Against the wall were ranged, in regular array, a long row of elm boards cut in the same shape: looking in the dim light, like high-shouldered ghosts with their hands in their breeches pockets. EOS The atmosphere seemed tainted with the smell of coffins. EOS The recess beneath the counter in which his flock mattress was thrust, looked like a grave. EOS Nor were these the only dismal feelings which depressed Oliver. EOS He was alone in a strange place; and we all know how chilled and desolate the best of us will sometimes feel in such a situation. EOS The boy had no friends to care for, or to care for him. EOS But his heart was heavy, notwithstanding; and he wished, as he crept into his narrow bed, that that were his coffin, and that he could be lain in a calm and lasting sleep in the churchyard ground, with the tall grass waving gently above his head, and the sound of the old deep bell to soothe him in his sleep. EOS Oliver was awakened in the morning, by a loud kicking at the outside of the shop-door: which, before he could huddle on his clothes, was repeated, in an angry and impetuous manner, about twenty-five times. EOS 'Open the door, will yer?' EOS cried the voice which belonged to the legs which had kicked at the door. EOS 'I suppose yer the new boy, ain't yer?' EOS said the voice through the key-hole. EOS 'Ten, sir,' replied Oliver. EOS and having made this obliging promise, the voice began to whistle. EOS He drew back the bolts with a trembling hand, and opened the door. EOS inquired Oliver, innocently. EOS 'Yer don't know who I am, I suppose, Work'us?' EOS said the charity-boy, in continuation: descending from the top of the post, meanwhile, with edifying gravity. EOS 'No, sir,' rejoined Oliver. EOS 'I'm Mister Noah Claypole,' said the charity-boy, 'and you're under me. EOS Take down the shutters, yer idle young ruffian!' EOS It is difficult for a large-headed, small-eyed youth, of lumbering make and heavy countenance, to look dignified under any circumstances; but it is more especially so, when superadded to these personal attractions are a red nose and yellow smalls. EOS Mr. Sowerberry came down soon after. EOS Oliver having 'caught it,' in fulfilment of Noah's prediction, followed that young gentleman down the stairs to breakfast. EOS 'Come near the fire, Noah,' said Charlotte. EOS 'I saved a nice little bit of bacon for you from master's breakfast. EOS There's your tea; take it away to that box, and drink it there, and make haste, for they'll want you to mind the shop. EOS 'D'ye hear, Work'us?' EOS Why don't you let the boy alone?' EOS 'Why everybody lets him alone enough, for the matter of that. EOS Neither his father nor his mother will ever interfere with him. EOS All his relations let him have his own way pretty well. EOS he! EOS he!' EOS 'Oh, you queer soul!' EOS said Charlotte, bursting into a hearty laugh, in which she was joined by Noah; after which they both looked scornfully at poor Oliver Twist, as he sat shivering on the box in the coldest corner of the room, and ate the stale pieces which had been specially reserved for him. EOS Noah was a charity-boy, but not a workhouse orphan. EOS No chance-child was he, for he could trace his genealogy all the way back to his parents, who lived hard by; his mother being a washerwoman, and his father a drunken soldier, discharged with a wooden leg, and a diurnal pension of twopence-halfpenny and an unstateable fraction. EOS The shop-boys in the neighbourhood had long been in the habit of branding Noah in the public streets, with the ignominious epithets of 'leathers,' 'charity,' and the like; and Noah had bourne them without reply. EOS But, now that fortune had cast in his way a nameless orphan, at whom even the meanest could point the finger of scorn, he retorted on him with interest. EOS It shows us what a beautiful thing human nature may be made to be; and how impartially the same amiable qualities are developed in the finest lord and the dirtiest charity-boy. EOS Mr. and Mrs. Sowerberry--the shop being shut up--were taking their supper in the little back-parlour, when Mr. Sowerberry, after several deferential glances at his wife, said,  'My dear--'  He was going to say more; but, Mrs. Sowerberry looking up, with a peculiarly unpropitious aspect, he stopped short. EOS 'Well,' said Mrs. Sowerberry, sharply. EOS 'Nothing, my dear, nothing,' said Mr. Sowerberry. EOS said Mrs. Sowerberry. EOS 'I am nobody; don't consult me, pray. EOS _I_ don't want to intrude upon your secrets.' EOS As Mrs. Sowerberry said this, she gave an hysterical laugh, which threatened violent consequences. EOS He had gone out to dinner; but his 'prentice (which is a very clever lad) sent 'em some medicine in a blacking-bottle, offhand.' EOS 'Ah, there's promptness,' said the undertaker. EOS The houses on either side were high and large, but very old, and tenanted by people of the poorest class: as their neglected appearance would have sufficiently denoted, without the concurrent testimony afforded by the squalid looks of the few men and women who, with folded arms and bodies half doubled, occasionally skulked along. EOS A great many of the tenements had shop-fronts; but these were fast closed, and mouldering away; only the upper rooms being inhabited. EOS The very rats, which here and there lay putrefying in its rottenness, were hideous with famine. EOS Stumbling against a door on the landing, he rapped at it with his knuckles.
