EOS The next day, (the family having been meanwhile relieved with a half-quartern loaf and a piece of cheese, left with them by Mr. Bumble himself,) Oliver and his master returned to the miserable abode; where Mr. Bumble had already arrived, accompanied by four men from the workhouse, who were to act as bearers. EOS An old black cloak had been thrown over the rags of the old woman and the man; and the bare coffin having been screwed down, was hoisted on the shoulders of the bearers, and carried into the street. EOS 'Now, you must put your best leg foremost, old lady!' EOS whispered Sowerberry in the old woman's ear; 'we are rather late; and it won't do, to keep the clergyman waiting. EOS Move on, my men,--as quick as you like!' EOS Mr. Bumble and Sowerberry walked at a good smart pace in front; and Oliver, whose legs were not so long as his master's, ran by the side. EOS There was not so great a necessity for hurrying as Mr. Sowerberry had anticipated, however; for when they reached the obscure corner of the churchyard in which the nettles grew, and where the parish graves were made, the clergyman had not arrived; and the clerk, who was sitting by the vestry-room fire, seemed to think it by no means improbable that it might be an hour or so, before he came. EOS So, they put the bier on the brink of the grave; and the two mourners waited patiently in the damp clay, with a cold rain drizzling down, while the ragged boys whom the spectacle had attracted into the churchyard played a noisy game at hide-and-seek among the tombstones, or varied their amusements by jumping backwards and forwards over the coffin. EOS Mr. Sowerberry and Bumble, being personal friends of the clerk, sat by the fire with him, and read the paper. EOS Immediately afterwards, the clergyman appeared: putting on his surplice as he came along. EOS Mr. Bumble then thrashed a boy or two, to keep up appearances; and the reverend gentleman, having read as much of the burial service as could be compressed into four minutes, gave his surplice to the clerk, and walked away again. EOS 'Now, Bill!' EOS said Sowerberry to the grave-digger. EOS It was no very difficult task, for the grave was so full, that the uppermost coffin was within a few feet of the surface. EOS The grave-digger shovelled in the earth; stamped it loosely down with his feet: shouldered his spade; and walked off, followed by the boys, who murmured very loud complaints at the fun being over so soon. EOS 'They want to shut up the yard.' EOS 'Well, Oliver,' said Sowerberry, as they walked home, 'how do you like it?' EOS 'Pretty well, thank you, sir' replied Oliver, with considerable hesitation. EOS 'Not very much, sir.' EOS 'Ah, you'll get used to it in time, Oliver,' said Sowerberry. EOS 'Nothing when you _are_ used to it, my boy.' EOS Oliver wondered, in his own mind, whether it had taken a very long time to get Mr. Sowerberry used to it. EOS But he thought it better not to ask the question; and walked back to the shop: thinking over all he had seen and heard. EOS CHAPTER VI  OLIVER, BEING GOADED BY THE TAUNTS OF NOAH, ROUSES INTO ACTION, AND RATHER ASTONISHES HIM  The month's trial over, Oliver was formally apprenticed. EOS It was a nice sickly season just at this time. EOS In commercial phrase, coffins were looking up; and, in the course of a few weeks, Oliver acquired a great deal of experience. EOS The success of Mr. Sowerberry's ingenious speculation, exceeded even his most sanguine hopes. EOS The oldest inhabitants recollected no period at which measles had been so prevalent, or so fatal to infant existence; and many were the mournful processions which little Oliver headed, in a hat-band reaching down to his knees, to the indescribable admiration and emotion of all the mothers in the town. EOS As Oliver accompanied his master in most of his adult expeditions too, in order that he might acquire that equanimity of demeanour and full command of nerve which was essential to a finished undertaker, he had many opportunities of observing the beautiful resignation and fortitude with which some strong-minded people bear their trials and losses. EOS Husbands, too, bore the loss of their wives with the most heroic calmness. EOS It was observable, too, that ladies and gentlemen who were in passions of anguish during the ceremony of interment, recovered almost as soon as they reached home, and became quite composed before the tea-drinking was over. EOS All this was very pleasant and improving to see; and Oliver beheld it with great admiration. EOS That Oliver Twist was moved to resignation by the example of these good people, I cannot, although I am his biographer, undertake to affirm with any degree of confidence; but I can most distinctly say, that for many months he continued meekly to submit to the domination and ill-treatment of Noah Claypole: who used him far worse than before, now that his jealousy was roused by seeing the new boy promoted to the black stick and hatband, while he, the old one, remained stationary in the muffin-cap and leathers. EOS Charlotte treated him ill, because Noah did; and Mrs. Sowerberry was his decided enemy, because Mr. Sowerberry was disposed to be his friend; so, between these three on one side, and a glut of funerals on the other, Oliver was not altogether as comfortable as the hungry pig was, when he was shut up, by mistake, in the grain department of a brewery. EOS And now, I come to a very important passage in Oliver's history; for I have to record an act, slight and unimportant perhaps in appearance, but which indirectly produced a material change in all his future prospects and proceedings. EOS One day, Oliver and Noah had descended into the kitchen at the usual dinner-hour, to banquet upon a small joint of mutton--a pound and a half of the worst end of the neck--when Charlotte being called out of the way, there ensued a brief interval of time, which Noah Claypole, being hungry and vicious, considered he could not possibly devote to a worthier purpose than aggravating and tantalising young Oliver Twist. EOS Intent upon this innocent amusement, Noah put his feet on the table-cloth; and pulled Oliver's hair; and twitched his ears; and expressed his opinion that he was a 'sneak'; and furthermore announced his intention of coming to see him hanged, whenever that desirable event should take place; and entered upon various topics of petty annoyance, like a malicious and ill-conditioned charity-boy as he was. EOS But, making Oliver cry, Noah attempted to be more facetious still; and in his attempt, did what many sometimes do to this day, when they want to be funny. EOS 'Work'us,' said Noah, 'how's your mother?' EOS Oliver's colour rose as he said this; he breathed quickly; and there was a curious working of the mouth and nostrils, which Mr. Claypole thought must be the immediate precursor of a violent fit of crying. EOS Under this impression he returned to the charge. EOS said Noah. EOS 'Of a broken heart, some of our old nurses told me,' replied Oliver: more as if he were talking to himself, than answering Noah. EOS 'I think I know what it must be to die of that!' EOS 'Tol de rol lol lol, right fol lairy, Work'us,' said Noah, as a tear rolled down Oliver's cheek. EOS 'What's set you a snivelling now?' EOS 'Not _you_,' replied Oliver, sharply. EOS Don't say anything more to me about her; you'd better not!' EOS 'Better not!' EOS exclaimed Noah. EOS 'Well! EOS Better not! EOS Work'us, don't be impudent. EOS She was a nice 'un she was. EOS Oh, Lor!' EOS 'Yer know, Work'us,' continued Noah, emboldened by Oliver's silence, and speaking in a jeering tone of affected pity: of all tones the most annoying: 'Yer know, Work'us, it can't be helped now; and of course yer couldn't help it then; and I am very sorry for it; and I'm sure we all are, and pity yer very much. EOS 'What did you say?' EOS inquired Oliver, looking up very quickly. EOS 'A regular right-down bad 'un, Work'us,' replied Noah, coolly. EOS Crimson with fury, Oliver started up; overthrew the chair and table; seized Noah by the throat; shook him, in the violence of his rage, till his teeth chattered in his head; and collecting his whole force into one heavy blow, felled him to the ground. EOS A minute ago, the boy had looked the quiet child, mild, dejected creature that harsh treatment had made him. EOS But his spirit was roused at last; the cruel insult to his dead mother had set his blood on fire. EOS His breast heaved; his attitude was erect; his eye bright and vivid; his whole person changed, as he stood glaring over the cowardly tormentor who now lay crouching at his feet; and defied him with an energy he had never known before. EOS 'He'll murder me!' EOS Oliver's gone mad! EOS Char--lotte!' EOS And between every syllable, Charlotte gave Oliver a blow with all her might: accompanying it with a scream, for the benefit of society. EOS Charlotte's fist was by no means a light one; but, lest it should not be effectual in calming Oliver's wrath, Mrs. Sowerberry plunged into the kitchen, and assisted to hold him with one hand, while she scratched his face with the other. EOS In this favourable position of affairs, Noah rose from the ground, and pommelled him behind. EOS This was rather too violent exercise to last long. EOS 'Bless her, she's going off!' EOS 'Oh! EOS Charlotte,' said Mrs. Sowerberry:  speaking as well as she could, through a deficiency of breath, and a sufficiency of cold water, which Noah had poured over her head and shoulders. EOS mercy indeed, ma'am,' was the reply. EOS Poor Noah! EOS 'Poor fellow!' EOS 'What's to be done!' EOS exclaimed Mrs. Sowerberry. EOS 'Your master's not at home; there's not a man in the house, and he'll kick that door down in ten minutes.' EOS 'Dear, dear! EOS I don't know, ma'am,' said Charlotte, 'unless we send for the police-officers.' EOS Make haste! EOS It'll keep the swelling down.' EOS CHAPTER VII  OLIVER CONTINUES REFRACTORY  Noah Claypole ran along the streets at his swiftest pace, and paused not once for breath, until he reached the workhouse-gate. EOS 'Why, what's the matter with the boy!' EOS said the old pauper. EOS Bumble! EOS Mr. EOS cried Noah, with well-affected dismay: and in tones so loud and agitated, that they not only caught the ear of Mr. Bumble himself, who happened to be hard by, but alarmed him so much that he rushed into the yard without his cocked hat,--which is a very curious and remarkable circumstance: as showing that even a beadle, acted upon a sudden and powerful impulse, may be afflicted with a momentary visitation of loss of self-possession, and forgetfulness of personal dignity. EOS said Noah:  'Oliver, sir,--Oliver has--'  'What? EOS What?' EOS Not run away, sir, but he's turned wicious,' replied Noah. EOS 'He tried to murder me, sir; and then he tried to murder Charlotte; and then missis. EOS Oh! EOS Such agony, please, sir!' EOS When Noah saw that the intelligence he communicated perfectly paralysed Mr. Bumble, he imparted additional effect thereunto, by bewailing his dreadful wounds ten times louder than before; and when he observed a gentleman in a white waistcoat crossing the yard, he was more tragic in his lamentations than ever: rightly conceiving it highly expedient to attract the notice, and rouse the indignation, of the gentleman aforesaid. EOS The gentleman's notice was very soon attracted; for he had not walked three paces, when he turned angrily round, and inquired what that young cur was howling for, and why Mr. Bumble did not favour him with something which would render the series of vocular exclamations so designated, an involuntary process? EOS 'It's a poor boy from the free-school, sir,' replied Mr. Bumble, 'who has been nearly murdered--all but murdered, sir,--by young Twist.' EOS exclaimed the gentleman in the white waistcoat, stopping short. EOS 'And his master, too, I think you said, Noah?' EOS 'No! EOS he's out, or he would have murdered him,' replied Noah. EOS 'He said he wanted to.' EOS 'Ah! EOS Said he wanted to, did he, my boy?' EOS 'Yes, sir,' replied Noah. EOS 'And please, sir, missis wants to know whether Mr. Bumble can spare time to step up there, directly, and flog him--'cause master's out.' EOS 'Certainly, my boy; certainly,' said the gentleman in the white waistcoat: smiling benignly, and patting Noah's head, which was about three inches higher than his own. EOS 'You're a good boy--a very good boy. EOS Here's a penny for you. EOS Bumble, just step up to Sowerberry's with your cane, and see what's best to be done. EOS 'No, I will not, sir,' replied the beadle. EOS Here the position of affairs had not at all improved. EOS Sowerberry had not yet returned, and Oliver continued to kick, with undiminished vigour, at the cellar-door. EOS With this view he gave a kick at the outside, by way of prelude; and, then, applying his mouth to the keyhole, said, in a deep and impressive tone:  'Oliver!' EOS 'Come; you let me out!' EOS replied Oliver, from the inside. EOS said Mr. Bumble. EOS 'Yes,' replied Oliver. EOS Ain't you a-trembling while I speak, sir?' EOS said Mr. Bumble. EOS 'No!' EOS He stepped back from the keyhole; drew himself up to his full height; and looked from one to another of the three bystanders, in mute astonishment. EOS 'No boy in half his senses could venture to speak so to you.' EOS 'It's Meat.' EOS 'What?' EOS exclaimed Mrs. Sowerberry. EOS 'You've over-fed him, ma'am. EOS You've raised a artificial soul and spirit in him, ma'am unbecoming a person of his condition: as the board, Mrs. Sowerberry, who are practical philosophers, will tell you. EOS It's quite enough that we let 'em have live bodies. EOS If you had kept the boy on gruel, ma'am, this would never have happened.' EOS 'Dear, dear!' EOS ejaculated Mrs. Sowerberry, piously raising her eyes to the kitchen ceiling: 'this comes of being liberal!' EOS The liberality of Mrs. Sowerberry to Oliver, had consisted of a profuse bestowal upon him of all the dirty odds and ends which nobody else would eat; so there was a great deal of meekness and self-devotion in her voluntarily remaining under Mr. Bumble's heavy accusation. EOS Of which, to do her justice, she was wholly innocent, in thought, word, or deed. EOS 'Ah!' EOS Excitable natures, Mrs. Sowerberry! EOS Both the nurse and doctor said, that that mother of his made her way here, against difficulties and pain that would have killed any well-disposed woman, weeks before.' EOS At this point of Mr. Bumble's discourse, Oliver, just hearing enough to know that some allusion was being made to his mother, recommenced kicking, with a violence that rendered every other sound inaudible. EOS Oliver's clothes had been torn in the beating he had received; his face was bruised and scratched; and his hair scattered over his forehead. EOS 'Now, you are a nice young fellow, ain't you?' EOS 'He called my mother names,' replied Oliver. EOS said Mrs. Sowerberry. EOS 'She deserved what he said, and worse.' EOS 'She did,' said Mrs. Sowerberry. EOS 'It's a lie!' EOS said Oliver. EOS Mrs. Sowerberry burst into a flood of tears. EOS This flood of tears left Mr. Sowerberry no alternative. EOS If he had hesitated for one instant to punish Oliver most severely, it must be quite clear to every experienced reader that he would have been, according to all precedents in disputes of matrimony established, a brute, an unnatural husband, an insulting creature, a base imitation of a man, and various other agreeable characters too numerous for recital within the limits of this chapter. EOS To do him justice, he was, as far as his power went--it was not very extensive--kindly disposed towards the boy; perhaps, because it was his interest to be so; perhaps, because his wife disliked him. EOS The flood of tears, however, left him no resource; so he at once gave him a drubbing, which satisfied even Mrs. Sowerberry herself, and rendered Mr. Bumble's subsequent application of the parochial cane, rather unnecessary. EOS It was not until he was left alone in the silence and stillness of the gloomy workshop of the undertaker, that Oliver gave way to the feelings which the day's treatment may be supposed likely to have awakened in a mere child. EOS But now, when there were none to see or hear him, he fell upon his knees on the floor; and, hiding his face in his hands, wept such tears as, God send for the credit of our nature, few so young may ever have cause to pour out before him! EOS For a long time, Oliver remained motionless in this attitude. EOS The stars seemed, to the boy's eyes, farther from the earth than he had ever seen them before; there was no wind; and the sombre shadows thrown by the trees upon the ground, looked sepulchral and death-like, from being so still. EOS With the first ray of light that struggled through the crevices in the shutters, Oliver arose, and again unbarred the door. EOS He looked to the right and to the left, uncertain whither to fly. EOS He took the same route; and arriving at a footpath across the fields: which he knew, after some distance, led out again into the road; struck into it, and walked quickly on. EOS Along this same footpath, Oliver well-remembered he had trotted beside Mr. Bumble, when he first carried him to the workhouse from the farm. EOS His way lay directly in front of the cottage. EOS His heart beat quickly when he bethought himself of this; and he half resolved to turn back. EOS Besides, it was so early that there was very little fear of his being seen; so he walked on. EOS He reached the house. EOS There was no appearance of its inmates stirring at that early hour. EOS A child was weeding one of the little beds; as he stopped, he raised his pale face and disclosed the features of one of his former companions. EOS They had been beaten, and starved, and shut up together, many and many a time. EOS 'Hush, Dick!' EOS said Oliver, as the boy ran to the gate, and thrust his thin arm between the rails to greet him. EOS 'Nobody but me,' replied the child. EOS 'You musn't say you saw me, Dick,' said Oliver. EOS 'I am running away. EOS They beat and ill-use me, Dick; and I am going to seek my fortune, some long way off. EOS I don't know where. EOS 'Yes, yes, I will, to say good-b'ye to you,' replied Oliver. EOS I know I shall! EOS You will be well and happy!' EOS I know the doctor must be right, Oliver, because I dream so much of Heaven, and Angels, and kind faces that I never see when I am awake. EOS Kiss me,' said the child,  climbing up the low gate, and flinging his little arms round Oliver's neck. EOS 'Good-b'ye, dear! EOS God bless you!' EOS The blessing was from a young child's lips, but it was the first that Oliver had ever heard invoked upon his head; and through the struggles and sufferings, and troubles and changes, of his after life, he never once forgot it. EOS It was eight o'clock now. EOS Though he was nearly five miles away from the town, he ran, and hid behind the hedges, by turns, till noon: fearing that he might be pursued and overtaken. EOS Then he sat down to rest by the side of the milestone, and began to think, for the first time, where he had better go and try to live. EOS The stone by which he was seated, bore, in large characters, an intimation that it was just seventy miles from that spot to London. EOS The name awakened a new train of ideas in the boy's mind. EOS He had often heard the old men in the workhouse, too, say that no lad of spirit need want in London; and that there were ways of living in that vast city, which those who had been bred up in country parts had no idea of. EOS It was the very place for a homeless boy, who must die in the streets unless some one helped him. EOS He had diminished the distance between himself and London by full four miles more, before he recollected how much he must undergo ere he could hope to reach his place of destination. EOS He had a crust of bread, a coarse shirt, and two pairs of stockings, in his bundle. EOS 'A clean shirt,' thought Oliver, 'is a very comfortable thing; and so are two pairs of darned stockings; and so is a penny; but they are small helps to a sixty-five miles' walk in winter time.' EOS But Oliver's thoughts, like those of most other people, although they were extremely ready and active to point out his difficulties, were wholly at a loss to suggest any feasible mode of surmounting them; so, after a good deal of thinking to no particular purpose, he changed his little bundle over to the other shoulder, and trudged on. EOS He felt frightened at first, for the wind moaned dismally over the empty fields: and he was cold and hungry, and more alone than he had ever felt before. EOS Being very tired with his walk, however, he soon fell asleep and forgot his troubles. EOS He felt cold and stiff, when he got up next morning, and so hungry that he was obliged to exchange the penny for a small loaf, in the very first village through which he passed. EOS He had walked no more than twelve miles, when night closed in again. EOS His feet were sore, and his legs so weak that they trembled beneath him. EOS Poor Oliver tried to keep up with the coach a little way, but was unable to do it, by reason of his fatigue and sore feet. EOS When the outsides saw this, they put their halfpence back into their pockets again, declaring that he was an idle young dog, and didn't deserve anything; and the coach rattled away and left only a cloud of dust behind. EOS This frightened Oliver very much, and made him glad to get out of those villages with all possible expedition. EOS In others, he would stand about the inn-yards, and look mournfully at every one who passed: a proceeding which generally terminated in the landlady's ordering one of the post-boys who were lounging about, to drive that strange boy out of the place, for she was sure he had come to steal something. EOS The window-shutters were closed; the street was empty; not a soul had awakened to the business of the day. EOS By degrees, the shutters were opened; the window-blinds were drawn up; and people began passing to and fro. EOS Some few stopped to gaze at Oliver for a moment or two, or turned round to stare at him as they hurried by; but none relieved him, or troubled themselves to inquire how he came there. EOS He had no heart to beg. EOS And there he sat. EOS He had been crouching on the step for some time: wondering at the great number of public-houses (every other house in Barnet was a tavern, large or small), gazing listlessly at the coaches as they passed through, and thinking how strange it seemed that they could do, with ease, in a few hours, what it had taken him a whole week of courage and determination beyond his years to accomplish: when he was roused by observing that a boy, who had passed him carelessly some minutes before, had returned, and was now surveying him most earnestly from the opposite side of the way. EOS He took little heed of this at first; but the boy remained in the same attitude of close observation so long, that Oliver raised his head, and returned his steady look. EOS What's the row?' EOS The boy who addressed this inquiry to the young wayfarer, was about his own age: but one of the queerest looking boys that Oliver had even seen. EOS He was a snub-nosed, flat-browed, common-faced boy enough; and as dirty a juvenile as one would wish to see; but he had about him all the airs and manners of a man. EOS He was short of his age: with rather bow-legs, and little, sharp, ugly eyes. EOS His hat was stuck on the top of his head so lightly, that it threatened to fall off every moment--and would have done so, very often, if the wearer had not had a knack of every now and then giving his head a sudden twitch, which brought it back to its old place again. EOS He wore a man's coat, which reached nearly to his heels. EOS He was, altogether, as roystering and swaggering a young gentleman as ever stood four feet six, or something less, in the bluchers. EOS 'Hullo, my covey! EOS 'I am very hungry and tired,' replied Oliver: the tears standing in his eyes as he spoke. EOS 'I have walked a long way. EOS I have been walking these seven days.' EOS 'Walking for sivin days!' EOS 'Oh, I see. EOS Beak's order, eh? EOS Oliver mildly replied, that he had always heard a bird's mouth described by the term in question. EOS 'Why, a beak's a madgst'rate; and when you walk by a beak's order, it's not straight forerd, but always agoing up, and niver a coming down agin. EOS Was you never on the mill?' EOS inquired Oliver. EOS 'What mill! EOS Why, _the_ mill--the mill as takes up so little room that it'll work inside a Stone Jug; and always goes better when the wind's low with people, than when it's high; acos then they can't get workmen. EOS But come,' said the young gentleman; 'you want grub, and you shall have it. EOS I'm at low-water-mark myself--only one bob and a magpie; but, as far as it goes, I'll fork out and stump. EOS There! EOS the ham being kept clean and preserved from dust, by the ingenious expedient of making a hole in the loaf by pulling out a portion of the crumb, and stuffing it therein. EOS Taking the bread under his arm, the young gentlman turned into a small public-house, and led the way to a tap-room in the rear of the premises. EOS 'Yes.' EOS 'Money?' EOS 'No.' EOS The strange boy whistled; and put his arms into his pockets, as far as the big coat-sleeves would let them go. EOS 'Do you live in London?' EOS 'Yes. EOS I do, when I'm at home,' replied the boy. EOS 'I suppose you want some place to sleep in to-night, don't you?' EOS 'I do, indeed,' answered Oliver. EOS 'Don't fret your eyelids on that score,' said the young gentleman. EOS 'I've got to be in London to-night; and I know a 'spectable old gentleman as lives there, wot'll give you lodgings for nothink, and never ask for the change--that is, if any genelman he knows interduces you. EOS And don't he know me? EOS Not in the least! EOS Certainly not!' EOS The young gentleman smiled, as if to intimate that the latter fragments of discourse were playfully ironical; and finished the beer as he did so. EOS This unexpected offer of shelter was too tempting to be resisted; especially as it was immediately followed up, by the assurance that the old gentleman referred to, would doubtless provide Oliver with a comfortable place, without loss of time. EOS This led to a more friendly and confidential dialogue; from which Oliver discovered that his friend's name was Jack Dawkins, and that he was a peculiar pet and protege of the elderly gentleman before mentioned. EOS As John Dawkins objected to their entering London before nightfall, it was nearly eleven o'clock when they reached the turnpike at Islington. EOS They crossed from the Angel into St. John's Road; struck down the small street which terminates at Sadler's Wells Theatre; through Exmouth Street and Coppice Row; down the little court by the side of the workhouse; across the classic ground which once bore the name of Hockley-in-the-Hole; thence into Little Saffron Hill; and so into Saffron Hill the Great: along which the Dodger scudded at a rapid pace, directing Oliver to follow close at his heels. EOS Although Oliver had enough to occupy his attention in keeping sight of his leader, he could not help bestowing a few hasty glances on either side of the way, as he passed along. EOS The street was very narrow and muddy, and the air was impregnated with filthy odours. EOS The sole places that seemed to prosper amid the general blight of the place, were the public-houses; and in them, the lowest orders of Irish were wrangling with might and main. EOS Oliver was just considering whether he hadn't better run away, when they reached the bottom of the hill. EOS 'Now, then!' EOS cried a voice from below, in reply to a whistle from the Dodger. EOS 'Plummy and slam!' EOS was the reply. EOS This seemed to be some watchword or signal that all was right; for the light of a feeble candle gleamed on the wall at the remote end of the passage; and a man's face peeped out, from where a balustrade of the old kitchen staircase had been broken away. EOS 'Who's the t'other one?' EOS 'Yes, he's a sortin' the wipes. EOS The candle was drawn back, and the face disappeared. EOS Oliver, groping his way with one hand, and having the other firmly grasped by his companion, ascended with much difficulty the dark and broken stairs: which his conductor mounted with an ease and expedition that showed he was well acquainted with them. EOS There was a deal table before the fire: upon which were a candle, stuck in a ginger-beer bottle, two or three pewter pots, a loaf and butter, and a plate. EOS In a frying-pan, which was on the fire, and which was secured to the mantelshelf by a string, some sausages were cooking; and standing over them, with a toasting-fork in his hand, was a very old shrivelled Jew, whose villainous-looking and repulsive face was obscured by a quantity of matted red hair. EOS He was dressed in a greasy flannel gown, with his throat bare; and seemed to be dividing his attention between the frying-pan and the clothes-horse, over which a great number of silk handkerchiefs were hanging. EOS So did the Jew himself, toasting-fork in hand. EOS The Jew grinned; and, making a low obeisance to Oliver, took him by the hand, and hoped he should have the honour of his intimate acquaintance. EOS Upon this, the young gentleman with the pipes came round him, and shook both his hands very hard--especially the one in which he held his little bundle. EOS One young gentleman was very anxious to hang up his cap for him; and another was so obliging as to put his hands in his pockets, in order that, as he was very tired, he might not have the trouble of emptying them, himself, when he went to bed. EOS These civilities would probably be extended much farther, but for a liberal exercise of the Jew's toasting-fork on the heads and shoulders of the affectionate youths who offered them. EOS 'Dodger, take off the sausages; and draw a tub near the fire for Oliver. EOS Ah, you're a-staring at the pocket-handkerchiefs! EOS eh, my dear. EOS There are a good many of 'em, ain't there? EOS We've just looked 'em out, ready for the wash; that's all, Oliver; that's all. EOS ha! EOS ha!' EOS The latter part of this speech, was hailed by a boisterous shout from all the hopeful pupils of the merry old gentleman. EOS In the midst of which they went to supper. EOS Oliver ate his share, and the Jew then mixed him a glass of hot gin-and-water: telling him he must drink it off directly, because another gentleman wanted the tumbler. EOS Oliver did as he was desired. EOS He would stop every now and then to listen when there was the least noise below: and when he had satisfied himself, he would go on whistling and stirring again, as before. EOS Although Oliver had roused himself from sleep, he was not thoroughly awake. EOS There is a drowsy state, between sleeping and waking, when you dream more in five minutes with your eyes half open, and yourself half conscious of everything that is passing around you, than you would in five nights with your eyes fast closed, and your senses wrapt in perfect unconsciousness. EOS At such time, a mortal knows just enough of what his mind is doing, to form some glimmering conception of its mighty powers, its bounding from earth and spurning time and space, when freed from the restraint of its corporeal associate. EOS He saw the Jew with his half-closed eyes; heard his low whistling; and recognised the sound of the spoon grating against the saucepan's sides: and yet the self-same senses were mentally engaged, at the same time, in busy action with almost everybody he had ever known. EOS When the coffee was done, the Jew drew the saucepan to the hob. EOS Standing, then in an irresolute attitude for a few minutes, as if he did not well know how to employ himself, he turned round and looked at Oliver, and called him by his name. EOS He did not answer, and was to all appearances asleep. EOS After satisfying himself upon this head, the Jew stepped gently to the door: which he fastened. EOS His eyes glistened as he raised the lid, and looked in. EOS 'Aha!' EOS 'Clever dogs! EOS Clever dogs! EOS Staunch to the last! EOS Never told the old parson where they were. EOS Never poached upon old Fagin! EOS It wouldn't have loosened the knot, or kept the drop up, a minute longer. EOS Fine fellows! EOS Fine fellows!' EOS With these, and other muttered reflections of the like nature, the Jew once more deposited the watch in its place of safety. EOS There seemed to be some very minute inscription on it; for the Jew laid it flat upon the table, and shading it with his hand, pored over it, long and earnestly. EOS At length he put it down, as if despairing of success; and, leaning back in his chair, muttered:  'What a fine thing capital punishment is! EOS Dead men never repent; dead men never bring awkward stories to light. EOS Ah, it's a fine thing for the trade! EOS He closed the lid of the box with a loud crash; and, laying his hand on a bread knife which was on the table, started furiously up. EOS He trembled very much though; for, even in his terror, Oliver could see that the knife quivered in the air. EOS 'What do you watch me for? EOS Why are you awake? EOS What have you seen? EOS Speak out, boy! EOS Quick--quick! EOS for your life. EOS 'I am very sorry if I have disturbed you, sir.' EOS said the Jew, scowling fiercely on the boy. EOS 'No! EOS No, indeed!' EOS replied Oliver. EOS 'Are you sure?' EOS cried the Jew: with a still fiercer look than before: and a threatening attitude. EOS 'I was not, indeed, sir.' EOS 'Tush, tush, my dear!' EOS said the Jew, abruptly resuming his old manner, and playing with the knife a little, before he laid it down; as if to induce the belief that he had caught it up, in mere sport. EOS I only tried to frighten you. EOS You're a brave boy. EOS ha! EOS you're a brave boy, Oliver.' EOS said the Jew, laying his hand upon it after a short pause. EOS 'Ah!' EOS said the Jew, turning rather pale. EOS 'They--they're mine, Oliver; my little property. EOS All I have to live upon, in my old age. EOS Oliver thought the old gentleman must be a decided miser to live in such a dirty place, with so many watches; but, thinking that perhaps his fondness for the Dodger and the other boys, cost him a good deal of money, he only cast a deferential look at the Jew, and asked if he might get up. EOS 'Certainly, my dear, certainly,' replied the old gentleman. EOS 'Stay. EOS There's a pitcher of water in the corner by the door. EOS The four sat down, to breakfast, on the coffee, and some hot rolls and ham which the Dodger had brought home in the crown of his hat. EOS 'Well,' said the Jew, glancing slyly at Oliver, and addressing himself to the Dodger, 'I hope you've been at work this morning, my dears?' EOS 'Hard,' replied the Dodger. EOS 'As nails,' added Charley Bates. EOS 'Good boys, good boys!' EOS 'What have you got, Dodger?' EOS 'Lined?' EOS inquired the Jew, with eagerness. EOS 'Not so heavy as they might be,' said the Jew, after looking at the insides carefully; 'but very neat and nicely made. EOS Ingenious workman, ain't he, Oliver?' EOS said Fagin to Charley Bates. EOS You haven't marked them well, though, Charley; so the marks shall be picked out with a needle, and we'll teach Oliver how to do it. EOS 'If you please, sir,' said Oliver. EOS 'You'd like to be able to make pocket-handkerchiefs as easy as Charley Bates, wouldn't you, my dear?' EOS 'Very much, indeed, if you'll teach me, sir,' replied Oliver. EOS Master Bates saw something so exquisitely ludicrous in this reply, that he burst into another laugh; which laugh, meeting the coffee he was drinking, and carrying it down some wrong channel, very nearly terminated in his premature suffocation. EOS said Charley when he recovered, as an apology to the company for his unpolite behaviour. EOS The Dodger said nothing, but he smoothed Oliver's hair over his eyes, and said he'd know better, by and by; upon which the old gentleman, observing Oliver's colour mounting, changed the subject by asking whether there had been much of a crowd at the execution that morning? EOS When the breakfast was cleared away; the merry old gentlman and the two boys played at a very curious and uncommon game, which was performed in this way. EOS The merry old gentleman, placing a snuff-box in one pocket of his trousers, a note-case in the other, and a watch in his waistcoat pocket, with a guard-chain round his neck, and sticking a mock diamond pin in his shirt: buttoned his coat tight round him, and putting his spectacle-case and handkerchief in his pockets, trotted up and down the room with a stick, in imitation of the manner in which old gentlemen walk about the streets any hour in the day. EOS Sometimes he stopped at the fire-place, and sometimes at the door, making believe that he was staring with all his might into shop-windows. EOS All this time, the two boys followed him closely about: getting out of his sight, so nimbly, every time he turned round, that it was impossible to follow their motions. EOS At last, the Dodger trod upon his toes, or ran upon his boot accidently, while Charley Bates stumbled up against him behind; and in that one moment they took from him, with the most extraordinary rapidity, snuff-box, note-case, watch-guard, chain, shirt-pin, pocket-handkerchief, even the spectacle-case. EOS They wore a good deal of hair, not very neatly turned up behind, and were rather untidy about the shoes and stockings. EOS They were not exactly pretty, perhaps; but they had a great deal of colour in their faces, and looked quite stout and hearty. EOS As there is no doubt they were. EOS The visitors stopped a long time. EOS Spirits were produced, in consequence of one of the young ladies complaining of a coldness in her inside; and the conversation took a very convivial and improving turn. EOS At length, Charley Bates expressed his opinion that it was time to pad the hoof. EOS This, it occurred to Oliver, must be French for going out; for directly afterwards, the Dodger, and Charley, and the two young ladies, went away together, having been kindly furnished by the amiable old Jew with money to spend. EOS 'There, my dear,' said Fagin. EOS 'Have they done work, sir?' EOS inquired Oliver. EOS Make 'em your models,' tapping the fire-shovel on the hearth to add force to his words; 'do everything they bid you, and take their advice in all matters--especially the Dodger's, my dear. EOS He'll be a great man himself, and will make you one too, if you take pattern by him.--Is my handkerchief hanging out of my pocket, my dear?' EOS said the Jew, stopping short. EOS 'I never saw a sharper lad. EOS Here's a shilling for you. EOS And now come here, and I'll show you how to take the marks out of the handkerchiefs.' EOS But, thinking that the Jew, being so much his senior, must know best, he followed him quietly to the table, and was soon deeply involved in his new study. EOS CHAPTER X  OLIVER BECOMES BETTER ACQUAINTED WITH THE CHARACTERS OF HIS NEW ASSOCIATES; AND PURCHASES EXPERIENCE AT A HIGH PRICE. EOS At length, he began to languish for fresh air, and took many occasions of earnestly entreating the old gentleman to allow him to go out to work with his two companions. EOS Whenever the Dodger or Charley Bates came home at night, empty-handed, he would expatiate with great vehemence on the misery of idle and lazy habits; and would enforce upon them the necessity of an active life, by sending them supperless to bed. EOS On one occasion, indeed, he even went so far as to knock them both down a flight of stairs; but this was carrying out his virtuous precepts to an unusual extent. EOS Perhaps these were reasons for the old gentleman's giving his assent; but, whether they were or no, he told Oliver he might go, and placed him under the joint guardianship of Charley Bates, and his friend the Dodger. EOS The three boys sallied out; the Dodger with his coat-sleeves tucked up, and his hat cocked, as usual; Master Bates sauntering along with his hands in his pockets; and Oliver between them, wondering where they were going, and what branch of manufacture he would be instructed in, first. EOS The pace at which they went, was such a very lazy, ill-looking saunter, that Oliver soon began to think his companions were going to deceive the old gentleman, by not going to work at all. EOS The Dodger had a vicious propensity, too, of pulling the caps from the heads of small boys and tossing them down areas; while Charley Bates exhibited some very loose notions concerning the rights of property, by pilfering divers apples and onions from the stalls at the kennel sides, and thrusting them into pockets which were so surprisingly capacious, that they seemed to undermine his whole suit of clothes in every direction. EOS These things looked so bad, that Oliver was on the point of declaring his intention of seeking his way back, in the best way he could; when his thoughts were suddenly directed into another channel, by a very mysterious change of behaviour on the part of the Dodger. EOS They were just emerging from a narrow court not far from the open square in Clerkenwell, which is yet called, by some strange perversion of terms, 'The Green': when the Dodger made a sudden stop; and, laying his finger on his lip, drew his companions back again, with the greatest caution and circumspection. EOS 'What's the matter?' EOS demanded Oliver. EOS 'Hush!' EOS 'The old gentleman over the way?' EOS 'Yes, I see him.' EOS 'A prime plant,' observed Master Charley Bates. EOS Oliver looked from one to the other, with the greatest surprise; but he was not permitted to make any inquiries; for the two boys walked stealthily across the road, and slunk close behind the old gentleman towards whom his attention had been directed. EOS Oliver walked a few paces after them; and, not knowing whether to advance or retire, stood looking on in silent amazement. EOS The old gentleman was a very respectable-looking personage, with a powdered head and gold spectacles. EOS He was dressed in a bottle-green coat with a black velvet collar; wore white trousers; and carried a smart bamboo cane under his arm. EOS To see him hand the same to Charley Bates; and finally to behold them, both running away round the corner at full speed! EOS In an instant the whole mystery of the hankerchiefs, and the watches, and the jewels, and the Jew, rushed upon the boy's mind. EOS He stood, for a moment, with the blood so tingling through all his veins from terror, that he felt as if he were in a burning fire; then, confused and frightened, he took to his heels; and, not knowing what he did, made off as fast as he could lay his feet to the ground. EOS This was all done in a minute's space. EOS In the very instant when Oliver began to run, the old gentleman, putting his hand to his pocket, and missing his handkerchief, turned sharp round. EOS Seeing the boy scudding away at such a rapid pace, he very naturally concluded him to be the depredator; and shouting 'Stop thief!' EOS with all his might, made off after him, book in hand. EOS But the old gentleman was not the only person who raised the hue-and-cry. EOS The Dodger and Master Bates, unwilling to attract public attention by running down the open street, had merely retired into the very first doorway round the corner. EOS They no sooner heard the cry, and saw Oliver running, than, guessing exactly how the matter stood, they issued forth with great promptitude; and, shouting 'Stop thief!' EOS Although Oliver had been brought up by philosophers, he was not theoretically acquainted with the beautiful axiom that self-preservation is the first law of nature. EOS If he had been, perhaps he would have been prepared for this. EOS 'Stop thief! EOS Stop thief!' EOS There is a magic in the sound. EOS Away they run, pell-mell, helter-skelter, slap-dash: tearing, yelling, screaming, knocking down the passengers as they turn the corners, rousing up the dogs, and astonishing the fowls: and streets, squares, and courts, re-echo with the sound. EOS 'Stop thief! EOS Stop thief!' EOS The cry is taken up by a hundred voices, and the crowd accumulate at every turning. EOS Away they fly, splashing through the mud, and rattling along the pavements: up go the windows, out run the people, onward bear the mob, a whole audience desert Punch in the very thickest of the plot, and, joining the rushing throng, swell the shout, and lend fresh vigour to the cry, 'Stop thief! EOS Stop thief!' EOS 'Stop thief! EOS Stop thief!' EOS There is a passion FOR _hunting_ _something_ deeply implanted in the human breast. EOS 'Stop thief!' EOS A clever blow. EOS He is down upon the pavement; and the crowd eagerly gather round him:  each new comer, jostling and struggling with the others to catch a glimpse. EOS 'Stand aside!' EOS 'Give him a little air!' EOS 'Nonsense! EOS 'Where's the gentleman?' EOS 'Here his is, coming down the street.' EOS 'Make room there for the gentleman!' EOS 'Is this the boy, sir!' EOS 'Come, get up,' said the man, roughly. EOS 'It wasn't me indeed, sir. EOS 'They are here somewhere.' EOS 'Oh no, they ain't,' said the officer. EOS The boys shouted in triumph; and on they went. EOS CHAPTER XI  TREATS OF MR. FANG THE POLICE MAGISTRATE; AND FURNISHES A SLIGHT SPECIMEN OF HIS MODE OF ADMINISTERING JUSTICE  The offence had been committed within the district, and indeed in the immediate neighborhood of, a very notorious metropolitan police office. EOS The crowd had only the satisfaction of accompanying Oliver through two or three streets, and down a place called Mutton Hill, when he was led beneath a low archway, and up a dirty court, into this dispensary of summary justice, by the back way. EOS It was a small paved yard into which they turned; and here they encountered a stout man with a bunch of whiskers on his face, and a bunch of keys in his hand. EOS 'What's the matter now?' EOS said the man carelessly. EOS 'A young fogle-hunter,' replied the man who had Oliver in charge. EOS 'Are you the party that's been robbed, sir?' EOS 'Yes, I am,' replied the old gentleman; 'but I am not sure that this boy actually took the handkerchief. EOS I--I would rather not press the case.' EOS 'Must go before the magistrate now, sir,' replied the man. EOS This was an invitation for Oliver to enter through a door which he unlocked as he spoke, and which led into a stone cell. EOS Here he was searched; and nothing being found upon him, locked up. EOS This cell was in shape and size something like an area cellar, only not so light. EOS But this is little. EOS In our station-houses, men and women are every night confined on the most trivial charges--the word is worth noting--in dungeons, compared with which, those in Newgate, occupied by the most atrocious felons, tried, found guilty, and under sentence of death, are palaces. EOS Let any one who doubts this, compare the two. EOS The old gentleman looked almost as rueful as Oliver when the key grated in the lock. EOS He turned with a sigh to the book, which had been the innocent cause of all this disturbance. EOS _Can_ he be innocent? EOS 'No,' said the old gentleman, shaking his head; 'it must be imagination.' EOS He wandered over them again. EOS But the old gentleman could recall no one countenance of which Oliver's features bore a trace. EOS CHAPTER XII  IN WHICH OLIVER IS TAKEN BETTER CARE OF THAN HE EVER WAS BEFORE. EOS AND IN WHICH THE NARRATIVE REVERTS TO THE MERRY OLD GENTLEMAN AND HIS YOUTHFUL FRIENDS. EOS The coach rattled away, over nearly the same ground as that which Oliver had traversed when he first entered London in company with the Dodger; and, turning a different way when it reached the Angel at Islington, stopped at length before a neat house, in a quiet shady street near Pentonville. EOS The worm does not work more surely on the dead body, than does this slow creeping fire upon the living frame. EOS Weak, and thin, and pallid, he awoke at last from what seemed to have been a long and troubled dream. EOS Feebly raising himself in the bed, with his head resting on his trembling arm, he looked anxiously around. EOS 'What room is this? EOS Where have I been brought to?' EOS said Oliver. EOS 'This is not the place I went to sleep in.' EOS He uttered these words in a feeble voice, being very faint and weak; but they were overheard at once. EOS With those words, the old lady very gently placed Oliver's head upon the pillow; and, smoothing back his hair from his forehead, looked so kindly and loving in his face, that he could not help placing his little withered hand in hers, and drawing it round his neck. EOS 'What a grateful little dear it is. EOS What would his mother feel if she had sat by him as I have, and could see him now!' EOS I almost feel as if she had.' EOS 'If she had seen me hurt, it would have made her sorrowful; and her face has always looked sweet and happy, when I have dreamed of her.' EOS 'You _are_ a great deal better, are you not, my dear?' EOS 'Yes,  I know you are,' said the gentleman:  'You're hungry too, an't you?' EOS 'Hem!' EOS said the gentleman. EOS Oliver knew not the cause of this sudden exclamation; for, not being strong enough to bear the start it gave him, he fainted away. EOS A weakness on his part, which affords the narrative an opportunity of relieving the reader from suspense, in behalf of the two young pupils of the Merry Old Gentleman; and of recording--  That when the Dodger, and his accomplished friend Master Bates, joined in the hue-and-cry which was raised at Oliver's heels, in consequence of their executing an illegal conveyance of Mr. Brownlow's personal property, as has been already described, they were actuated by a very laudable and becoming regard for themselves; and forasmuch as the freedom of the subject and the liberty of the individual are among the first and proudest boasts of a true-hearted Englishman, so, I need hardly beg the reader to observe, that this action should tend to exalt them in the opinion of all public and patriotic men, in almost as great a degree as this strong proof of their anxiety for their own preservation and safety goes to corroborate and confirm the little code of laws which certain profound and sound-judging philosophers have laid down as the main-springs of all Nature's deeds and actions:  the said philosophers very wisely reducing the good lady's proceedings to matters of maxim and theory:  and, by a very neat and pretty compliment to her exalted wisdom and understanding, putting entirely out of sight any considerations of heart, or generous impulse and feeling. EOS Thus, to do a great right, you may do a little wrong; and you may take any means which the end to be attained, will justify; the amount of the right, or the amount of the wrong, or indeed the distinction between the two, being left entirely to the philosopher concerned, to be settled and determined by his clear, comprehensive, and impartial view of his own particular case. EOS It was not until the two boys had scoured, with great rapidity, through a most intricate maze of narrow streets and courts, that they ventured to halt beneath a low and dark archway. EOS Having remained silent here, just long enough to recover breath to speak, Master Bates uttered an exclamation of amusement and delight; and, bursting into an uncontrollable fit of laughter, flung himself upon a doorstep, and rolled thereon in a transport of mirth. EOS 'What's the matter?' EOS inquired the Dodger. EOS 'Ha! EOS ha!' EOS roared Charley Bates. EOS 'Do you want to be grabbed, stupid?' EOS 'I can't help it,' said Charley, 'I can't help it! EOS To see him splitting away at that pace, and cutting round the corners, and knocking up again' the posts, and starting on again as if he was made of iron as well as them, and me with the wipe in my pocket, singing out arter him--oh, my eye!' EOS The vivid imagination of Master Bates presented the scene before him in too strong colours. EOS 'What'll Fagin say?' EOS repeated Charley Bates. EOS 'Ah, what?' EOS 'What should he say?' EOS Mr. Dawkins whistled for a couple of minutes; then, taking off his hat, scratched his head, and nodded thrice. EOS 'What do you mean?' EOS said Charley. EOS 'Toor rul lol loo, gammon and spinnage, the frog he wouldn't, and high cockolorum,' said the Dodger:  with a slight sneer on his intellectual countenance. EOS There was a rascally smile on his white face as he turned round, and looking sharply out from under his thick red eyebrows, bent his ear towards the door, and listened. EOS 'Why, how's this?' EOS Mr. Fagin looked so very much in earnest, that Charley Bates, who deemed it prudent in all cases to be on the safe side, and who conceived it by no means improbable that it might be his turn to be throttled second, dropped upon his knees, and raised a loud, well-sustained, and continuous roar--something between a mad bull and a speaking trumpet. EOS 'Will you speak?' EOS thundered the Jew:  shaking the Dodger so much that his keeping in the big coat at all, seemed perfectly miraculous. EOS said the Jew. EOS 'Bet will go; won't you, my dear?' EOS 'Wheres?' EOS 'Only just up to the office, my dear,' said the Jew coaxingly. EOS Entering by the back way, she tapped softly with the key at one of the cell-doors, and listened. EOS There was no sound within:  so she coughed and listened again. EOS CHAPTER XIV  COMPRISING FURTHER PARTICULARS OF OLIVER'S STAY AT MR. BROWNLOW'S, WITH THE REMARKABLE PREDICTION WHICH ONE MR. EOS CHAPTER XV  SHOWING HOW VERY FOND OF OLIVER TWIST, THE MERRY OLD JEW AND MISS NANCY WERE  In the obscure parlour of a low public-house, in the filthiest part of Little Saffron Hill; a dark and gloomy den, where a flaring gas-light burnt all day in the winter-time; and where no ray of sun ever shone in the summer:  there sat, brooding over a little pewter measure and a small glass, strongly impregnated with the smell of liquor, a man in a velveteen coat, drab shorts, half-boots and stockings, whom even by that dim light no experienced agent of the police would have hesitated to recognise as Mr. William Sikes. EOS At his feet, sat a white-coated, red-eyed dog; who occupied himself, alternately, in winking at his master with both eyes at the same time; and in licking a large, fresh cut on one side of his mouth, which appeared to be the result of some recent conflict. EOS 'Keep quiet, you warmint! EOS Whether his meditations were so intense as to be disturbed by the dog's winking, or whether his feelings were so wrought upon by his reflections that they required all the relief derivable from kicking an unoffending animal to allay them, is matter for argument and consideration. EOS Having given in a hearty shake, he retired, growling, under a form; just escaping the pewter measure which Mr. Sikes levelled at his head. EOS 'You would, would you?' EOS CHAPTER XVI  RELATES WHAT BECAME OF OLIVER TWIST, AFTER HE HAD BEEN CLAIMED BY NANCY  The narrow streets and courts, at length, terminated in a large open space; scattered about which, were pens for beasts, and other indications of a cattle-market. EOS Sikes slackened his pace when they reached this spot:  the girl being quite unable to support any longer, the rapid rate at which they had hitherto walked. EOS growled Sikes, as Oliver hesitated, and looked round. EOS 'Here, Bull's-Eye!' EOS The dog looked up, and growled. EOS 'See here, boy!' EOS said Sikes, putting his other hand to Oliver's throat; 'if he speaks ever so soft a word, hold him! EOS D'ye mind!' EOS The dog growled again; and licking his lips, eyed Oliver as if he were anxious to attach himself to his windpipe without delay. EOS 'He's as willing as a Christian, strike me blind if he isn't!' EOS 'Now, you know what you've got to expect, master, so call away as quick as you like; the dog will soon stop that game. EOS Get on, young'un!' EOS Bull's-eye wagged his tail in acknowledgment of this unusually endearing form of speech; and, giving vent to another admonitory growl for the benefit of Oliver, led the way onward. EOS It was Smithfield that they were crossing, although it might have been Grosvenor Square, for anything Oliver knew to the contrary. EOS The night was dark and foggy. EOS The lights in the shops could scarecely struggle through the heavy mist, which thickened every moment and shrouded the streets and houses in gloom; rendering the strange place still stranger in Oliver's eyes; and making his uncertainty the more dismal and depressing. EOS They had hurried on a few paces, when a deep church-bell struck the hour. EOS With its first stroke, his two conductors stopped, and turned their heads in the direction whence the sound proceeded. EOS 'Eight o' clock, Bill,' said Nancy, when the bell ceased. EOS replied Sikes. EOS 'I wonder whether THEY can hear it,' said Nancy. EOS Arter I was locked up for the night, the row and din outside made the thundering old jail so silent, that I could almost have beat my brains out against the iron plates of the door.' EOS 'Poor fellow!' EOS 'Yes; that's all you women think of,' answered Sikes. EOS 'Fine young chaps! EOS Well, they're as good as dead, so it don't much matter.' EOS With this consolation, Mr. Sikes appeared to repress a rising tendency to jealousy, and, clasping Oliver's wrist more firmly, told him to step out again. EOS 'Wait a minute!' EOS said the girl:  'I wouldn't hurry by, if it was you that was coming out to be hung, the next time eight o'clock struck, Bill. EOS 'Unless you could pitch over a file and twenty yards of good stout rope, you might as well be walking fifty mile off, or not walking at all, for all the good it would do me. EOS Come on, and don't stand preaching there.' EOS But Oliver felt her hand tremble, and, looking up in her face as they passed a gas-lamp, saw that it had turned a deadly white. EOS They walked on, by little-frequented and dirty ways, for a full half-hour:  meeting very few people, and those appearing from their looks to hold much the same position in society as Mr. Sikes himself. EOS 'All right,' cried Sikes, glancing cautiously about. EOS Nancy stooped below the shutters, and Oliver heard the sound of a bell. EOS They crossed to the opposite side of the street, and stood for a few moments under a lamp. EOS Mr. Sikes then seized the terrified boy by the collar with very little ceremony; and all three were quickly inside the house. EOS The passage was perfectly dark. EOS 'Anybody here?' EOS inquired Sikes. EOS 'No,' replied a voice, which Oliver thought he had heard before. EOS asked the robber. EOS Oh, no!' EOS The style of this reply, as well as the voice which delivered it, seemed familiar to Oliver's ears:  but it was impossible to distinguish even the form of the speaker in the darkness. EOS Look after your legs if you do!' EOS 'Stand still a moment, and I'll get you one,' replied the voice. EOS The receding footsteps of the speaker were heard; and, in another minute, the form of Mr. John Dawkins, otherwise the Artful Dodger, appeared. EOS He bore in his right hand a tallow candle stuck in the end of a cleft stick. EOS The young gentleman did not stop to bestow any other mark of recognition upon Oliver than a humourous grin; but, turning away, beckoned the visitors to follow him down a flight of stairs. EOS They crossed an empty kitchen; and, opening the door of a low earthy-smelling room, which seemed to have been built in a small back-yard, were received with a shout of laughter. EOS 'Oh, my wig, my wig!' EOS cried Master Charles Bates, from whose lungs the laughter had proceeded:  'here he is! EOS Oh, Fagin, look at him! EOS Hold me, somebody, while I laugh it out.' EOS With this irrepressible ebullition of mirth, Master Bates laid himself flat on the floor: and kicked convulsively for five minutes, in an ectasy of facetious joy. EOS The Artful, meantime, who was of a rather saturnine disposition, and seldom gave way to merriment when it interfered with business, rifled Oliver's pockets with steady assiduity. EOS 'Look at his togs, Fagin!' EOS said Charley, putting the light so close to his new jacket as nearly to set him on fire. EOS Superfine cloth, and the heavy swell cut! EOS And his books, too! EOS Nothing but a gentleman, Fagin!' EOS 'The Artful shall give you another suit, my dear, for fear you should spoil that Sunday one. EOS Why didn't you write, my dear, and say you were coming? EOS At his, Master Bates roared again: so loud, that Fagin himself relaxed, and even the Dodger smiled; but as the Artful drew forth the five-pound note at that instant, it is doubtful whether the sally of the discovery awakened his merriment. EOS 'Hallo, what's that?' EOS 'No, no, my dear,' said the Jew. EOS 'Mine, Bill, mine. EOS You shall have the books.' EOS 'If that ain't mine!' EOS The Jew started. EOS Oliver started too, though from a very different cause; for he hoped that the dispute might really end in his being taken back. EOS 'Come! EOS Hand over, will you?' EOS said Sikes. EOS 'This is hardly fair, Bill; hardly fair, is it, Nancy?' EOS inquired the Jew. EOS Give it here, you avaricious old skeleton, give it here!' EOS With this gentle remonstrance, Mr. Sikes plucked the note from between the Jew's finger and thumb; and looking the old man coolly in the face, folded it up small, and tied it in his neckerchief. EOS 'That's for our share of the trouble,' said Sikes; 'and not half enough, neither. EOS You may keep the books, if you're fond of reading. EOS If you ain't, sell 'em.' EOS At sight of the dismayed look with which Oliver regarded his tormentors, Master Bates, who was blessed with a lively sense of the ludicrous, fell into another ectasy, more boisterous than the first. EOS 'They belong to the old gentleman,' said Oliver, wringing his hands; 'to the good, kind, old gentleman who took me into his house, and had me nursed, when I was near dying of the fever. EOS Keep me here all my life long; but pray, pray send them back. EOS He'll think I stole them; the old lady: all of them who were so kind to me: will think I stole them. EOS With these words, which were uttered with all the energy of passionate grief, Oliver fell upon his knees at the Jew's feet; and beat his hands together, in perfect desperation. EOS 'The boy's right,' remarked Fagin, looking covertly round, and knitting his shaggy eyebrows into a hard knot. EOS Ha! EOS ha!' EOS chuckled the Jew, rubbing his hands, 'it couldn't have happened better, if we had chosen our time!' EOS 'Of course it couldn't,' replied Sikes; 'I know'd that, directly I see him coming through Clerkenwell, with the books under his arm. EOS It's all right enough. EOS They're soft-hearted psalm-singers, or they wouldn't have taken him in at all; and they'll ask no questions after him, fear they should be obliged to prosecute, and so get him lagged. EOS He's safe enough.' EOS Oliver had looked from one to the other, while these words were being spoken, as if he were bewildered, and could scarecely understand what passed; but when Bill Sikes concluded, he jumped suddenly to his feet, and tore wildly from the room:  uttering shrieks for help, which made the bare old house echo to the roof. EOS 'Keep back the dog, Bill!' EOS 'Keep back the dog; he'll tear the boy to pieces.' EOS 'Serve him right!' EOS cried Sikes, struggling to disengage himself from the girl's grasp. EOS 'Shan't he!' EOS said Sikes, setting his teeth. EOS 'I'll soon do that, if you don't keep off.' EOS 'What's the matter here!' EOS 'The girl's gone mad, I think,' replied Sikes, savagely. EOS 'Then keep quiet, will you?' EOS said the Jew, with a threatening look. EOS 'No, I won't do that, neither,' replied Nancy, speaking very loud. EOS 'Come! EOS With the view of diverting the attention of the company, he turned to Oliver. EOS said the Jew, taking up a jagged and knotted club which law in a corner of the fireplace; 'eh?' EOS sneered the Jew, catching the boy by the arm. EOS The Jew inflicted a smart blow on Oliver's shoulders with the club; and was raising it for a second, when the girl, rushing forward, wrested it from his hand. EOS She flung it into the fire, with a force that brought some of the glowing coals whirling out into the room. EOS 'I won't stand by and see it done, Fagin,' cried the girl. EOS 'You've got the boy, and what more would you have?--Let him be--let him be--or I shall put that mark on some of you, that will bring me to the gallows before my time.' EOS The girl stamped her foot violently on the floor as she vented this threat; and with her lips compressed, and her hands clenched, looked alternately at the Jew and the other robber: her face quite colourless from the passion of rage into which she had gradually worked herself. EOS 'Why, Nancy!' EOS said the Jew, in a soothing tone; after a pause, during which he and Mr. Sikes had stared at one another in a disconcerted manner; 'you,--you're more clever than ever to-night. EOS ha! EOS my dear, you are acting beautifully.' EOS said the girl. EOS 'Take care I don't overdo it. EOS You will be the worse for it, Fagin, if I do; and so I tell you in good time to keep clear of me.' EOS The Jew saw that it would be hopeless to affect any further mistake regarding the reality of Miss Nancy's rage; and, shrinking involuntarily back a few paces, cast a glance, half imploring and half cowardly, at Sikes: as if to hint that he was the fittest person to pursue the dialogue. EOS As they produced no visible effect on the object against whom they were discharged, however, he resorted to more tangible arguments. EOS 'What do you mean by this?' EOS Burn my body! EOS Do you know who you are, and what you are?' EOS 'Well, then, keep quiet,' rejoined Sikes, with a growl like that he was accustomed to use when addressing his dog, 'or I'll quiet you for a good long time to come.' EOS The girl laughed again: even less composedly than before; and, darting a hasty look at Sikes, turned her face aside, and bit her lip till the blood came. EOS 'God Almighty help me, I am!' EOS cried the girl passionately; 'and I wish I had been struck dead in the street, or had changed places with them we passed so near to-night, before I had lent a hand in bringing him here. EOS Isn't that enough for the old wretch, without blows?' EOS 'Civil words, you villain! EOS pointing to Oliver. EOS 'I have been in the same trade, and in the same service, for twelve years since. EOS Don't you know it? EOS Speak out! EOS 'It is my living; and the cold, wet, dirty streets are my home; and you're the wretch that drove me to them long ago, and that'll keep me there, day and night, day and night, till I die!' EOS The girl said nothing more; but, tearing her hair and dress in a transport of passion, made such a rush at the Jew as would probably have left signal marks of her revenge upon him, had not her wrists been seized by Sikes at the right moment; upon which, she made a few ineffectual struggles, and fainted. EOS 'She's all right now,' said Sikes, laying her down in a corner. EOS 'She's uncommon strong in the arms, when she's up in this way.' EOS 'It's the worst of having to do with women,' said the Jew, replacing his club; 'but they're clever, and we can't get on, in our line, without 'em. EOS 'I suppose he'd better not wear his best clothes tomorrow, Fagin, had he?' EOS Master Bates, apparently much delighted with his commission, took the cleft stick: and led Oliver into an adjacent kitchen, where there were two or three of the beds on which he had slept before; and here, with many uncontrollable bursts of laughter, he produced the identical old suit of clothes which Oliver had so much congratulated himself upon leaving off at Mr. Brownlow's; and the accidental display of which, to Fagin, by the Jew who purchased them, had been the very first clue received, of his whereabout. EOS 'Put off the smart ones,' said Charley, 'and I'll give 'em to Fagin to take care of. EOS What fun it is!' EOS Poor Oliver unwillingly complied. EOS Master Bates rolling up the new clothes under his arm, departed from the room, leaving Oliver in the dark, and locking the door behind him. EOS The noise of Charley's laughter, and the voice of Miss Betsy, who opportunely arrived to throw water over her friend, and perform other feminine offices for the promotion of her recovery, might have kept many people awake under more happy circumstances than those in which Oliver was placed. EOS But he was sick and weary; and he soon fell sound asleep. EOS CHAPTER XVII  OLIVER'S DESTINY CONTINUING UNPROPITIOUS, BRINGS A GREAT MAN TO LONDON TO INJURE HIS REPUTATION  It is the custom on the stage, in all good murderous melodramas, to present the tragic and the comic scenes, in as regular alternation, as the layers of red and white in a side of streaky bacon. EOS We behold, with throbbing bosoms, the heroine in the grasp of a proud and ruthless baron: her virtue and her life alike in danger, drawing forth her dagger to preserve the one at the cost of the other; and just as our expectations are wrought up to the highest pitch, a whistle is heard, and we are straightway transported to the great hall of the castle; where a grey-headed seneschal sings a funny chorus with a funnier body of vassals, who are free of all sorts of places, from church vaults to palaces, and roam about in company, carolling perpetually. EOS Such changes appear absurd; but they are not so unnatural as they would seem at first sight. EOS The actors in the mimic life of the theatre, are blind to violent transitions and abrupt impulses of passion or feeling, which, presented before the eyes of mere spectators, are at once condemned as outrageous and preposterous. EOS If so, let it be considered a delicate intimation on the part of the historian that he is going back to the town in which Oliver Twist was born; the reader taking it for granted that there are good and substantial reasons for making the journey, or he would not be invited to proceed upon such an expedition. EOS Mr. Bumble emerged at early morning from the workhouse-gate, and walked with portly carriage and commanding steps, up the High Street. EOS Mr. Bumble always carried his head high; but this morning it was higher than usual. EOS There was an abstraction in his eye, an elevation in his air, which might have warned an observant stranger that thoughts were passing in the beadle's mind, too great for utterance. EOS Mr. Bumble stopped not to converse with the small shopkeepers and others who spoke to him, deferentially, as he passed along. EOS said Mrs. Mann, hearing the well-known shaking at the garden-gate. EOS 'If it isn't him at this time in the morning! EOS Well, dear me, it IS a pleasure, this is! EOS Come into the parlour, sir, please.' EOS The first sentence was addressed to Susan; and the exclamations of delight were uttered to Mr. Bumble: as the good lady unlocked the garden-gate: and showed him, with great attention and respect, into the house. EOS Mann,' said Mr. Bumble; not sitting upon, or dropping himself into a seat, as any common jackanapes would: but letting himself gradually and slowly down into a chair; 'Mrs. EOS Mann, ma'am, good morning.' EOS 'Well, and good morning to _you_, sir,' replied Mrs. Mann, with many smiles; 'and hoping you find yourself well, sir!' EOS 'So-so, Mrs. Mann,' replied the beadle. EOS 'A porochial life is not a bed of roses, Mrs. EOS 'Ah, that it isn't indeed, Mr. Bumble,' rejoined the lady. EOS And all the infant paupers might have chorussed the rejoinder with great propriety, if they had heard it. EOS 'A porochial life, ma'am,' continued Mr. Bumble, striking the table with his cane, 'is a life of worrit, and vexation, and hardihood; but all public characters, as I may say, must suffer prosecution.' EOS You may well sigh, Mrs. EOS Mann!' EOS Finding she had done right, Mrs. Mann sighed again:  evidently to the satisfaction of the public character:  who, repressing a complacent smile by looking sternly at his cocked hat, said,  'Mrs. EOS Mann, I am going to London.' EOS 'Lauk, Mr. EOS Bumble!' EOS cried Mrs. Mann, starting back. EOS 'To London, ma'am,' resumed the inflexible beadle, 'by coach. EOS I and two paupers, Mrs. Mann! EOS A legal action is a coming on, about a settlement; and the board has appointed me--me, Mrs. Mann--to dispose to the matter before the quarter-sessions at Clerkinwell. EOS And I very much question,' added Mr. Bumble, drawing himself up, 'whether the Clerkinwell Sessions will not find themselves in the wrong box before they have done with me.' EOS you mustn't be too hard upon them, sir,' said Mrs. Mann, coaxingly. EOS 'The Clerkinwell Sessions have brought it upon themselves, ma'am,' replied Mr. Bumble; 'and if the Clerkinwell Sessions find that they come off rather worse than they expected, the Clerkinwell Sessions have only themselves to thank.' EOS At length she said,  'You're going by coach, sir? EOS I thought it was always usual to send them paupers in carts.' EOS 'The opposition coach contracts for these two; and takes them cheap,' said Mr. Bumble. EOS 'They are both in a very low state, and we find it would come two pound cheaper to move 'em than to bury 'em--that is, if we can throw 'em upon another parish, which I think we shall be able to do, if they don't die upon the road to spite us. EOS Ha! EOS ha!' EOS When Mr. Bumble had laughed a little while, his eyes again encountered the cocked hat; and he became grave. EOS 'We are forgetting business, ma'am,' said the beadle; 'here is your porochial stipend for the month.' EOS 'It's very much blotted, sir,' said the farmer of infants; 'but it's formal enough, I dare say. EOS Thank you, Mr. Bumble, sir, I am very much obliged to you, I'm sure.' EOS 'Can't you look at the gentleman, you obstinate boy?' EOS The child meekly raised his eyes, and encountered those of Mr. Bumble. EOS 'What's the matter with you, porochial Dick?' EOS Mr. Bumble shortly afterwards took himself off, to prepare for his journey. EOS At six o'clock next morning, Mr. Bumble:  having exchanged his cocked hat for a round one, and encased his person in a blue great-coat with a cape to it:  took his place on the outside of the coach, accompanied by the criminals whose settlement was disputed; with whom, in due course of time, he arrived in London. EOS Having disposed of these evil-minded persons for the night, Mr. Bumble sat himself down in the house at which the coach stopped; and took a temperate dinner of steaks, oyster sauce, and porter. EOS The above reward will be paid to any person who will give such information as will lead to the discovery of the said Oliver Twist, or tend to throw any light upon his previous history, in which the advertiser is, for many reasons, warmly interested.' EOS And then followed a full description of Oliver's dress, person, appearance, and disappearance:  with the name and address of Mr. Brownlow at full length. EOS To this inquiry the girl returned the not uncommon, but rather evasive reply of 'I don't know; where do you come from?' EOS I knew we should! EOS I was certain of it. EOS Bless his heart! EOS I said so all along.' EOS The girl, who was not quite so susceptible, had run upstairs meanwhile; and now returned with a request that Mr. Bumble would follow her immediately: which he did.
