EOS 'Yes, sir,' said Mr. Bumble. EOS 'And you ARE a beadle, are you not?' EOS 'I am a porochial beadle, gentlemen,' rejoined Mr. Bumble proudly. EOS A beadle all over!' EOS Mr. Brownlow gently shook his head to impose silence on his friend, and resumed:  'Do you know where this poor boy is now?' EOS 'No more than nobody,' replied Mr. Bumble. EOS 'Well, what DO you know of him?' EOS 'Speak out, my friend, if you have anything to say. EOS What DO you know of him?' EOS 'You see?' EOS Mr. Brownlow looked apprehensively at Mr. Bumble's pursed-up countenance; and requested him to communicate what he knew regarding Oliver, in as few words as possible. EOS Mr. Bumble put down his hat; unbuttoned his coat; folded his arms; inclined his head in a retrospective manner; and, after a few moments' reflection, commenced his story. EOS It would be tedious if given in the beadle's words:  occupying, as it did, some twenty minutes in the telling; but the sum and substance of it was, that Oliver was a foundling, born of low and vicious parents. EOS That he had, from his birth, displayed no better qualities than treachery, ingratitude, and malice. EOS That he had terminated his brief career in the place of his birth, by making a sanguinary and cowardly attack on an unoffending lad, and running away in the night-time from his master's house. EOS Folding his arms again, he then awaited Mr. Brownlow's observations. EOS 'I fear it is all too true,' said the old gentleman sorrowfully, after looking over the papers. EOS It was too late to do it now, however; so he shook his head gravely, and, pocketing the five guineas, withdrew. EOS At length he stopped, and rang the bell violently. EOS Bedwin,' said Mr. Brownlow, when the housekeeper appeared; 'that boy, Oliver, is an imposter.' EOS 'It can't be, sir. EOS It cannot be,' said the old lady energetically. EOS 'I tell you he is,' retorted the old gentleman. EOS 'What do you mean by can't be? EOS 'I never will believe it, sir,' replied the old lady, firmly. EOS 'Never!' EOS Bah!' EOS 'He was a dear, grateful, gentle child, sir,' retorted Mrs. Bedwin, indignantly. EOS 'I know what children are, sir; and have done these forty years; and people who can't say the same, shouldn't say anything about them. EOS That's my opinion!' EOS 'Silence!' EOS said the old gentleman, feigning an anger he was far from feeling. EOS Never. EOS Never, on any pretence, mind! EOS You may leave the room, Mrs. Bedwin. EOS Remember! EOS There were sad hearts at Mr. Brownlow's that night. EOS Mr. Fagin laid great stress on the fact of his having taken Oliver in, and cherished him, when, without his timely aid, he might have perished with hunger; and he related the dismal and affecting history of a young lad whom, in his philanthropy, he had succoured under parallel circumstances, but who, proving unworthy of his confidence and evincing a desire to communicate with the police, had unfortunately come to be hanged at the Old Bailey one morning. EOS Mr. Fagin did not seek to conceal his share in the catastrophe, but lamented with tears in his eyes that the wrong-headed and treacherous behaviour of the young person in question, had rendered it necessary that he should become the victim of certain evidence for the crown: which, if it were not precisely true, was indispensably necessary for the safety of him (Mr. Fagin) and a few select friends. EOS Mr. Fagin concluded by drawing a rather disagreeable picture of the discomforts of hanging; and, with great friendliness and politeness of manner, expressed his anxious hopes that he might never be obliged to submit Oliver Twist to that unpleasant operation. EOS Little Oliver's blood ran cold, as he listened to the Jew's words, and imperfectly comprehended the dark threats conveyed in them. EOS That it was possible even for justice itself to confound the innocent with the guilty when they were in accidental companionship, he knew already; and that deeply-laid plans for the destruction of inconveniently knowing or over-communicative persons, had been really devised and carried out by the Jew on more occasions than one, he thought by no means unlikely, when he recollected the general nature of the altercations between that gentleman and Mr. Sikes: which seemed to bear reference to some foregone conspiracy of the kind. EOS The Jew, smiling hideously, patted Oliver on the head, and said, that if he kept himself quiet, and applied himself to business, he saw they would be very good friends yet. EOS Then, taking his hat, and covering himself with an old patched great-coat, he went out, and locked the room-door behind him. EOS Which, never failing to revert to his kind friends, and the opinion they must long ago have formed of him, were sad indeed. EOS After the lapse of a week or so, the Jew left the room-door unlocked; and he was at liberty to wander about the house. EOS The rooms upstairs had great high wooden chimney-pieces and large doors, with panelled walls and cornices to the ceiling; which, although they were black with neglect and dust, were ornamented in various ways. EOS From all of these tokens Oliver concluded that a long time ago, before the old Jew was born, it had belonged to better people, and had perhaps been quite gay and handsome:  dismal and dreary as it looked now. EOS Spiders had built their webs in the angles of the walls and ceilings; and sometimes, when Oliver walked softly into a room, the mice would scamper across the floor, and run back terrified to their holes. EOS In all the rooms, the mouldering shutters were fast closed:  the bars which held them were screwed tight into the wood; the only light which was admitted, stealing its way through round holes at the top: which made the rooms more gloomy, and filled them with strange shadows. EOS There was a back-garret window with rusty bars outside, which had no shutter; and out of this, Oliver often gazed with a melancholy face for hours together; but nothing was to be descried from it but a confused and crowded mass of housetops, blackened chimneys, and gable-ends. EOS One afternoon, the Dodger and Master Bates being engaged out that evening, the first-named young gentleman took it into his head to evince some anxiety regarding the decoration of his person (to do him justice, this was by no means an habitual weakness with him); and, with this end and aim, he condescendingly commanded Oliver to assist him in his toilet, straightway. EOS The phrase, rendered into plain English, signifieth, cleaning his boots. EOS Whether it was the sense of freedom and independence which a rational animal may be supposed to feel when he sits on a table in an easy attitude smoking a pipe, swinging one leg carelessly to and fro, and having his boots cleaned all the time, without even the past trouble of having taken them off, or the prospective misery of putting them on, to disturb his reflections; or whether it was the goodness of the tobacco that soothed the feelings of the Dodger, or the mildness of the beer that mollified his thoughts; he was evidently tinctured, for the nonce, with a spice of romance and enthusiasm, foreign to his general nature. EOS He looked down on Oliver, with a thoughtful countenance, for a brief space; and then, raising his head, and heaving a gentle sign, said, half in abstraction, and half to Master Bates:  'What a pity it is he isn't a prig!' EOS 'Ah!' EOS said Master Charles Bates; 'he don't know what's good for him.' EOS The Dodger sighed again, and resumed his pipe: as did Charley Bates. EOS They both smoked, for some seconds, in silence. EOS 'I suppose you don't even know what a prig is?' EOS 'It's a the--; you're one, are you not?' EOS 'I'd scorn to be anything else.' EOS Mr. Dawkins gave his hat a ferocious cock, after delivering this sentiment, and looked at Master Bates, as if to denote that he would feel obliged by his saying anything to the contrary. EOS So's Fagin. EOS So's Bet. EOS So we all are, down to the dog. EOS And he's the downiest one of the lot!' EOS 'And the least given to peaching,' added Charley Bates. EOS 'He wouldn't so much as bark in a witness-box, for fear of committing himself; no, not if you tied him up in one, and left him there without wittles for a fortnight,' said the Dodger. EOS These were, the great advantages of the trade, the proficiency of the Dodger, the amiability of Charley Bates, and the liberality of the Jew himself. EOS From this day, Oliver was seldom left alone; but was placed in almost constant communication with the two boys, who played the old game with the Jew every day: whether for their own improvement or Oliver's, Mr. Fagin best knew. EOS At other times the old man would tell them stories of robberies he had committed in his younger days:  mixed up with so much that was droll and curious, that Oliver could not help laughing heartily, and showing that he was amused in spite of all his better feelings. EOS In short, the wily old Jew had the boy in his toils. EOS CHAPTER XIX  IN WHICH A NOTABLE PLAN IS DISCUSSED AND DETERMINED ON  It was a chill, damp, windy night, when the Jew: buttoning his great-coat tight round his shrivelled body, and pulling the collar up over his ears so as completely to obscure the lower part of his face: emerged from his den. EOS CHAPTER XXI  THE EXPEDITION  It was a cheerless morning when they got into the street; blowing and raining hard; and the clouds looking dull and stormy. EOS There was a faint glimmering of the coming day in the sky; but it rather aggravated than relieved the gloom of the scene:  the sombre light only serving to pale that which the street lamps afforded, without shedding any warmer or brighter tints upon the wet house-tops, and dreary streets. EOS By the time they had turned into the Bethnal Green Road, the day had fairly begun to break. EOS Many of the lamps were already extinguished; a few country waggons were slowly toiling on, towards London; now and then, a stage-coach, covered with mud, rattled briskly by: the driver bestowing, as he passed, an admonitory lash upon the heavy waggoner who, by keeping on the wrong side of the road, had endangered his arriving at the office, a quarter of a minute after his time. EOS The public-houses, with gas-lights burning inside, were already open. EOS By degrees, other shops began to be unclosed, and a few scattered people were met with. EOS It was as light as it was likely to be, till night came on again, and the busy morning of half the London population had begun. EOS All the pens in the centre of the large area, and as many temporary pens as could be crowded into the vacant space, were filled with sheep; tied up to posts by the gutter side were long lines of beasts and oxen, three or four deep. EOS Countrymen, butchers, drovers, hawkers, boys, thieves, idlers, and vagabonds of every low grade, were mingled together in a mass; the whistling of drovers, the barking dogs, the bellowing and plunging of the oxen, the bleating of sheep, the grunting and squeaking of pigs, the cries of hawkers, the shouts, oaths, and quarrelling on all sides; the ringing of bells and roar of voices, that issued from every public-house; the crowding, pushing, driving, beating, whooping and yelling; the hideous and discordant dim that resounded from every corner of the market; and the unwashed, unshaven, squalid, and dirty figures constantly running to and fro, and bursting in and out of the throng; rendered it a stunning and bewildering scene, which quite confounded the senses. EOS Mr. Sikes, dragging Oliver after him, elbowed his way through the thickest of the crowd, and bestowed very little attention on the numerous sights and sounds, which so astonished the boy. EOS He nodded, twice or thrice, to a passing friend; and, resisting as many invitations to take a morning dram, pressed steadily onward, until they were clear of the turmoil, and had made their way through Hosier Lane into Holborn. EOS 'Now, young 'un!' EOS you must step out. EOS Come, don't lag behind already, Lazy-legs!' EOS Mr. Sikes accompanied this speech with a jerk at his little companion's wrist; Oliver, quickening his pace into a kind of trot between a fast walk and a run, kept up with the rapid strides of the house-breaker as well as he could. EOS They held their course at this rate, until they had passed Hyde Park corner, and were on their way to Kensington:  when Sikes relaxed his pace, until an empty cart which was at some little distance behind, came up. EOS Seeing 'Hounslow' written on it, he asked the driver with as much civility as he could assume, if he would give them a lift as far as Isleworth. EOS 'Jump up,' said the man. EOS 'Is that your boy?' EOS 'Your father walks rather too quick for you, don't he, my man?' EOS inquired the driver: seeing that Oliver was out of breath. EOS Thus addressing Oliver, he helped him into the cart; and the driver, pointing to a heap of sacks, told him to lie down there, and rest himself. EOS As they passed the different mile-stones, Oliver wondered, more and more, where his companion meant to take him. EOS At length, they came to a public-house called the Coach and Horses; a little way beyond which, another road appeared to run off. EOS And here, the cart stopped. EOS Sikes dismounted with great precipitation, holding Oliver by the hand all the while; and lifting him down directly, bestowed a furious look upon him, and rapped the side-pocket with his fist, in a significant manner. EOS They turned round to the left, a short way past the public-house; and then, taking a right-hand road, walked on for a long time: passing many large gardens and gentlemen's houses on both sides of the way, and stopping for nothing but a little beer, until they reached a town. EOS They lingered about, in the fields, for some hours. EOS CHAPTER XXIII  WHICH CONTAINS THE SUBSTANCE OF A PLEASANT CONVERSATION BETWEEN MR. BUMBLE AND A LADY; AND SHOWS THAT EVEN A BEADLE MAY BE SUSCEPTIBLE ON SOME POINTS  The night was bitter cold. EOS The snow lay on the ground, frozen into a hard thick crust, so that only the heaps that had drifted into byways and corners were affected by the sharp wind that howled abroad:  which, as if expending increased fury on such prey as it found, caught it savagely up in clouds, and, whirling it into a thousand misty eddies, scattered it in air. EOS Bleak, dark, and piercing cold, it was a night for the well-housed and fed to draw round the bright fire and thank God they were at home; and for the homeless, starving wretch to lay him down and die. EOS Many hunger-worn outcasts close their eyes in our bare streets, at such times, who, let their crimes have been what they may, can hardly open them in a more bitter world. EOS Such was the aspect of out-of-doors affairs, when Mrs. Corney, the matron of the workhouse to which our readers have been already introduced as the birthplace of Oliver Twist, sat herself down before a cheerful fire in her own little room, and glanced, with no small degree of complacency, at a small round table:  on which stood a tray of corresponding size, furnished with all necessary materials for the most grateful meal that matrons enjoy. EOS In fact, Mrs. Corney was about to solace herself with a cup of tea. EOS Mr. Bumble's conduct on being left to himself, was rather inexplicable. EOS CHAPTER XXIV  TREATS ON A VERY POOR SUBJECT. EOS BUT IS A SHORT ONE, AND MAY BE FOUND OF IMPORTANCE IN THIS HISTORY  It was no unfit messenger of death, who had disturbed the quiet of the matron's room. EOS How few of Nature's faces are left alone to gladden us with their beauty! EOS The cares, and sorrows, and hungerings, of the world, change them as they change hearts; and it is only when those passions sleep, and have lost their hold for ever, that the troubled clouds pass off, and leave Heaven's surface clear. EOS It is a common thing for the countenances of the dead, even in that fixed and rigid state, to subside into the long-forgotten expression of sleeping infancy, and settle into the very look of early life; so calm, so peaceful, do they grow again, that those who knew them in their happy childhood, kneel by the coffin's side in awe, and see the Angel even upon earth. EOS Confined as the limits of Field Lane are, it has its barber, its coffee-shop, its beer-shop, and its fried-fish warehouse. EOS It is a commercial colony of itself:  the emporium of petty larceny: visited at early morning, and setting-in of dusk, by silent merchants, who traffic in dark back-parlours, and who go as strangely as they come. EOS The Three Cripples, or rather the Cripples; which was the sign by which the establishment was familiarly known to its patrons:  was the public-house in which Mr. Sikes and his dog have already figured. EOS When this was over, the chairman gave a sentiment, after which, the professional gentleman on the chairman's right and left volunteered a duet, and sang it, with great applause. EOS There was the chairman himself, (the landlord of the house,) a coarse, rough, heavy built fellow, who, while the songs were proceeding, rolled his eyes hither and thither, and, seeming to give himself up to joviality, had an eye for everything that was done, and an ear for everything that was said--and sharp ones, too. EOS Near him were the singers: receiving, with professional indifference, the compliments of the company, and applying themselves, in turn, to a dozen proffered glasses of spirits and water, tendered by their more boisterous admirers; whose countenances, expressive of almost every vice in almost every grade, irresistibly attracted the attention, by their very repulsiveness. EOS Cunning, ferocity, and drunkeness in all its stages, were there, in their strongest aspect; and women: some with the last lingering tinge of their early freshness almost fading as you looked:  others with every mark and stamp of their sex utterly beaten out, and presenting but one loathsome blank of profligacy and crime; some mere girls, others but young women, and none past the prime of life; formed the darkest and saddest portion of this dreary picture. EOS And so the amiable couple parted. EOS CHAPTER XXVII  ATONES FOR THE UNPOLITENESS OF A FORMER CHAPTER; WHICH DESERTED A LADY, MOST UNCEREMONIOUSLY  As it would be, by no means, seemly in a humble author to keep so mighty a personage as a beadle waiting, with his back to the fire, and the skirts of his coat gathered up under his arms, until such time as it might suit his pleasure to relieve him; and as it would still less become his station, or his gallantry to involve in the same neglect a lady on whom that beadle had looked with an eye of tenderness and affection, and in whose ear he had whispered sweet words, which, coming from such a quarter, might well thrill the bosom of maid or matron of whatsoever degree; the historian whose pen traces these words--trusting that he knows his place, and that he entertains a becoming reverence for those upon earth to whom high and important authority is delegated--hastens to pay them that respect which their position demands, and to treat them with all that duteous ceremony which their exalted rank, and (by consequence) great virtues, imperatively claim at his hands. EOS Towards this end, indeed, he had purposed to introduce, in this place, a dissertation touching the divine right of beadles, and elucidative of the position, that a beadle can do no wrong:  which could not fail to have been both pleasurable and profitable to the right-minded reader but which he is unfortunately compelled, by want of time and space, to postpone to some more convenient and fitting opportunity; on the arrival of which, he will be prepared to show, that a beadle properly constituted:  that is to say, a parochial beadle, attached to a parochial workhouse, and attending in his official capacity the parochial church:  is, in right and virtue of his office, possessed of all the excellences and best qualities of humanity; and that to none of those excellences, can mere companies' beadles, or court-of-law beadles, or even chapel-of-ease beadles (save the last, and they in a very lowly and inferior degree), lay the remotest sustainable claim. EOS Mr. Bumble had re-counted the teaspoons, re-weighed the sugar-tongs, made a closer inspection of the milk-pot, and ascertained to a nicety the exact condition of the furniture, down to the very horse-hair seats of the chairs; and had repeated each process full half a dozen times; before he began to think that it was time for Mrs. Corney to return. EOS Thinking begets thinking; as there were no sounds of Mrs. Corney's approach, it occured to Mr. Bumble that it would be an innocent and virtuous way of spending the time, if he were further to allay his curiousity by a cursory glance at the interior of Mrs. Corney's chest of drawers. EOS Having listened at the keyhole, to assure himself that nobody was approaching the chamber, Mr. Bumble, beginning at the bottom, proceeded to make himself acquainted with the contents of the three long drawers: which, being filled with various garments of good fashion and texture, carefully preserved between two layers of old newspapers, speckled with dried lavender: seemed to yield him exceeding satisfaction. EOS He was still placidly engaged in this latter survey, when Mrs. Corney, hurrying into the room, threw herself, in a breathless state, on a chair by the fireside, and covering her eyes with one hand, placed the other over her heart, and gasped for breath. EOS said Mr. Bumble, checking himself, with native majesty, 'this is them wicious paupers!' EOS 'I can't help it,' whimpered the lady. EOS 'A little of the wine?' EOS replied Mrs. Corney. EOS CHAPTER XXVIII  LOOKS AFTER OLIVER, AND PROCEEDS WITH HIS ADVENTURES  'Wolves tear your throats!' EOS muttered Sikes, grinding his teeth. EOS 'Stop, you white-livered hound!' EOS cried the robber, shouting after Toby Crackit, who, making the best use of his long legs, was already ahead. EOS For he was not quite satisfied that he was beyond the range of pistol-shot; and Sikes was in no mood to be played with. EOS cried Sikes, laying the boy in a dry ditch at his feet, and drawing a pistol from his pocket. EOS 'Don't play booty with me.' EOS At this moment the noise grew louder. EOS Sikes, again looking round, could discern that the men who had given chase were already climbing the gate of the field in which he stood; and that a couple of dogs were some paces in advance of them. EOS Sikes clenched his teeth; took one look around; threw over the prostrate form of Oliver, the cape in which he had been hurriedly muffled; ran along the front of the hedge, as if to distract the attention of those behind, from the spot where the boy lay; paused, for a second, before another hedge which met it at right angles; and whirling his pistol high into the air, cleared it at a bound, and was gone. EOS 'Pincher! EOS Come here, come here!' EOS The dogs, who, in common with their masters, seemed to have no particular relish for the sport in which they were engaged, readily answered to the command. EOS Three men, who had by this time advanced some distance into the field, stopped to take counsel together. EOS 'I am agreeable to anything which is agreeable to Mr. Giles,' said a shorter man; who was by no means of a slim figure, and who was very pale in the face, and very polite: as frightened men frequently are. EOS 'I shouldn't wish to appear ill-mannered, gentlemen,' said the third, who had called the dogs back, 'Mr. EOS Thank my stars, I know my sitiwation.' EOS To tell the truth, the little man _did_ seem to know his situation, and to know perfectly well that it was by no means a desirable one; for his teeth chattered in his head as he spoke. EOS 'You are afraid, Brittles,' said Mr. Giles. EOS 'You're a falsehood, Mr. Giles,' said Brittles. EOS Now, these four retorts arose from Mr. Giles's taunt; and Mr. Giles's taunt had arisen from his indignation at having the responsibility of going home again, imposed upon himself under cover of a compliment. EOS The third man brought the dispute to a close, most philosophically. EOS 'I'll tell you what it is, gentlemen,' said he, 'we're all afraid.' EOS 'Speak for yourself, sir,' said Mr. Giles, who was the palest of the party. EOS 'So I do,' replied the man. EOS 'It's natural and proper to be afraid, under such circumstances. EOS I am.' EOS 'So am I,' said Brittles; 'only there's no call to tell a man he is, so bounceably.' EOS These frank admissions softened Mr. Giles, who at once owned that _he_ was afraid; upon which, they all three faced about, and ran back again with the completest unanimity, until Mr. Giles (who had the shortest wind of the party, as was encumbered with a pitchfork) most handsomely insisted on stopping, to make an apology for his hastiness of speech. EOS 'But it's wonderful,' said Mr. Giles, when he had explained, 'what a man will do, when his blood is up. EOS I should have committed murder--I know I should--if we'd caught one of them rascals.' EOS As the other two were impressed with a similar presentiment; and as their blood, like his, had all gone down again; some speculation ensued upon the cause of this sudden change in their temperament. EOS 'I know what it was,' said Mr. Giles; 'it was the gate.' EOS 'I shouldn't wonder if it was,' exclaimed Brittles, catching at the idea. EOS I felt all mine suddenly going away, as I was climbing over it.' EOS It was quite obvious, therefore, that it was the gate; especially as there was no doubt regarding the time at which the change had taken place, because all three remembered that they had come in sight of the robbers at the instant of its occurance. EOS Mr. Giles acted in the double capacity of butler and steward to the old lady of the mansion; Brittles was a lad of all-work: who, having entered her service a mere child, was treated as a promising young boy still, though he was something past thirty. EOS Encouraging each other with such converse as this; but, keeping very close together, notwithstanding, and looking apprehensively round, whenever a fresh gust rattled through the boughs; the three men hurried back to a tree, behind which they had left their lantern, lest its light should inform the thieves in what direction to fire. EOS Catching up the light, they made the best of their way home, at a good round trot; and long after their dusky forms had ceased to be discernible, the light might have been seen twinkling and dancing in the distance, like some exhalation of the damp and gloomy atmosphere through which it was swiftly borne. EOS The air grew colder, as day came slowly on; and the mist rolled along the ground like a dense cloud of smoke. EOS The grass was wet; the pathways, and low places, were all mire and water; the damp breath of an unwholesome wind went languidly by, with a hollow moaning. EOS Still, Oliver lay motionless and insensible on the spot where Sikes had left him. EOS Morning drew on apace. EOS The rain came down, thick and fast, and pattered noisily among the leafless bushes. EOS But, Oliver felt it not, as it beat against him; for he still lay stretched, helpless and unconscious, on his bed of clay. EOS His left arm, rudely bandaged in a shawl, hung heavy and useless at his side; the bandage was saturated with blood. EOS He was so weak, that he could scarcely raise himself into a sitting posture; when he had done so, he looked feebly round for help, and groaned with pain. EOS After a short return of the stupor in which he had been so long plunged, Oliver:  urged by a creeping sickness at his heart, which seemed to warn him that if he lay there, he must surely die:  got upon his feet, and essayed to walk. EOS His head was dizzy, and he staggered to and fro like a drunken man. EOS Then, he was alone with Sikes, plodding on as on the previous day; and as shadowy people passed them, he felt the robber's grasp upon his wrist. EOS Suddenly, he started back at the report of firearms; there rose into the air, loud cries and shouts; lights gleamed before his eyes; all was noise and tumult, as some unseen hand bore him hurriedly away. EOS Thus he staggered on, creeping, almost mechanically, between the bars of gates, or through hedge-gaps as they came in his way, until he reached a road. EOS Here the rain began to fall so heavily, that it roused him. EOS He looked about, and saw that at no great distance there was a house, which perhaps he could reach. EOS Pitying his condition, they might have compassion on him; and if they did not, it would be better, he thought, to die near human beings, than in the lonely open fields. EOS He summoned up all his strength for one last trial, and bent his faltering steps towards it. EOS As he drew nearer to this house, a feeling come over him that he had seen it before. EOS That garden wall! EOS On the grass inside, he had fallen on his knees last night, and prayed the two men's mercy. EOS It was the very house they had attempted to rob. EOS Oliver felt such fear come over him when he recognised the place, that, for the instant, he forgot the agony of his wound, and thought only of flight. EOS CHAPTER XXIX  HAS AN INTRODUCTORY ACCOUNT OF THE INMATES OF THE HOUSE, TO WHICH OLIVER RESORTED  In a handsome room:  though its furniture had rather the air of old-fashioned comfort, than of modern elegance:  there sat two ladies at a well-spread breakfast-table. EOS Mr. Giles, dressed with scrupulous care in a full suit of black, was in attendance upon them. EOS Her eyes (and age had dimmed but little of their brightness) were attentively upon her young companion. EOS She was not past seventeen. EOS Thus, a strain of gentle music, or the rippling of water in a silent place, or the odour of a flower, or the mention of a familiar word, will sometimes call up sudden dim remembrances of scenes that never were, in this life; which vanish like a breath; which some brief memory of a happier existence, long gone by, would seem to have awakened; which no voluntary exertion of the mind can ever recall. EOS 'What can this mean?' EOS exclaimed the elder lady. EOS 'This poor child can never have been the pupil of robbers!' EOS urged Rose. EOS 'My dear young lady,' rejoined the surgeon, mournfully shaking his head; 'crime, like death, is not confined to the old and withered alone. EOS The youngest and fairest are too often its chosen victims.' EOS 'But, can you--oh! EOS said Rose. EOS The surgeon shook his head, in a manner which intimated that he feared it was very possible; and observing that they might disturb the patient, led the way into an adjoining apartment. EOS as you love me, and know that I have never felt the want of parents in your goodness and affection, but that I might have done so, and might have been equally helpless and unprotected with this poor child, have pity upon him before it is too late!' EOS 'My dear love,' said the elder lady, as she folded the weeping girl to her bosom, 'do you think I would harm a hair of his head?' EOS replied Rose, eagerly. EOS What can I do to save him, sir?' EOS 'Let me think, ma'am,' said the doctor; 'let me think.' EOS Mr. Losberne thrust his hands into his pockets, and took several turns up and down the room; often stopping, and balancing himself on his toes, and frowning frightfully. EOS After various exclamations of 'I've got it now' and 'no, I haven't,' and as many renewals of the walking and frowning, he at length made a dead halt, and spoke as follows:  'I think if you give me a full and unlimited commission to bully Giles, and that little boy, Brittles, I can manage it. EOS You don't object to that?' EOS 'Unless there is some other way of preserving the child,' replied Mrs. Maylie. EOS 'There is no other,' said the doctor. EOS 'No other, take my word for it.' EOS 'You seem to think,' retorted the doctor, 'that everybody is disposed to be hard-hearted to-day, except yourself, Miss Rose. EOS I only hope, for the sake of the rising male sex generally, that you may be found in as vulnerable and soft-hearted a mood by the first eligible young fellow who appeals to your compassion; and I wish I were a young fellow, that I might avail myself, on the spot, of such a favourable opportunity for doing so, as the present.' EOS 'You are as great a boy as poor Brittles himself,' returned Rose, blushing. EOS The great point of our agreement is yet to come. EOS The conference was a long one. EOS Oliver told them all his simple history, and was often compelled to stop, by pain and want of strength. EOS It was a solemn thing, to hear, in the darkened room, the feeble voice of the sick child recounting a weary catalogue of evils and calamities which hard men had brought upon him. EOS Oh! EOS Oliver's pillow was smoothed by gentle hands that night; and loveliness and virtue watched him as he slept. EOS He felt calm and happy, and could have died without a murmur. EOS And finding nobody about the parlours, it occurred to him, that he could perhaps originate the proceedings with better effect in the kitchen; so into the kitchen he went. EOS The latter gentleman had a large staff, a large head, large features, and large half-boots; and he looked as if he had been taking a proportionate allowance of ale--as indeed he had. EOS 'Sit still!' EOS said the doctor, waving his hand. EOS 'Thank you, sir, said Mr. Giles. EOS Brittles headed a low murmur, by which the ladies and gentlemen generally were understood to express the gratification they derived from Mr. Giles's condescension. EOS Mr. Giles looked round with a patronising air, as much as to say that so long as they behaved properly, he would never desert them. EOS asked Giles. EOS 'So-so'; returned the doctor. EOS 'I am afraid you have got yourself into a scrape there, Mr. EOS Giles.' EOS 'I hope you don't mean to say, sir,' said Mr. Giles, trembling, 'that he's going to die. EOS If I thought it, I should never be happy again. EOS I wouldn't cut a boy off:  no, not even Brittles here; not for all the plate in the county, sir.' EOS Giles, are you a Protestant?' EOS 'Yes, sir, I hope so,' faltered Mr. Giles, who had turned very pale. EOS 'And what are _you_, boy?' EOS said the doctor, turning sharply upon Brittles. EOS said the doctor, shaking his forefinger with great solemnity of manner, and tapping the bridge of his nose with it, to bespeak the exercise of that worthy's utmost acuteness. EOS 'Here's the house broken into,' said the doctor, 'and a couple of men catch one moment's glimpse of a boy, in the midst of gunpowder smoke, and in all the distraction of alarm and darkness. EOS Now, the question is, whether these men are justified by the fact; if not, in what situation do they place themselves?' EOS He said, if that wasn't law, he would be glad to know what was. EOS 'I ask you again,' thundered the doctor, 'are you, on your solemn oaths, able to identify that boy?' EOS Brittles looked doubtfully at Mr. Giles; Mr. Giles looked doubtfully at Brittles; the constable put his hand behind his ear, to catch the reply; the two women and the tinker leaned forward to listen; the doctor glanced keenly round; when a ring was heard at the gate, and at the same moment, the sound of wheels. EOS 'It's the runners!' EOS 'The what?' EOS 'The Bow Street officers, sir,' replied Brittles, taking up a candle; 'me and Mr. Giles sent for 'em this morning.' EOS 'What?' EOS cried the doctor. EOS 'Just send somebody out to relieve my mate, will you, young man?' EOS said the officer; 'he's in the gig, a-minding the prad. EOS The man who had knocked at the door, was a stout personage of middle height, aged about fifty: with shiny black hair, cropped pretty close; half-whiskers, a round face, and sharp eyes. EOS 'Tell your governor that Blathers and Duff is here, will you?' EOS 'Oh! EOS Good-evening, master. EOS Can I have a word or two with you in private, if you please?' EOS said Blathers. EOS 'Nothing at all,' replied the doctor. EOS 'I don't think it would exonerate him, either with them, or with legal functionaries of a higher grade. EOS What is he, after all, they would say? EOS A runaway. EOS Judged by mere worldly considerations and probabilities, his story is a very doubtful one.' EOS 'You believe it, surely?' EOS '_I_ believe it, strange as it is; and perhaps I may be an old fool for doing so,' rejoined the doctor; 'but I don't think it is exactly the tale for a practical police-officer, nevertheless.' EOS 'Why not?' EOS On his own showing, you see, he has been the companion of thieves for some time past; he has been carried to a police-officer, on a charge of picking a gentleman's pocket; he has been taken away, forcibly, from that gentleman's house, to a place which he cannot describe or point out, and of the situation of which he has not the remotest idea. EOS He is brought down to Chertsey, by men who seem to have taken a violent fancy to him, whether he will or no; and is put through a window to rob a house; and then, just at the very moment when he is going to alarm the inmates, and so do the very thing that would set him all to rights, there rushes into the way, a blundering dog of a half-bred butler, and shoots him! EOS As if on purpose to prevent his doing any good for himself! EOS 'I see it, of course,' replied Rose, smiling at the doctor's impetuosity; 'but still I do not see anything in it, to criminate the poor child.' EOS They never see, whether for good or bad, more than one side of any question; and that is, always, the one which first presents itself to them.' EOS He was wery quick about it. EOS But Conkey was quick, too; for he fired a blunderbuss arter him, and roused the neighbourhood. EOS One day he came up to the office, all in a hurry, and had a private interview with the magistrate, who, after a deal of talk, rings the bell, and orders Jem Spyers in (Jem was a active officer), and tells him to go and assist Mr. Chickweed in apprehending the man as robbed his house. EOS Messrs. Blathers and Duff looked at Mr. Giles, as he was thus recommended to their notice. EOS Do you think so now?' EOS inquired Blathers. EOS rejoined Blathers, impatiently. EOS 'I don't know; I really don't know,' said Giles, with a rueful countenance. EOS 'What do you think?' EOS Among other ingenious surmises, the question was then raised, whether Mr. Giles had really hit anybody; and upon examination of the fellow pistol to that which he had fired, it turned out to have no more destructive loading than gunpowder and brown paper: a discovery which made a considerable impression on everybody but the doctor, who had drawn the ball about ten minutes before. EOS Finally, the officers, without troubling themselves very much about Oliver, left the Chertsey constable in the house, and took up their rest for that night in the town; promising to return the next morning. EOS With the next morning, there came a rumour, that two men and a boy were in the cage at Kingston, who had been apprehended over night under suspicious circumstances; and to Kingston Messrs. Blathers and Duff journeyed accordingly. EOS The suspicious circumstances, however, resolving themselves, on investigation, into the one fact, that they had been discovered sleeping under a haystack; which, although a great crime, is only punishable by imprisonment, and is, in the merciful eye of the English law, and its comprehensive love of all the King's subjects, held to be no satisfactory proof, in the absence of all other evidence, that the sleeper, or sleepers, have committed burglary accompanied with violence, and have therefore rendered themselves liable to the punishment of death; Messrs. Blathers and Duff came back again, as wise as they went. EOS In short, after some more examination, and a great deal more conversation, a neighbouring magistrate was readily induced to take the joint bail of Mrs. Maylie and Mr. Losberne for Oliver's appearance if he should ever be called upon; and Blathers and Duff, being rewarded with a couple of guineas, returned to town with divided opinions on the subject of their expedition: the latter gentleman on a mature consideration of all the circumstances, inclining to the belief that the burglarious attempt had originated with the Family Pet; and the former being equally disposed to concede the full merit of it to the great Mr. Conkey Chickweed. EOS Meanwhile, Oliver gradually throve and prospered under the united care of Mrs. Maylie, Rose, and the kind-hearted Mr. Losberne. EOS CHAPTER XXXII  OF THE HAPPY LIFE OLIVER BEGAN TO LEAD WITH HIS KIND FRIENDS  Oliver's ailings were neither slight nor few. EOS In addition to the pain and delay attendant on a broken limb, his exposure to the wet and cold had brought on fever and ague:  which hung about him for many weeks, and reduced him sadly. EOS 'Poor fellow!' EOS We are going into the country, and my aunt intends that you shall accompany us. EOS The quiet place, the pure air, and all the pleasure and beauties of spring, will restore you in a few days. EOS We will employ you in a hundred ways, when you can bear the trouble.' EOS dear lady, if I could but work for you; if I could only give you pleasure by watering your flowers, or watching your birds, or running up and down the whole day long, to make you happy; what would I give to do it!' EOS 'You shall give nothing at all,' said Miss Maylie, smiling; 'for, as I told you before, we shall employ you in a hundred ways; and if you only take half the trouble to please us, that you promise now, you will make me very happy indeed.' EOS 'Happy, ma'am!' EOS cried Oliver; 'how kind of you to say so!' EOS 'To think that my dear good aunt should have been the means of rescuing any one from such sad misery as you have described to us, would be an unspeakable pleasure to me; but to know that the object of her goodness and compassion was sincerely grateful and attached, in consequence, would delight me, more than you can well imagine. EOS Do you understand me?' EOS 'Oh yes, ma'am, yes!' EOS replied Oliver eagerly; 'but I was thinking that I am ungrateful now.' EOS 'To whom?' EOS inquired the young lady. EOS 'To the kind gentleman, and the dear old nurse, who took so much care of me before,' rejoined Oliver. EOS 'I am sure they would,' rejoined Oliver's benefactress; 'and Mr. Losberne has already been kind enough to promise that when you are well enough to bear the journey, he will carry you to see them.' EOS 'Has he, ma'am?' EOS 'I don't know what I shall do for joy when I see their kind faces once again!' EOS One morning he and Mr. Losberne set out, accordingly, in a little carriage which belonged to Mrs. Maylie. EOS 'Do you see anything--hear anything--feel anything--eh?' EOS 'That, sir,' cried Oliver, pointing out of the carriage window. EOS 'Yes; well, what of it? EOS Stop coachman. EOS 'What of the house, my man; eh?' EOS 'The thieves--the house they took me to!' EOS whispered Oliver. EOS 'The devil it is!' EOS 'Hallo, there! EOS let me out!' EOS But, before the coachman could dismount from his box, he had tumbled out of the coach, by some means or other; and, running down to the deserted tenement, began kicking at the door like a madman. EOS said a little ugly hump-backed man:  opening the door so suddenly, that the doctor, from the very impetus of his last kick, nearly fell forward into the passage. EOS 'Matter!' EOS exclaimed the other, collaring him, without a moment's reflection. EOS The hump-backed man stared, as if in excess of amazement and indignation; then, twisting himself, dexterously, from the doctor's grasp, growled forth a volley of horrid oaths, and retired into the house. EOS Before he could shut the door, however, the doctor had passed into the parlour, without a word of parley. EOS He looked anxiously round; not an article of furniture; not a vestige of anything, animate or inanimate; not even the position of the cupboards; answered Oliver's description! EOS 'Now!' EOS said the hump-backed man, who had watched him keenly, 'what do you mean by coming into my house, in this violent way? EOS Which is it?' EOS 'Did you ever know a man come out to do either, in a chariot and pair, you ridiculous old vampire?' EOS said the irritable doctor. EOS 'Will you take yourself off, before I do you a mischief? EOS Curse you!' EOS 'As soon as I think proper,' said Mr. Losberne, looking into the other parlour; which, like the first, bore no resemblance whatever to Oliver's account of it. EOS 'I shall find you out, some day, my friend.' EOS 'Will you?' EOS sneered the ill-favoured cripple. EOS 'If you ever want me, I'm here. EOS I haven't lived here mad and all alone, for five-and-twenty years, to be scared by you. EOS 'Stupid enough, this,' muttered the doctor to himself; 'the boy must have made a mistake. EOS Here! EOS Put that in your pocket, and shut yourself up again.' EOS He continued to utter the most fearful imprecations, until the driver had resumed his seat; and when they were once more on their way, they could see him some distance behind: beating his feet upon the ground, and tearing his hair, in transports of real or pretended rage. EOS said the doctor, after a long silence. EOS 'Did you know that before, Oliver?' EOS 'No, sir.' EOS 'An ass,' said the doctor again, after a further silence of some minutes. EOS That would have served me right, though. EOS I am always involving myself in some scrape or other, by acting on impulse. EOS It might have done me good.' EOS Now, the fact was that the excellent doctor had never acted upon anything but impulse all through his life, and it was no bad compliment to the nature of the impulses which governed him, that so far from being involved in any peculiar troubles or misfortunes, he had the warmest respect and esteem of all who knew him. EOS If the truth must be told, he was a little out of temper, for a minute or two, at being disappointed in procuring corroborative evidence of Oliver's story on the very first occasion on which he had a chance of obtaining any. EOS When the coach turned into it, his heart beat so violently, that he could scarcely draw his breath. EOS 'That! EOS replied Oliver, pointing eagerly out of the window. EOS 'The white house. EOS make haste! EOS Pray make haste! EOS 'Come, come!' EOS 'You will see them directly, and they will be overjoyed to find you safe and well.' EOS 'Oh! EOS I hope so!' EOS cried Oliver. EOS The coach rolled on. EOS No; that was the wrong house; the next door. EOS Alas! EOS the white house was empty, and there was a bill in the window. EOS 'To Let.' EOS 'Knock at the next door,' cried Mr. Losberne, taking Oliver's arm in his. EOS 'What has become of Mr. Brownlow, who used to live in the adjoining house, do you know?' EOS She presently returned, and said, that Mr. Brownlow had sold off his goods, and gone to the West Indies, six weeks before. EOS Oliver clasped his hands, and sank feebly backward. EOS 'Has his housekeeper gone too?' EOS 'Yes, sir'; replied the servant. EOS 'Then turn towards home again,' said Mr. Losberne to the driver; 'and don't stop to bait the horses, till you get out of this confounded London!' EOS 'The book-stall keeper, sir?' EOS 'My poor boy, this is disappointment enough for one day,' said the doctor. EOS 'Quite enough for both of us. EOS If we go to the book-stall keeper's, we shall certainly find that he is dead, or has set his house on fire, or run away. EOS This bitter disappointment caused Oliver much sorrow and grief, even in the midst of his happiness; for he had pleased himself, many times during his illness, with thinking of all that Mr. Brownlow and Mrs. Bedwin would say to him: and what delight it would be to tell them how many long days and nights he had passed in reflecting on what they had done for him, and in bewailing his cruel separation from them. EOS The circumstance occasioned no alteration, however, in the behaviour of his benefactors. EOS After another fortnight, when the fine warm weather had fairly begun, and every tree and flower was putting forth its young leaves and rich blossoms, they made preparations for quitting the house at Chertsey, for some months. EOS Who can describe the pleasure and delight, the peace of mind and soft tranquillity, the sickly boy felt in the balmy air, and among the green hills and rich woods, of an inland village! EOS Men who have lived in crowded, pent-up streets, through lives of toil, and who have never wished for change; men, to whom custom has indeed been second nature, and who have come almost to love each brick and stone that formed the narrow boundaries of their daily walks; even they, with the hand of death upon them, have been known to yearn at last for one short glimpse of Nature's face; and, carried far from the scenes of their old pains and pleasures, have seemed to pass at once into a new state of being. EOS Crawling forth, from day to day, to some green sunny spot, they have had such memories wakened up within them by the sight of the sky, and hill and plain, and glistening water, that a foretaste of heaven itself has soothed their quick decline, and they have sunk into their tombs, as peacefully as the sun whose setting they watched from their lonely chamber window but a few hours before, faded from their dim and feeble sight! EOS The memories which peaceful country scenes call up, are not of this world, nor of its thoughts and hopes. EOS Oliver often wandered here; and, thinking of the wretched grave in which his mother lay, would sometimes sit him down and sob unseen; but, when he raised his eyes to the deep sky overhead, he would cease to think of her as lying in the ground, and would weep for her, sadly, but without pain. EOS The days were peaceful and serene; the nights brought with them neither fear nor care; no languishing in a wretched prison, or associating with wretched men; nothing but pleasant and happy thoughts. EOS Every morning he went to a white-headed old gentleman, who lived near the little church: who taught him to read better, and to write:  and who spoke so kindly, and took such pains, that Oliver could never try enough to please him. EOS And when Sunday came, how differently the day was spent, from any way in which he had ever spent it yet! EOS and how happily too; like all the other days in that most happy time! EOS There was the little church, in the morning, with the green leaves fluttering at the windows:  the birds singing without:  and the sweet-smelling air stealing in at the low porch, and filling the homely building with its fragrance. EOS The poor people were so neat and clean, and knelt so reverently in prayer, that it seemed a pleasure, not a tedious duty, their assembling there together; and though the singing might be rude, it was real, and sounded more musical (to Oliver's ears at least) than any he had ever heard in church before. EOS Then, there were the walks as usual, and many calls at the clean houses of the labouring men; and at night, Oliver read a chapter or two from the Bible, which he had been studying all the week, and in the performance of which duty he felt more proud and pleased, than if he had been the clergyman himself. EOS In the morning, Oliver would be a-foot by six o'clock, roaming the fields, and plundering the hedges, far and wide, for nosegays of wild flowers, with which he would return laden, home; and which it took great care and consideration to arrange, to the best advantage, for the embellishment of the breakfast-table. EOS There was fresh groundsel, too, for Miss Maylie's birds, with which Oliver, who had been studying the subject under the able tuition of the village clerk, would decorate the cages, in the most approved taste. EOS When the birds were made all spruce and smart for the day, there was usually some little commission of charity to execute in the village; or, failing that, there was rare cricket-playing, sometimes, on the green; or, failing that, there was always something to do in the garden, or about the plants, to which Oliver (who had studied this science also, under the same master, who was a gardener by trade,) applied himself with hearty good-will, until Miss Rose made her appearance:  when there were a thousand commendations to be bestowed on all he had done. EOS CHAPTER XXXIII  WHEREIN THE HAPPINESS OF OLIVER AND HIS FRIENDS, EXPERIENCES A SUDDEN CHECK  Spring flew swiftly by, and summer came. EOS If the village had been beautiful at first it was now in the full glow and luxuriance of its richness. EOS The great trees, which had looked shrunken and bare in the earlier months, had now burst into strong life and health; and stretching forth their green arms over the thirsty ground, converted open and naked spots into choice nooks, where was a deep and pleasant shade from which to look upon the wide prospect, steeped in sunshine, which lay stretched beyond. EOS The earth had donned her mantle of brightest green; and shed her richest perfumes abroad. EOS It was the prime and vigour of the year; all things were glad and flourishing. EOS Still, the same quiet life went on at the little cottage, and the same cheerful serenity prevailed among its inmates. EOS He was still the same gentle, attached, affectionate creature that he had been when pain and suffering had wasted his strength, and when he was dependent for every slight attention, and comfort on those who tended him. EOS Rose had been in high spirits, too, and they had walked on, in merry conversation, until they had far exceeded their ordinary bounds. EOS Mrs. Maylie being fatigued, they returned more slowly home. EOS The young lady merely throwing off her simple bonnet, sat down to the piano as usual. EOS After running abstractedly over the keys for a few minutes, she fell into a low and very solemn air; and as she played it, they heard a sound as if she were weeping. EOS 'Rose, my dear!' EOS said the elder lady. EOS Rose made no reply, but played a little quicker, as though the words had roused her from some painful thoughts. EOS 'Rose, my love!' EOS cried Mrs. Maylie, rising hastily, and bending over her. EOS 'What is this? EOS In tears! EOS My dear child, what distresses you?' EOS 'Nothing, aunt; nothing,' replied the young lady. EOS interposed Mrs. Maylie. EOS Oh, not ill!' EOS replied Rose: shuddering as though some deadly chillness were passing over her, while she spoke; 'I shall be better presently. EOS Close the window, pray!' EOS Oliver hastened to comply with her request. EOS Covering her face with her hands, she sank upon a sofa, and gave vent to the tears which she was now unable to repress. EOS said the elderly lady, folding her arms about her, 'I never saw you so before.' EOS 'I would not alarm you if I could avoid it,' rejoined Rose; 'but indeed I have tried very hard, and cannot help this. EOS Another minute, and it was suffused with a crimson flush:  and a heavy wildness came over the soft blue eye. EOS She don't look well to-night, but--'  The old lady motioned to him not to speak; and sitting herself down in a dark corner of the room, remained silent for some time. EOS At length, she said, in a trembling voice:  'I hope not, Oliver. EOS 'What?' EOS inquired Oliver. EOS 'The heavy blow,' said the old lady, 'of losing the dear girl who has so long been my comfort and happiness.' EOS 'Oh! EOS exclaimed Oliver, hastily. EOS 'Amen to that, my child!' EOS said the old lady, wringing her hands. EOS 'Surely there is no danger of anything so dreadful?' EOS 'She is very ill now,' rejoined Mrs. Maylies; 'and will be worse, I am sure. EOS My dear, dear Rose! EOS She gave way to such great grief, that Oliver, suppressing his own emotion, ventured to remonstrate with her; and to beg, earnestly, that, for the sake of the dear young lady herself, she would be more calm. EOS 'And consider, ma'am,' said Oliver, as the tears forced themselves into his eyes, despite of his efforts to the contrary. EOS consider how young and good she is, and what pleasure and comfort she gives to all about her. EOS I am sure--certain--quite certain--that, for your sake, who are so good yourself; and for her own; and for the sake of all she makes so happy; she will not die. EOS 'Hush!' EOS But you teach me my duty, notwithstanding. EOS I had forgotten it for a moment, Oliver, but I hope I may be pardoned, for I am old, and have seen enough of illness and death to know the agony of separation from the objects of our love. EOS God's will be done! EOS I love her; and He knows how well!' EOS Oliver was surprised to see that as Mrs. Maylie said these words, she checked her lamentations as though by one effort; and drawing herself up as she spoke, became composed and firm. EOS He was still more astonished to find that this firmness lasted; and that, under all the care and watching which ensued, Mrs. Maylie was ever ready and collected: performing all the duties which had devolved upon her, steadily, and, to all external appearances, even cheerfully. EOS But he was young, and did not know what strong minds are capable of, under trying circumstances. EOS How should he, when their possessors so seldom know themselves? EOS An anxious night ensued. EOS When morning came, Mrs. Maylie's predictions were but too well verified. EOS Rose was in the first stage of a high and dangerous fever. EOS It must be carried to the market-town: which is not more than four miles off, by the footpath across the field:  and thence dispatched, by an express on horseback, straight to Chertsey. EOS The people at the inn will undertake to do this: and I can trust to you to see it done, I know.' EOS I would not forward it, unless I feared the worst.' EOS inquired Oliver; impatient to execute his commission, and holding out his trembling hand for the letter. EOS 'No,' replied the old lady, giving it to him mechanically. EOS Oliver glanced at it, and saw that it was directed to Harry Maylie, Esquire, at some great lord's house in the country; where, he could not make out. EOS 'Shall it go, ma'am?' EOS asked Oliver, looking up, impatiently. EOS 'I think not,' replied Mrs. Maylie, taking it back. EOS 'I will wait until to-morrow.' EOS Here he paused, and looked about for the inn. EOS There were a white bank, and a red brewery, and a yellow town-hall; and in one corner there was a large house, with all the wood about it painted green:  before which was the sign of 'The George.' EOS To this he hastened, as soon as it caught his eye. EOS This gentleman walked with much deliberation into the bar to make out the bill:  which took a long time making out:  and after it was ready, and paid, a horse had to be saddled, and a man to be dressed, which took up ten good minutes more. EOS Meanwhile Oliver was in such a desperate state of impatience and anxiety, that he felt as if he could have jumped upon the horse himself, and galloped away, full tear, to the next stage. EOS He was turning out of the gateway when he accidently stumbled against a tall man wrapped in a cloak, who was at that moment coming out of the inn door. EOS 'Hah!' EOS 'What the devil's this?' EOS 'I am sorry,' stammered Oliver, confused by the strange man's wild look. EOS 'I hope I have not hurt you!' EOS 'Rot you!' EOS murmured the man, in a horrible passion; between his clenched teeth; 'if I had only had the courage to say the word, I might have been free of you in a night. EOS Curses on your head, and black death on your heart, you imp! EOS What are you doing here?' EOS Oliver gazed, for a moment, at the struggles of the madman (for such he supposed him to be); and then darted into the house for help. EOS Having seen him safely carried into the hotel, he turned his face homewards, running as fast as he could, to make up for lost time:  and recalling with a great deal of astonishment and some fear, the extraordinary behaviour of the person from whom he had just parted. EOS The circumstance did not dwell in his recollection long, however: for when he reached the cottage, there was enough to occupy his mind, and to drive all considerations of self completely from his memory. EOS 'In fact,' he said, 'it would be little short of a miracle, if she recovered.' EOS Oh! EOS All the livelong day, and for hours after it had grown dark, Oliver paced softly up and down the garden, raising his eyes every instant to the sick chamber, and shuddering to see the darkened window, looking as if death lay stretched inside. EOS Late that night, Mr. Losberne arrived. EOS 'It is hard,' said the good doctor, turning away as he spoke; 'so young; so much beloved; but there is very little hope.' EOS Another morning. EOS Oliver crept away to the old churchyard, and sitting down on one of the green mounds, wept and prayed for her, in silence. EOS He almost thought that shrouds were for the old and shrunken; and that they never wrapped the young and graceful form in their ghastly folds. EOS A knell from the church bell broke harshly on these youthful thoughts. EOS Another! EOS Again! EOS They stood uncovered by a grave; and there was a mother--a mother once--among the weeping train. EOS But the sun shone brightly, and the birds sang on. EOS Oliver turned homeward, thinking on the many kindnesses he had received from the young lady, and wishing that the time could come again, that he might never cease showing her how grateful and attached he was. EOS There is no remorse so deep as that which is unavailing; if we would be spared its tortures, let us remember this, in time. EOS When he reached home Mrs. Maylie was sitting in the little parlour. EOS They sat, listening, and afraid to speak, for hours. EOS The untasted meal was removed, with looks which showed that their thoughts were elsewhere, they watched the sun as he sank lower and lower, and, at length, cast over sky and earth those brilliant hues which herald his departure. EOS Their quick ears caught the sound of an approaching footstep. EOS They both involuntarily darted to the door, as Mr. Losberne entered. EOS 'What of Rose?' EOS cried the old lady. EOS 'Tell me at once! EOS Oh, tell me! EOS in the name of Heaven!' EOS 'Be calm, my dear ma'am, pray.' EOS 'Let me go, in God's name! EOS She is dead! EOS cried the doctor, passionately. EOS 'As He is good and merciful, she will live to bless us all, for years to come.' EOS He had scarcely the power of understanding anything that had passed, until, after a long ramble in the quiet evening air, a burst of tears came to his relief, and he seemed to awaken, all at once, to a full sense of the joyful change that had occurred, and the almost insupportable load of anguish which had been taken from his breast. EOS The night was fast closing in, when he returned homeward:  laden with flowers which he had culled, with peculiar care, for the adornment of the sick chamber. EOS As he walked briskly along the road, he heard behind him, the noise of some vehicle, approaching at a furious pace. EOS Looking round, he saw that it was a post-chaise, driven at great speed; and as the horses were galloping, and the road was narrow, he stood leaning against a gate until it should have passed him. EOS As it dashed on, Oliver caught a glimpse of a man in a white nightcap, whose face seemed familiar to him, although his view was so brief that he could not identify the person. EOS In another second or two, the nightcap was thrust out of the chaise-window, and a stentorian voice bellowed to the driver to stop:  which he did, as soon as he could pull up his horses. EOS Then, the nightcap once again appeared: and the same voice called Oliver by his name. EOS 'Here!' EOS cried the voice. EOS Giles popped out his nightcap again, preparatory to making some reply, when he was suddenly pulled back by a young gentleman who occupied the other corner of the chaise, and who eagerly demanded what was the news. EOS 'In a word!' EOS cried the gentleman, 'Better or worse?' EOS 'Better--much better!' EOS replied Oliver, hastily. EOS 'Thank Heaven!' EOS exclaimed the gentleman. EOS 'Quite, sir,' replied Oliver. EOS The gentleman said not another word, but, opening the chaise-door, leaped out, and taking Oliver hurriedly by the arm, led him aside. EOS 'You are quite certain? EOS There is no possibility of any mistake on your part, my boy, is there?' EOS 'Do not deceive me, by awakening hopes that are not to be fulfilled.' EOS 'I would not for the world, sir,' replied Oliver. EOS 'Indeed you may believe me. EOS Mr. Losberne's words were, that she would live to bless us all for many years to come. EOS I heard him say so.' EOS The tears stood in Oliver's eyes as he recalled the scene which was the beginning of so much happiness; and the gentleman turned his face away, and remained silent, for some minutes. EOS Oliver thought he heard him sob, more than once; but he feared to interrupt him by any fresh remark--for he could well guess what his feelings were--and so stood apart, feigning to be occupied with his nosegay. EOS All this time, Mr. Giles, with the white nightcap on, had been sitting on the steps of the chaise, supporting an elbow on each knee, and wiping his eyes with a blue cotton pocket-handkerchief dotted with white spots. EOS That the honest fellow had not been feigning emotion, was abundantly demonstrated by the very red eyes with which he regarded the young gentleman, when he turned round and addressed him. EOS 'I think you had better go on to my mother's in the chaise, Giles,' said he. EOS 'I would rather walk slowly on, so as to gain a little time before I see her. EOS You can say I am coming.' EOS 'Well,' rejoined Harry Maylie, smiling, 'you can do as you like. EOS Let him go on with the luggage, if you wish it, and do you follow with us. EOS Only first exchange that nightcap for some more appropriate covering, or we shall be taken for madmen.' EOS This done, the postboy drove off; Giles, Mr. Maylie, and Oliver, followed at their leisure. EOS He seemed about five-and-twenty years of age, and was of the middle height; his countenance was frank and handsome; and his demeanor easy and prepossessing. EOS Notwithstanding the difference between youth and age, he bore so strong a likeness to the old lady, that Oliver would have had no great difficulty in imagining their relationship, if he had not already spoken of her as his mother. EOS Mrs. Maylie was anxiously waiting to receive her son when he reached the cottage. EOS 'Mother!' EOS 'I did,' replied Mrs. Maylie; 'but, on reflection, I determined to keep back the letter until I had heard Mr. Losberne's opinion.' EOS 'But why,' said the young man, 'why run the chance of that occurring which so nearly happened? EOS How could I ever have know happiness again!' EOS 'If that _had_ been the case, Harry,' said Mrs. Maylie, 'I fear your happiness would have been effectually blighted, and that your arrival here, a day sooner or a day later, would have been of very, very little import.' EOS rejoined the young man; 'or why should I say, _if_?--It is--it is--you know it, mother--you must know it!' EOS 'I know that she deserves the best and purest love the heart of man can offer,' said Mrs. Maylie; 'I know that the devotion and affection of her nature require no ordinary return, but one that shall be deep and lasting. EOS 'This is unkind, mother,' said Harry. EOS 'Mother,' said the young man, impatiently, 'he would be a selfish brute, unworthy alike of the name of man and of the woman you describe, who acted thus.' EOS 'You think so now, Harry,' replied his mother. EOS 'The mental agony I have suffered, during the last two days, wrings from me the avowal to you of a passion which, as you well know, is not one of yesterday, nor one I have lightly formed. EOS On Rose, sweet, gentle girl! EOS my heart is set, as firmly as ever heart of man was set on woman. EOS Mother, think better of this, and of me, and do not disregard the happiness of which you seem to think so little.' EOS 'Harry,' said Mrs. Maylie, 'it is because I think so much of warm and sensitive hearts, that I would spare them from being wounded. EOS was the impatient reply; 'Mother, I have considered, years and years. EOS I have considered, ever since I have been capable of serious reflection. EOS My feelings remain unchanged, as they ever will; and why should I suffer the pain of a delay in giving them vent, which can be productive of no earthly good? EOS Before I leave this place, Rose shall hear me.' EOS 'She shall,' said Mrs. Maylie. EOS 'That I leave you to discover,' replied Mrs. Maylie. EOS God bless you!' EOS 'I shall see you again to-night?' EOS 'By and by,' replied the lady; 'when I leave Rose.' EOS The former now held out his hand to Harry Maylie; and hearty salutations were exchanged between them. EOS inquired the doctor, when he had concluded.
