EOS CHAPTER XLVI  THE APPOINTMENT KEPT  The church clocks chimed three quarters past eleven, as two figures emerged on London Bridge. EOS One, which advanced with a swift and rapid step, was that of a woman who looked eagerly about her as though in quest of some expected object; the other figure was that of a man, who slunk along in the deepest shadow he could find, and, at some distance, accommodated his pace to hers:  stopping when she stopped:  and as she moved again, creeping stealthily on:  but never allowing himself, in the ardour of his pursuit, to gain upon her footsteps. EOS Thus, they crossed the bridge, from the Middlesex to the Surrey shore, when the woman, apparently disappointed in her anxious scrutiny of the foot-passengers, turned back. EOS The movement was sudden; but he who watched her, was not thrown off his guard by it; for, shrinking into one of the recesses which surmount the piers of the bridge, and leaning over the parapet the better to conceal his figure, he suffered her to pass on the opposite pavement. EOS At nearly the centre of the bridge, she stopped. EOS The man stopped too. EOS The day had been unfavourable, and at that hour and place there were few people stirring. EOS Such as there were, hurried quickly past:  very possibly without seeing, but certainly without noticing, either the woman, or the man who kept her in view. EOS Their appearance was not calculated to attract the importunate regards of such of London's destitute population, as chanced to take their way over the bridge that night in search of some cold arch or doorless hovel wherein to lay their heads; they stood there in silence:  neither speaking nor spoken to, by any one who passed. EOS A mist hung over the river, deepening the red glare of the fires that burnt upon the small craft moored off the different wharfs, and rendering darker and more indistinct the murky buildings on the banks. EOS The old smoke-stained storehouses on either side, rose heavy and dull from the dense mass of roofs and gables, and frowned sternly upon water too black to reflect even their lumbering shapes. EOS The girl had taken a few restless turns to and fro--closely watched meanwhile by her hidden observer--when the heavy bell of St. Paul's tolled for the death of another day. EOS The hour had not struck two minutes, when a young lady, accompanied by a grey-haired gentleman, alighted from a hackney-carriage within a short distance of the bridge, and, having dismissed the vehicle, walked straight towards it. EOS They walked onward, looking about them with the air of persons who entertained some very slight expectation which had little chance of being realised, when they were suddenly joined by this new associate. EOS They halted with an exclamation of surprise, but suppressed it immediately; for a man in the garments of a countryman came close up--brushed against them, indeed--at that precise moment. EOS As she uttered these words, and indicated, with her hand, the direction in which she wished them to proceed, the countryman looked round, and roughly asking what they took up the whole pavement for, passed on. EOS These stairs are a part of the bridge; they consist of three flights. EOS Just below the end of the second, going down, the stone wall on the left terminates in an ornamental pilaster facing towards the Thames. EOS At this point the lower steps widen:  so that a person turning that angle of the wall, is necessarily unseen by any others on the stairs who chance to be above him, if only a step. EOS The countryman looked hastily round, when he reached this point; and as there seemed no better place of concealment, and, the tide being out, there was plenty of room, he slipped aside, with his back to the pilaster, and there waited:  pretty certain that they would come no lower, and that even if he could not hear what was said, he could follow them again, with safety. EOS 'This is far enough,' said a voice, which was evidently that of the gentleman. EOS 'I will not suffer the young lady to go any farther. EOS Many people would have distrusted you too much to have come even so far, but you see I am willing to humour you.' EOS cried the voice of the girl whom he had followed. EOS 'You're considerate, indeed, sir. EOS To humour me! EOS Well, well, it's no matter.' EOS Why not have let me speak to you, above there, where it is light, and there is something stirring, instead of bringing us to this dark and dismal hole?' EOS asked the gentleman, who seemed to pity her. EOS Horrible thoughts of death, and shrouds with blood upon them, and a fear that has made me burn as if I was on fire, have been upon me all day. EOS 'No imagination,' replied the girl in a hoarse voice. EOS 'I'll swear I saw "coffin" written in every page of the book in large black letters,--aye, and they carried one close to me, in the streets to-night.' EOS 'There is nothing unusual in that,' said the gentleman. EOS 'They have passed me often.' EOS '_Real ones_,' rejoined the girl. EOS 'This was not.' EOS There was something so uncommon in her manner, that the flesh of the concealed listener crept as he heard the girl utter these words, and the blood chilled within him. EOS 'Poor creature! EOS She seems to need it.' EOS 'Your haughty religious people would have held their heads up to see me as I am to-night, and preached of flames and vengeance,' cried the girl. EOS 'Oh, dear lady, why ar'n't those who claim to be God's own folks as gentle and as kind to us poor wretches as you, who, having youth, and beauty, and all that they have lost, might be a little proud instead of so much humbler?' EOS 'Ah!' EOS Between the Mussulman and the Pharisee, commend me to the first!' EOS These words appeared to be addressed to the young lady, and were perhaps uttered with the view of affording Nancy time to recover herself. EOS The gentleman, shortly afterwards, addressed himself to her. EOS 'You were not here last Sunday night,' he said. EOS 'By whom?' EOS 'You were not suspected of holding any communication with anybody on the subject which has brought us here to-night, I hope?' EOS asked the old gentleman. EOS 'No,' replied the girl, shaking her head. EOS 'It's not very easy for me to leave him unless he knows why; I couldn't give him a drink of laudanum before I came away.' EOS inquired the gentleman. EOS 'No; and neither he nor any of them suspect me.' EOS 'Good,' said the gentleman. EOS 'This young lady,' the gentleman began, 'has communicated to me, and to some other friends who can be safely trusted, what you told her nearly a fortnight since. EOS I confess to you that I had doubts, at first, whether you were to be implicitly relied upon, but now I firmly believe you are.' EOS 'I am,' said the girl earnestly. EOS To prove to you that I am disposed to trust you, I tell you without reserve, that we propose to extort the secret, whatever it may be, from the fear of this man Monks. EOS But if--if--' said the gentleman, 'he cannot be secured, or, if secured, cannot be acted upon as we wish, you must deliver up the Jew.' EOS I will never do it!' EOS replied the girl. EOS said the gentleman, who seemed fully prepared for this answer. EOS 'Never!' EOS returned the girl. EOS 'Tell me why?' EOS 'For one reason,' rejoined the girl firmly, 'for one reason, that the lady knows and will stand by me in, I know she will, for I have her promise:  and for this other reason, besides, that, bad life as he has led, I have led a bad life too; there are many of us who have kept the same courses together, and I'll not turn upon them, who might--any of them--have turned upon me, but didn't, bad as they are.' EOS 'What if he turns against the others?' EOS 'I promise you that in that case, if the truth is forced from him, there the matter will rest; there must be circumstances in Oliver's little history which it would be painful to drag before the public eye, and if the truth is once elicited, they shall go scot free.' EOS 'And if it is not?' EOS 'Have I the lady's promise for that?' EOS asked the girl. EOS 'My true and faithful pledge.' EOS said the girl, after a short pause. EOS 'Never,' replied the gentleman. EOS After receiving an assurance from both, that she might safely do so, she proceeded in a voice so low that it was often difficult for the listener to discover even the purport of what she said, to describe, by name and situation, the public-house whence she had been followed that night. EOS When she had thoroughly explained the localities of the place, the best position from which to watch it without exciting observation, and the night and hour on which Monks was most in the habit of frequenting it, she seemed to consider for a few moments, for the purpose of recalling his features and appearances more forcibly to her recollection. EOS 'He is tall,' said the girl, 'and a strongly made man, but not stout; he has a lurking walk; and as he walks, constantly looks over his shoulder, first on one side, and then on the other. EOS Don't forget that, for his eyes are sunk in his head so much deeper than any other man's, that you might almost tell him by that alone. EOS His lips are often discoloured and disfigured with the marks of teeth; for he has desperate fits, and sometimes even bites his hands and covers them with wounds--why did you start?' EOS said the girl, stopping suddenly. EOS 'Part of this,' said the girl, 'I have drawn out from other people at the house I tell you of, for I have only seen him twice, and both times he was covered up in a large cloak. EOS I think that's all I can give you to know him by. EOS Stay though,' she added. EOS cried the gentleman. EOS The young lady uttered a cry of surprise, and for a few moments they were so still that the listener could distinctly hear them breathe. EOS 'I should by your description. EOS It may not be the same.' EOS As he expressed himself to this effect, with assumed carelessness, he took a step or two nearer the concealed spy, as the latter could tell from the distinctness with which he heard him mutter, 'It must be he!' EOS 'Now,' he said, returning:  so it seemed by the sound:  to the spot where he had stood before, 'you have given us most valuable assistance, young woman, and I wish you to be the better for it. EOS What can I do to serve you?' EOS Tell me.' EOS 'Nothing, sir,' rejoined the girl, weeping. EOS 'You can do nothing to help me. EOS 'You put yourself beyond its pale,' said the gentleman. EOS I would not have you go back to exchange one word with any old companion, or take one look at any old haunt, or breathe the very air which is pestilence and death to you. EOS Quit them all, while there is time and opportunity!' EOS 'She hesitates, I am sure.' EOS 'I fear not, my dear,' said the gentleman. EOS 'No sir, I do not,' replied the girl, after a short struggle. EOS 'I am chained to my old life. EOS But,' she said, looking hastily round, 'this fear comes over me again. EOS I must go home.' EOS repeated the young lady, with great stress upon the word. EOS I shall be watched or seen. EOS Go! EOS Go! EOS 'It is useless,' said the gentleman, with a sigh. EOS 'We compromise her safety, perhaps, by staying here. EOS 'Yes, yes,' urged the girl. EOS 'You have.' EOS 'What,' cried the young lady, 'can be the end of this poor creature's life!' EOS 'What!' EOS repeated the girl. EOS 'Look before you, lady. EOS Look at that dark water. EOS It may be years hence, or it may be only months, but I shall come to that at last.' EOS 'It will never reach your ears, dear lady, and God forbid such horrors should!' EOS replied the girl. EOS 'Good-night, good-night!' EOS The gentleman turned away. EOS 'This purse,' cried the young lady. EOS 'Take it for my sake, that you may have some resource in an hour of need and trouble.' EOS 'No!' EOS replied the girl. EOS 'I have not done this for money. EOS And yet--give me something that you have worn:  I should like to have something--no, no, not a ring--your gloves or handkerchief--anything that I can keep, as having belonged to you, sweet lady. EOS Bless you! EOS Good-night, good-night!' EOS The sound of retreating footsteps were audible and the voices ceased. EOS cried the young lady, listening. EOS 'Did she call! EOS I thought I heard her voice.' EOS Rose Maylie lingered, but the old gentleman drew her arm through his, and led her, with gentle force, away. EOS As they disappeared, the girl sunk down nearly at her full length upon one of the stone stairs, and vented the anguish of her heart in bitter tears. EOS After a time she arose, and with feeble and tottering steps ascended the street. EOS The astonished listener remained motionless on his post for some minutes afterwards, and having ascertained, with many cautious glances round him, that he was again alone, crept slowly from his hiding-place, and returned, stealthily and in the shade of the wall, in the same manner as he had descended. EOS CHAPTER XLVII  FATAL CONSEQUENCES  It was nearly two hours before day-break; that time which in the autumn of the year, may be truly called the dead of night; when the streets are silent and deserted; when even sounds appear to slumber, and profligacy and riot have staggered home to dream; it was at this still and silent hour, that Fagin sat watching in his old lair, with face so distorted and pale, and eyes so red and blood-shot, that he looked less like a man, than like some hideous phantom, moist from the grave, and worried by an evil spirit. EOS He sat crouching over a cold hearth, wrapped in an old torn coverlet, with his face turned towards a wasting candle that stood upon a table by his side. EOS Stretched upon a mattress on the floor, lay Noah Claypole, fast asleep. EOS Towards him the old man sometimes directed his eyes for an instant, and then brought them back again to the candle; which with a long-burnt wick drooping almost double, and hot grease falling down in clots upon the table, plainly showed that his thoughts were busy elsewhere. EOS Indeed they were. EOS Mortification at the overthrow of his notable scheme; hatred of the girl who had dared to palter with strangers; and utter distrust of the sincerity of her refusal to yield him up; bitter disappointment at the loss of his revenge on Sikes; the fear of detection, and ruin, and death; and a fierce and deadly rage kindled by all; these were the passionate considerations which, following close upon each other with rapid and ceaseless whirl, shot through the brain of Fagin, as every evil thought and blackest purpose lay working at his heart. EOS He sat without changing his attitude in the least, or appearing to take the smallest heed of time, until his quick ear seemed to be attracted by a footstep in the street. EOS 'At last,' he muttered, wiping his dry and fevered mouth. EOS Sitting down and throwing back his outer coat, the man displayed the burly frame of Sikes. EOS he said, laying the bundle on the table. EOS 'Take care of that, and do the most you can with it. EOS Fagin laid his hand upon the bundle, and locking it in the cupboard, sat down again without speaking. EOS But he did not take his eyes off the robber, for an instant, during this action; and now that they sat over against each other, face to face, he looked fixedly at him, with his lips quivering so violently, and his face so altered by the emotions which had mastered him, that the housebreaker involuntarily drew back his chair, and surveyed him with a look of real affright. EOS 'Wot now?' EOS cried Sikes. EOS 'Wot do you look at a man so for?' EOS Fagin raised his right hand, and shook his trembling forefinger in the air; but his passion was so great, that the power of speech was for the moment gone. EOS 'Damme!' EOS I must look to myself here.' EOS 'No, no,' rejoined Fagin, finding his voice. EOS 'It's not--you're not the person, Bill. EOS I've no--no fault to find with you.' EOS 'Oh, you haven't, haven't you?' EOS 'I've got that to tell you, Bill,' said Fagin, drawing his chair nearer, 'will make you worse than me.' EOS returned the robber with an incredulous air. EOS Look sharp, or Nance will think I'm lost.' EOS 'Lost!' EOS cried Fagin. EOS 'She has pretty well settled that, in her own mind, already.' EOS Sikes looked with an aspect of great perplexity into the Jew's face, and reading no satisfactory explanation of the riddle there, clenched his coat collar in his huge hand and shook him soundly. EOS 'Speak, will you!' EOS he said; 'or if you don't, it shall be for want of breath. EOS Open your mouth and say wot you've got to say in plain words. EOS Out with it, you thundering old cur, out with it!' EOS 'Suppose that lad that's laying there--' Fagin began. EOS Sikes turned round to where Noah was sleeping, as if he had not previously observed him. EOS 'Well!' EOS Do you hear me?' EOS cried the Jew, his eyes flashing with rage. EOS 'What then!' EOS 'What if I did it!' EOS cried Fagin almost in a yell. EOS 'I, that knows so much, and could hang so many besides myself!' EOS 'I'd do something in the jail that 'ud get me put in irons; and if I was tried along with you, I'd fall upon you with them in the open court, and beat your brains out afore the people. EOS I should have such strength,' muttered the robber, poising his brawny arm, 'that I could smash your head as if a loaded waggon had gone over it.' EOS 'You would?' EOS 'Would I!' EOS said the housebreaker. EOS 'If it was Charley, or the Dodger, or Bet, or--'  'I don't care who,' replied Sikes impatiently. EOS 'Whoever it was, I'd serve them the same.' EOS Fagin looked hard at the robber; and, motioning him to be silent, stooped over the bed upon the floor, and shook the sleeper to rouse him. EOS Sikes leant forward in his chair:  looking on with his hands upon his knees, as if wondering much what all this questioning and preparation was to end in. EOS 'Bolter, Bolter! EOS said Fagin, looking up with an expression of devilish anticipation, and speaking slowly and with marked emphasis. EOS 'He's tired--tired with watching for her so long,--watching for _her_, Bill.' EOS asked Sikes, drawing back. EOS Fagin made no answer, but bending over the sleeper again, hauled him into a sitting posture. EOS 'Tell me that again--once again, just for him to hear,' said the Jew, pointing to Sikes as he spoke. EOS asked the sleepy Noah, shaking himself pettishly. EOS 'Yes.' EOS 'Yes.' EOS 'A gentleman and a lady that she had gone to of her own accord before, who asked her to give up all her pals, and Monks first, which she did--and to describe him, which she did--and to tell her what house it was that we meet at, and go to, which she did--and where it could be best watched from, which she did--and what time the people went there, which she did. EOS She did all this. EOS cried Fagin, half mad with fury. EOS 'All right,' replied Noah, scratching his head. EOS 'That's just what it was!' EOS 'What did they say, about last Sunday?' EOS 'Why I told yer that before.' EOS Tell it again!' EOS cried Fagin, tightening his grasp on Sikes, and brandishing his other hand aloft, as the foam flew from his lips. EOS 'Why--why? EOS cried Fagin. EOS 'What more of the man she had told them of before? EOS Tell him that, tell him that.' EOS 'Why, that she couldn't very easily get out of doors unless he knew where she was going to,' said Noah; 'and so the first time she went to see the lady, she--ha! EOS ha! EOS it made me laugh when she said it, that it did--she gave him a drink of laudanum.' EOS 'Hell's fire!' EOS 'Let me go!' EOS Flinging the old man from him, he rushed from the room, and darted, wildly and furiously, up the stairs. EOS 'Bill, Bill!' EOS 'A word. EOS 'Don't speak to me; it's not safe. EOS 'Hear me speak a word,' rejoined Fagin, laying his hand upon the lock. EOS 'You won't be--'  'Well,' replied the other. EOS 'You won't be--too--violent, Bill?' EOS Sikes made no reply; but, pulling open the door, of which Fagin had turned the lock, dashed into the silent streets. EOS The girl was lying, half-dressed, upon it. EOS He had roused her from her sleep, for she raised herself with a hurried and startled look. EOS 'Get up!' EOS 'It is,' was the reply. EOS There was a candle burning, but the man hastily drew it from the candlestick, and hurled it under the grate. EOS Seeing the faint light of early day without, the girl rose to undraw the curtain. EOS 'Let it be,' said Sikes, thrusting his hand before her. EOS 'Bill,' said the girl, in the low voice of alarm, 'why do you look like that at me!' EOS The robber sat regarding her, for a few seconds, with dilated nostrils and heaving breast; and then, grasping her by the head and throat, dragged her into the middle of the room, and looking once towards the door, placed his heavy hand upon her mouth. EOS 'Bill, Bill!' EOS gasped the girl, wrestling with the strength of mortal fear,--'I--I won't scream or cry--not once--hear me--speak to me--tell me what I have done!' EOS 'You know, you she devil!' EOS returned the robber, suppressing his breath. EOS 'Then spare my life for the love of Heaven, as I spared yours,' rejoined the girl, clinging to him. EOS think of all I have given up, only this one night, for you. EOS I have been true to you, upon my guilty soul I have!' EOS The man struggled violently, to release his arms; but those of the girl were clasped round his, and tear her as he would, he could not tear them away. EOS Let me see them again, and beg them, on my knees, to show the same mercy and goodness to you; and let us both leave this dreadful place, and far apart lead better lives, and forget how we have lived, except in prayers, and never see each other more. EOS It is never too late to repent. EOS They told me so--I feel it now--but we must have time--a little, little time!' EOS The housebreaker freed one arm, and grasped his pistol. EOS The certainty of immediate detection if he fired, flashed across his mind even in the midst of his fury; and he beat it twice with all the force he could summon, upon the upturned face that almost touched his own. EOS She staggered and fell:  nearly blinded with the blood that rained down from a deep gash in her forehead; but raising herself, with difficulty, on her knees, drew from her bosom a white handkerchief--Rose Maylie's own--and holding it up, in her folded hands, as high towards Heaven as her feeble strength would allow, breathed one prayer for mercy to her Maker. EOS The murderer staggering backward to the wall, and shutting out the sight with his hand, seized a heavy club and struck her down. EOS Of all the horrors that rose with an ill scent upon the morning air, that was the foulest and most cruel. EOS The sun--the bright sun, that brings back, not light alone, but new life, and hope, and freshness to man--burst upon the crowded city in clear and radiant glory. EOS Through costly-coloured glass and paper-mended window, through cathedral dome and rotten crevice, it shed its equal ray. EOS It lighted up the room where the murdered woman lay. EOS It did. EOS There had been a moan and motion of the hand; and, with terror added to rage, he had struck and struck again. EOS Once he threw a rug over it; but it was worse to fancy the eyes, and imagine them moving towards him, than to see them glaring upward, as if watching the reflection of the pool of gore that quivered and danced in the sunlight on the ceiling. EOS He had plucked it off again. EOS And there was the body--mere flesh and blood, no more--but such flesh, and so much blood! EOS There was hair upon the end, which blazed and shrunk into a light cinder, and, caught by the air, whirled up the chimney. EOS He washed himself, and rubbed his clothes; there were spots that would not be removed, but he cut the pieces out, and burnt them. EOS How those stains were dispersed about the room! EOS All this time he had, never once, turned his back upon the corpse; no, not for a moment. EOS It lay nearly under there. EOS God, how the sun poured down upon the very spot! EOS It was a relief to have got free of the room. EOS Traversing the hollow by the Vale of Heath, he mounted the opposite bank, and crossing the road which joins the villages of Hampstead and Highgate, made along the remaining portion of the heath to the fields at North End, in one of which he laid himself down under a hedge, and slept. EOS Soon he was up again, and away,--not far into the country, but back towards London by the high-road--then back again--then over another part of the same ground as he already traversed--then wandering up and down in fields, and lying on ditches' brinks to rest, and starting up to make for some other spot, and do the same, and ramble on again. EOS Where could he go, that was near and not too public, to get some meat and drink? EOS That was a good place, not far off, and out of most people's way. EOS Thither he directed his steps,--running sometimes, and sometimes, with a strange perversity, loitering at a snail's pace, or stopping altogether and idly breaking the hedges with a stick. EOS But when he got there, all the people he met--the very children at the doors--seemed to view him with suspicion. EOS Back he turned again, without the courage to purchase bit or drop, though he had tasted no food for many hours; and once more he lingered on the Heath, uncertain where to go. EOS He wandered over miles and miles of ground, and still came back to the old place. EOS Morning and noon had passed, and the day was on the wane, and still he rambled to and fro, and up and down, and round and round, and still lingered about the same spot. EOS At last he got away, and shaped his course for Hatfield. EOS There was a fire in the tap-room, and some country-labourers were drinking before it. EOS The conversation of the men assembled here, turned upon the neighbouring land, and farmers; and when those topics were exhausted, upon the age of some old man who had been buried on the previous Sunday; the young men present considering him very old, and the old men present declaring him to have been quite young--not older, one white-haired grandfather said, than he was--with ten or fifteen year of life in him at least--if he had taken care; if he had taken care. EOS The robber, after paying his reckoning, sat silent and unnoticed in his corner, and had almost dropped asleep, when he was half wakened by the noisy entrance of a new comer. EOS This was an antic fellow, half pedlar and half mountebank, who travelled about the country on foot to vend hones, strops, razors, washballs, harness-paste, medicine for dogs and horses, cheap perfumery, cosmetics, and such-like wares, which he carried in a case slung to his back. EOS His entrance was the signal for various homely jokes with the countrymen, which slackened not until he had made his supper, and opened his box of treasures, when he ingeniously contrived to unite business with amusement. EOS 'And what be that stoof? EOS 'This,' said the fellow, producing one, 'this is the infallible and invaluable composition for removing all sorts of stain, rust, dirt, mildew, spick, speck, spot, or spatter, from silk, satin, linen, cambric, cloth, crape, stuff, carpet, merino, muslin, bombazeen, or woollen stuff. EOS If a gentleman wants to prove this, he has only need to bolt one little square, and he has put it beyond question--for it's quite as satisfactory as a pistol-bullet, and a great deal nastier in the flavour, consequently the more credit in taking it. EOS One penny a square. EOS With all these virtues, one penny a square!' EOS There were two buyers directly, and more of the listeners plainly hesitated. EOS The vendor observing this, increased in loquacity. EOS 'It's all bought up as fast as it can be made,' said the fellow. EOS One penny a square! EOS Two half-pence is all the same, and four farthings is received with joy. EOS Wine-stains, fruit-stains, beer-stains, water-stains, paint-stains, pitch-stains, mud-stains, blood-stains! EOS Here is a stain upon the hat of a gentleman in company, that I'll take clean out, before he can order me a pint of ale.' EOS 'Hah!' EOS cried Sikes starting up. EOS Gentlemen all, observe the dark stain upon this gentleman's hat, no wider than a shilling, but thicker than a half-crown. EOS With the same perversity of feeling and irresolution that had fastened upon him, despite himself, all day, the murderer, finding that he was not followed, and that they most probably considered him some drunken sullen fellow, turned back up the town, and getting out of the glare of the lamps of a stage-coach that was standing in the street, was walking past, when he recognised the mail from London, and saw that it was standing at the little post-office. EOS He almost knew what was to come; but he crossed over, and listened. EOS 'That's for your people,' said the guard. EOS 'Now, look alive in there, will you. EOS Damn that 'ere bag, it warn't ready night afore last; this won't do, you know!' EOS 'Anything new up in town, Ben?' EOS asked the game-keeper, drawing back to the window-shutters, the better to admire the horses. EOS 'No, nothing that I knows on,' replied the man, pulling on his gloves. EOS 'Corn's up a little. EOS I heerd talk of a murder, too, down Spitalfields way, but I don't reckon much upon it.' EOS 'And a dreadful murder it was.' EOS 'Was it, sir?' EOS rejoined the guard, touching his hat. EOS 'A woman,' replied the gentleman. EOS 'It is supposed--'  'Now, Ben,' replied the coachman impatiently. EOS 'Coming!' EOS cried the office keeper, running out. EOS 'Coming,' growled the guard. EOS 'Ah, and so's the young 'ooman of property that's going to take a fancy to me, but I don't know when. EOS Here, give hold. EOS All ri--ight!' EOS The horn sounded a few cheerful notes, and the coach was gone. EOS At length he went back again, and took the road which leads from Hatfield to St. Albans. EOS He went on doggedly; but as he left the town behind him, and plunged into the solitude and darkness of the road, he felt a dread and awe creeping upon him which shook him to the core. EOS Every object before him, substance or shadow, still or moving, took the semblance of some fearful thing; but these fears were nothing compared to the sense that haunted him of that morning's ghastly figure following at his heels. EOS He could hear its garments rustling in the leaves, and every breath of wind came laden with that last low cry. EOS If he stopped it did the same. EOS If he ran, it followed--not running too:  that would have been a relief:  but like a corpse endowed with the mere machinery of life, and borne on one slow melancholy wind that never rose or fell. EOS At times, he turned, with desperate determination, resolved to beat this phantom off, though it should look him dead; but the hair rose on his head, and his blood stood still, for it had turned with him and was behind him then. EOS He had kept it before him that morning, but it was behind now--always. EOS He threw himself upon the road--on his back upon the road. EOS At his head it stood, silent, erect, and still--a living grave-stone, with its epitaph in blood. EOS Let no man talk of murderers escaping justice, and hint that Providence must sleep. EOS There were twenty score of violent deaths in one long minute of that agony of fear. EOS There was a shed in a field he passed, that offered shelter for the night. EOS Before the door, were three tall poplar trees, which made it very dark within; and the wind moaned through them with a dismal wail. EOS For now, a vision came before him, as constant and more terrible than that from which he had escaped. EOS There were but two, but they were everywhere. EOS If he shut out the sight, there came the room with every well-known object--some, indeed, that he would have forgotten, if he had gone over its contents from memory--each in its accustomed place. EOS The body was in _its_ place, and its eyes were as he saw them when he stole away. EOS He got up, and rushed into the field without. EOS He re-entered the shed, and shrunk down once more. EOS The eyes were there, before he had laid himself along. EOS And here he remained in such terror as none but he can know, trembling in every limb, and the cold sweat starting from every pore, when suddenly there arose upon the night-wind the noise of distant shouting, and the roar of voices mingled in alarm and wonder. EOS Any sound of men in that lonely place, even though it conveyed a real cause of alarm, was something to him. EOS He regained his strength and energy at the prospect of personal danger; and springing to his feet, rushed into the open air. EOS The shouts grew louder as new voices swelled the roar, and he could hear the cry of Fire! EOS The noise increased as he looked. EOS There were people there--men and women--light, bustle. EOS He darted onward--straight, headlong--dashing through brier and brake, and leaping gate and fence as madly as his dog, who careered with loud and sounding bark before him. EOS There were half-dressed figures tearing to and fro, some endeavouring to drag the frightened horses from the stables, others driving the cattle from the yard and out-houses, and others coming laden from the burning pile, amidst a shower of falling sparks, and the tumbling down of red-hot beams. EOS The apertures, where doors and windows stood an hour ago, disclosed a mass of raging fire; walls rocked and crumbled into the burning well; the molten lead and iron poured down, white hot, upon the ground. EOS Women and children shrieked, and men encouraged each other with noisy shouts and cheers. EOS The clanking of the engine-pumps, and the spirting and hissing of the water as it fell upon the blazing wood, added to the tremendous roar. EOS He shouted, too, till he was hoarse; and flying from memory and himself, plunged into the thickest of the throng. EOS Hither and thither he dived that night:  now working at the pumps, and now hurrying through the smoke and flame, but never ceasing to engage himself wherever noise and men were thickest. EOS He looked suspiciously about him, for the men were conversing in groups, and he feared to be the subject of their talk. EOS The dog obeyed the significant beck of his finger, and they drew off, stealthily, together. EOS He passed near an engine where some men were seated, and they called to him to share in their refreshment. EOS He took some bread and meat; and as he drank a draught of beer, heard the firemen, who were from London, talking about the murder. EOS He hurried off, and walked till he almost dropped upon the ground; then lay down in a lane, and had a long, but broken and uneasy sleep. EOS He wandered on again, irresolute and undecided, and oppressed with the fear of another solitary night. EOS Suddenly, he took the desperate resolution to going back to London. EOS 'There's somebody to speak to there, at all event,' he thought. EOS Why can't I lie by for a week or so, and, forcing blunt from Fagin, get abroad to France? EOS Damme, I'll risk it.' EOS He acted upon this impulse without delay, and choosing the least frequented roads began his journey back, resolved to lie concealed within a short distance of the metropolis, and, entering it at dusk by a circuitous route, to proceed straight to that part of it which he had fixed on for his destination. EOS The dog, though. EOS This might lead to his apprehension as he passed along the streets. EOS He resolved to drown him, and walked on, looking about for a pond: picking up a heavy stone and tying it to his handkerchief as he went. EOS The animal looked up into his master's face while these preparations were making; whether his instinct apprehended something of their purpose, or the robber's sidelong look at him was sterner than ordinary, he skulked a little farther in the rear than usual, and cowered as he came more slowly along. EOS The cheapest and least delicate provisions are heaped in the shops; the coarsest and commonest articles of wearing apparel dangle at the salesman's door, and stream from the house-parapet and windows. EOS Jostling with unemployed labourers of the lowest class, ballast-heavers, coal-whippers, brazen women, ragged children, and the raff and refuse of the river, he makes his way with difficulty along, assailed by offensive sights and smells from the narrow alleys which branch off on the right and left, and deafened by the clash of ponderous waggons that bear great piles of merchandise from the stacks of warehouses that rise from every corner. EOS In such a neighborhood, beyond Dockhead in the Borough of Southwark, stands Jacob's Island, surrounded by a muddy ditch, six or eight feet deep and fifteen or twenty wide when the tide is in, once called Mill Pond, but known in the days of this story as Folly Ditch. EOS It is a creek or inlet from the Thames, and can always be filled at high water by opening the sluices at the Lead Mills from which it took its old name. EOS In Jacob's Island, the warehouses are roofless and empty; the walls are crumbling down; the windows are windows no more; the doors are falling into the streets; the chimneys are blackened, but they yield no smoke. EOS Thirty or forty years ago, before losses and chancery suits came upon it, it was a thriving place; but now it is a desolate island indeed. EOS The houses have no owners; they are broken open, and entered upon by those who have the courage; and there they live, and there they die. EOS They must have powerful motives for a secret residence, or be reduced to a destitute condition indeed, who seek a refuge in Jacob's Island. EOS The stream abruptly turned, as this intelligence ran from mouth to mouth; and the people at the windows, seeing those upon the bridges pouring back, quitted their stations, and running into the street, joined the concourse that now thronged pell-mell to the spot they had left:  each man crushing and striving with his neighbor, and all panting with impatience to get near the door, and look upon the criminal as the officers brought him out. EOS The man had shrunk down, thoroughly quelled by the ferocity of the crowd, and the impossibility of escape; but seeing this sudden change with no less rapidity than it had occurred, he sprang upon his feet, determined to make one last effort for his life by dropping into the ditch, and, at the risk of being stifled, endeavouring to creep away in the darkness and confusion. EOS Roused into new strength and energy, and stimulated by the noise within the house which announced that an entrance had really been effected, he set his foot against the stack of chimneys, fastened one end of the rope tightly and firmly round it, and with the other made a strong running noose by the aid of his hands and teeth almost in a second. EOS At the very instant when he brought the loop over his head previous to slipping it beneath his arm-pits, and when the old gentleman before-mentioned (who had clung so tight to the railing of the bridge as to resist the force of the crowd, and retain his position) earnestly warned those about him that the man was about to lower himself down--at that very instant the murderer, looking behind him on the roof, threw his arms above his head, and uttered a yell of terror. EOS 'The eyes again!' EOS he cried in an unearthly screech. EOS The noose was on his neck. EOS It ran up with his weight, tight as a bow-string, and swift as the arrow it speeds. EOS The old chimney quivered with the shock, but stood it bravely. EOS CHAPTER LI  AFFORDING AN EXPLANATION OF MORE MYSTERIES THAN ONE, AND COMPREHENDING A PROPOSAL OF MARRIAGE WITH NO WORD OF SETTLEMENT OR PIN-MONEY  The events narrated in the last chapter were yet but two days old, when Oliver found himself, at three o'clock in the afternoon, in a travelling-carriage rolling fast towards his native town. EOS Mrs. Maylie, and Rose, and Mrs. Bedwin, and the good doctor were with him:  and Mr. Brownlow followed in a post-chaise, accompanied by one other person whose name had not been mentioned. EOS They had not talked much upon the way; for Oliver was in a flutter of agitation and uncertainty which deprived him of the power of collecting his thoughts, and almost of speech, and appeared to have scarcely less effect on his companions, who shared it, in at least an equal degree. EOS He and the two ladies had been very carefully made acquainted by Mr. Brownlow with the nature of the admissions which had been forced from Monks; and although they knew that the object of their present journey was to complete the work which had been so well begun, still the whole matter was enveloped in enough of doubt and mystery to leave them in endurance of the most intense suspense. EOS The same kind friend had, with Mr. Losberne's assistance, cautiously stopped all channels of communication through which they could receive intelligence of the dreadful occurrences that so recently taken place. EOS 'It was quite true,' he said, 'that they must know them before long, but it might be at a better time than the present, and it could not be at a worse.' EOS So, they travelled on in silence:  each busied with reflections on the object which had brought them together:  and no one disposed to give utterance to the thoughts which crowded upon all. EOS 'See there, there!' EOS Yonder is the path across the fields, leading to the old house where I was a little child! EOS Oh Dick, Dick, my dear old friend, if I could only see you now!' EOS 'You will see him soon,' replied Rose, gently taking his folded hands between her own. EOS 'You shall tell him how happy you are, and how rich you have grown, and that in all your happiness you have none so great as the coming back to make him happy too.' EOS 'Yes, yes,' said Oliver, 'and we'll--we'll take him away from here, and have him clothed and taught, and send him to some quiet country place where he may grow strong and well,--shall we?' EOS Rose nodded 'yes,' for the boy was smiling through such happy tears that she could not speak. EOS 'It will make you cry, I know, to hear what he can tell; but never mind, never mind, it will be all over, and you will smile again--I know that too--to think how changed he is; you did the same with me. EOS He said "God bless you" to me when I ran away,' cried the boy with a burst of affectionate emotion; 'and I will say "God bless you" now, and show him how I love him for it!' EOS As they approached the town, and at length drove through its narrow streets, it became matter of no small difficulty to restrain the boy within reasonable bounds. EOS There was Sowerberry's the undertaker's just as it used to be, only smaller and less imposing in appearance than he remembered it--there were all the well-known shops and houses, with almost every one of which he had some slight incident connected--there was Gamfield's cart, the very cart he used to have, standing at the old public-house door--there was the workhouse, the dreary prison of his youthful days, with its dismal windows frowning on the street--there was the same lean porter standing at the gate, at sight of whom Oliver involuntarily shrunk back, and then laughed at himself for being so foolish, then cried, then laughed again--there were scores of faces at the doors and windows that he knew quite well--there was nearly everything as if he had left it but yesterday, and all his recent life had been but a happy dream. EOS They drove straight to the door of the chief hotel (which Oliver used to stare up at, with awe, and think a mighty palace, but which had somehow fallen off in grandeur and size); and here was Mr. Grimwig all ready to receive them, kissing the young lady, and the old one too, when they got out of the coach, as if he were the grandfather of the whole party, all smiles and kindness, and not offering to eat his head--no, not once; not even when he contradicted a very old postboy about the nearest road to London, and maintained he knew it best, though he had only come that way once, and that time fast asleep. EOS There was dinner prepared, and there were bedrooms ready, and everything was arranged as if by magic. EOS Mr. Brownlow did not join them at dinner, but remained in a separate room. EOS The two other gentlemen hurried in and out with anxious faces, and, during the short intervals when they were present, conversed apart. EOS Monks cast a look of hate, which, even then, he could not dissemble, at the astonished boy, and sat down near the door. EOS Mr. Brownlow, who had papers in his hand, walked to a table near which Rose and Oliver were seated. EOS 'This is a painful task,' said he, 'but these declarations, which have been signed in London before many gentlemen, must be in substance repeated here. EOS I would have spared you the degradation, but we must hear them from your own lips before we part, and you know why.' EOS 'Go on,' said the person addressed, turning away his face. EOS 'Quick. EOS I have almost done enough, I think. EOS Don't keep me here.' EOS 'This child,' said Mr. Brownlow, drawing Oliver to him, and laying his hand upon his head, 'is your half-brother; the illegitimate son of your father, my dear friend Edwin Leeford, by poor young Agnes Fleming, who died in giving him birth.' EOS 'The term you use,' said Mr. Brownlow, sternly, 'is a reproach to those long since passed beyond the feeble censure of the world. EOS It reflects disgrace on no one living, except you who use it. EOS Let that pass. EOS 'In the workhouse of this town,' was the sullen reply. EOS 'You have the story there.' EOS 'I must have it here, too,' said Mr. Brownlow, looking round upon the listeners. EOS 'Listen then! EOS 'His father being taken ill at Rome, was joined by his wife, my mother, from whom he had been long separated, who went from Paris and took me with her--to look after his property, for what I know, for she had no great affection for him, nor he for her. EOS He knew nothing of us, for his senses were gone, and he slumbered on till next day, when he died. EOS Among the papers in his desk, were two, dated on the night his illness first came on, directed to yourself'; he addressed himself to Mr. Brownlow; 'and enclosed in a few short lines to you, with an intimation on the cover of the package that it was not to be forwarded till after he was dead. EOS One of these papers was a letter to this girl Agnes; the other a will.' EOS 'What of the letter?' EOS asked Mr. Brownlow. EOS She was, at that time, within a few months of her confinement. EOS I believe he had.' EOS He did this, he said, to mark his confidence in the other, and his conviction--only strengthened by approaching death--that the child would share her gentle heart, and noble nature. EOS If he were disappointed in this expectation, then the money was to come to you:  for then, and not till then, when both children were equal, would he recognise your prior claim upon his purse, who had none upon his heart, but had, from an infant, repulsed him with coldness and aversion.' EOS 'My mother,' said Monks, in a louder tone, 'did what a woman should have done. EOS The letter never reached its destination; but that, and other proofs, she kept, in case they ever tried to lie away the blot. EOS Goaded by shame and dishonour he fled with his children into a remote corner of Wales, changing his very name that his friends might never know of his retreat; and here, no great while afterwards, he was found dead in his bed. EOS There was a short silence here, until Mr. Brownlow took up the thread of the narrative. EOS 'Years after this,' he said, 'this man's--Edward Leeford's--mother came to me. EOS He had left her, when only eighteen; robbed her of jewels and money; gambled, squandered, forged, and fled to London:  where for two years he had associated with the lowest outcasts. EOS She was sinking under a painful and incurable disease, and wished to recover him before she died. EOS They were unavailing for a long time, but ultimately successful; and he went back with her to France.' EOS 'There she died,' said Monks, 'after a lingering illness; and, on her death-bed, she bequeathed these secrets to me, together with her unquenchable and deadly hatred of all whom they involved--though she need not have left me that, for I had inherited it long before. EOS She would not believe that the girl had destroyed herself, and the child too, but was filled with the impression that a male child had been born, and was alive. EOS I swore to her, if ever it crossed my path, to hunt it down; never to let it rest; to pursue it with the bitterest and most unrelenting animosity; to vent upon it the hatred that I deeply felt, and to spit upon the empty vaunt of that insulting will by draggin it, if I could, to the very gallows-foot. EOS He came in my way at last. EOS I began well; and, but for babbling drabs, I would have finished as I began!' EOS said Mr. Brownlow, turning to Monks. EOS 'I bought them from the man and woman I told you of, who stole them from the nurse, who stole them from the corpse,' answered Monks without raising his eyes. EOS Mr. Brownlow merely nodded to Mr. Grimwig, who disappearing with great alacrity, shortly returned, pushing in Mrs. Bumble, and dragging her unwilling consort after him. EOS cried Mr. Bumble, with ill-feigned enthusiasm, 'or is that little Oliver? EOS Oh O-li-ver, if you know'd how I've been a-grieving for you--'  'Hold your tongue, fool,' murmured Mrs. Bumble. EOS 'Isn't natur, natur, Mrs. EOS 'Can't I be supposed to feel--_I_ as brought him up porochially--when I see him a-setting here among ladies and gentlemen of the very affablest description! EOS I always loved that boy as if he'd been my--my--my own grandfather,' said Mr. Bumble, halting for an appropriate comparison. EOS 'Master Oliver, my dear, you remember the blessed gentleman in the white waistcoat? EOS Ah! EOS 'Come, sir,' said Mr. Grimwig, tartly; 'suppress your feelings.' EOS 'I will do my endeavours, sir,' replied Mr. Bumble. EOS This salutation was addressed to Mr. Brownlow, who had stepped up to within a short distance of the respectable couple. EOS He inquired, as he pointed to Monks,  'Do you know that person?' EOS 'No,' replied Mrs. Bumble flatly. EOS said Mr. Brownlow, addressing her spouse. EOS 'You never had, perhaps, a certain gold locket and ring?' EOS said Mr. Brownlow. EOS 'Certainly not,' replied the matron. EOS Again Mr. Brownlow nodded to Mr. Grimwig; and again that gentleman limped away with extraordinary readiness. EOS But not again did he return with a stout man and wife; for this time, he led in two palsied women, who shook and tottered as they walked. EOS 'You shut the door the night old Sally died,' said the foremost one, raising her shrivelled hand, 'but you couldn't shut out the sound, nor stop the chinks.' EOS 'We heard her try to tell you what she'd done, and saw you take a paper from her hand, and watched you too, next day, to the pawnbroker's shop,' said the first. EOS We found out that, and saw it given you. EOS we were by.' EOS 'Would you like to see the pawnbroker himself?' EOS asked Mr. Grimwig with a motion towards the door. EOS I _did_ sell them, and they're where you'll never get them. EOS 'Nothing,' replied Mr. Brownlow, 'except that it remains for us to take care that neither of you is employed in a situation of trust again. EOS You may leave the room.' EOS 'It was all Mrs. Bumble. EOS 'That is no excuse,' replied Mr. Brownlow. EOS 'You were present on the occasion of the destruction of these trinkets, and indeed are the more guilty of the two, in the eye of the law; for the law supposes that your wife acts under your direction.' EOS 'If the law supposes that,' said Mr. Bumble, squeezing his hat emphatically in both hands, 'the law is a ass--a idiot. EOS If that's the eye of the law, the law is a bachelor; and the worst I wish the law is, that his eye may be opened by experience--by experience.' EOS Laying great stress on the repetition of these two words, Mr. Bumble fixed his hat on very tight, and putting his hands in his pockets, followed his helpmate downstairs. EOS Do not tremble. EOS 'If they have--I do not know how they can, but if they have--any reference to me,' said Rose, 'pray let me hear them at some other time. EOS I have not strength or spirits now.' EOS 'Nay,' returned the old gentlman, drawing her arm through his; 'you have more fortitude than this, I am sure. EOS 'Yes,' replied Monks. EOS 'I never saw you before,' said Rose faintly. EOS 'I have seen you often,' returned Monks. EOS 'The father of the unhappy Agnes had _two_ daughters,' said Mr. Brownlow. EOS 'Go on,' said Mr. Brownlow, signing to Mrs. Maylie to approach. EOS 'Go on!' EOS 'You couldn't find the spot to which these people had repaired,' said Monks, 'but where friendship fails, hatred will often force a way. EOS My mother found it, after a year of cunning search--ay, and found the child.' EOS 'She took it, did she?' EOS She didn't quite rely, however, on their discontent and poverty for the child's unhappiness, but told the history of the sister's shame, with such alterations as suited her; bade them take good heed of the child, for she came of bad blood; and told them she was illegitimate, and sure to go wrong at one time or other. EOS The circumstances countenanced all this; the people believed it; and there the child dragged on an existence, miserable enough even to satisfy us, until a widow lady, residing, then, at Chester, saw the girl by chance, pitied her, and took her home. EOS There was some cursed spell, I think, against us; for in spite of all our efforts she remained there and was happy. EOS I lost sight of her, two or three years ago, and saw her no more until a few months back.' EOS 'Do you see her now?' EOS 'Yes. EOS Leaning on your arm.' EOS 'But not the less my niece,' cried Mrs. Maylie, folding the fainting girl in her arms; 'not the less my dearest child. EOS My sweet companion, my own dear girl!' EOS 'The only friend I ever had,' cried Rose, clinging to her. EOS 'The kindest, best of friends. EOS My heart will burst. EOS I cannot bear all this.' EOS 'You have borne more, and have been, through all, the best and gentlest creature that ever shed happiness on every one she knew,' said Mrs. Maylie, embracing her tenderly. EOS Rose, dear, darling Rose!' EOS A soft tap at the door, at length announced that some one was without. EOS 'I know it all,' he said, taking a seat beside the lovely girl. EOS 'I am not here by accident,' he added after a lengthened silence; 'nor have I heard all this to-night, for I knew it yesterday--only yesterday. EOS Do you guess that I have come to remind you of a promise?' EOS 'All. EOS I was to lay whatever of station or fortune I might possess at your feet, and if you still adhered to your former determination, I pledged myself, by no word or act, to seek to change it.' EOS 'If I ever owed a strict and rigid duty to her, whose goodness saved me from a life of indigence and suffering, when should I ever feel it, as I should to-night? EOS 'The disclosure of to-night,'--Harry began. EOS 'The disclosure of to-night,' replied Rose softly, 'leaves me in the same position, with reference to you, as that in which I stood before.' EOS 'You harden your heart against me, Rose,' urged her lover. EOS 'Oh Harry, Harry,' said the young lady, bursting into tears; 'I wish I could, and spare myself this pain.' EOS said Harry, taking her hand. EOS 'Think, dear Rose, think what you have heard to-night.' EOS cried Rose. EOS 'That a sense of his deep disgrace so worked upon my own father that he shunned all--there, we have said enough, Harry, we have said enough.' EOS 'Not yet, not yet,' said the young man, detaining her as she rose. EOS 'My hopes, my wishes, prospects, feeling:  every thought in life except my love for you:  have undergone a change. EOS I offer you, now, no distinction among a bustling crowd; no mingling with a world of malice and detraction, where the blood is called into honest cheeks by aught but real disgrace and shame; but a home--a heart and home--yes, dearest Rose, and those, and those alone, are all I have to offer.' EOS 'What do you mean!' EOS 'I mean but this--that when I left you last, I left you with a firm determination to level all fancied barriers between yourself and me; resolved that if my world could not be yours, I would make yours mine; that no pride of birth should curl the lip at you, for I would turn from it. EOS This I have done. EOS Such power and patronage:  such relatives of influence and rank:  as smiled upon me then, look coldly now; but there are smiling fields and waving trees in England's richest county; and by one village church--mine, Rose, my own!--there stands a rustic dwelling which you can make me prouder of, than all the hopes I have renounced, measured a thousandfold. EOS This is my rank and station now, and here I lay it down!' EOS *      *      *      *      *  'It's a trying thing waiting supper for lovers,' said Mr. Grimwig, waking up, and pulling his pocket-handkerchief from over his head. EOS Truth to tell, the supper had been waiting a most unreasonable time. EOS 'I had serious thoughts of eating my head to-night,' said Mr. Grimwig, 'for I began to think I should get nothing else. EOS I'll take the liberty, if you'll allow me, of saluting the bride that is to be.' EOS Mr. Grimwig lost no time in carrying this notice into effect upon the blushing girl; and the example, being contagious, was followed both by the doctor and Mr. Brownlow:  some people affirm that Harry Maylie had been observed to set it, originally, in a dark room adjoining; but the best authorities consider this downright scandal:  he being young and a clergyman. EOS There are tears stealing down your face at this moment. EOS Poor Dick was dead! EOS CHAPTER LII  FAGIN'S LAST NIGHT ALIVE  The court was paved, from floor to roof, with human faces. EOS Inquisitive and eager eyes peered from every inch of space. EOS From the rail before the dock, away into the sharpest angle of the smallest corner in the galleries, all looks were fixed upon one man--Fagin. EOS Before him and behind:  above, below, on the right and on the left:  he seemed to stand surrounded by a firmament, all bright with gleaming eyes. EOS He stood there, in all this glare of living light, with one hand resting on the wooden slab before him, the other held to his ear, and his head thrust forward to enable him to catch with greater distinctness every word that fell from the presiding judge, who was delivering his charge to the jury. EOS Beyond these manifestations of anxiety, he stirred not hand or foot. EOS He had scarcely moved since the trial began; and now that the judge ceased to speak, he still remained in the same strained attitude of close attention, with his gaze bent on him, as though he listened still. EOS Looking round, he saw that the juryman had turned together, to consider their verdict. EOS But in no one face--not even among the women, of whom there were many there--could he read the faintest sympathy with himself, or any feeling but one of all-absorbing interest that he should be condemned. EOS As he saw all this in one bewildered glance, the deathlike stillness came again, and looking back he saw that the jurymen had turned towards the judge. EOS Hush! EOS They only sought permission to retire. EOS Some of the people were eating, and some fanning themselves with handkerchiefs; for the crowded place was very hot. EOS There was one young man sketching his face in a little note-book. EOS He wondered whether it was like, and looked on when the artist broke his pencil-point, and made another with his knife, as any idle spectator might have done. EOS In the same way, when he turned his eyes towards the judge, his mind began to busy itself with the fashion of his dress, and what it cost, and how he put it on. EOS Not that, all this time, his mind was, for an instant, free from one oppressive overwhelming sense of the grave that opened at his feet; it was ever present to him, but in a vague and general way, and he could not fix his thoughts upon it. EOS Thus, even while he trembled, and turned burning hot at the idea of speedy death, he fell to counting the iron spikes before him, and wondering how the head of one had been broken off, and whether they would mend it, or leave it as it was. EOS At length there was a cry of silence, and a breathless look from all towards the door. EOS The jury returned, and passed him close. EOS He could glean nothing from their faces; they might as well have been of stone. EOS Perfect stillness ensued--not a rustle--not a breath--Guilty. EOS It was a peal of joy from the populace outside, greeting the news that he would die on Monday. EOS The noise subsided, and he was asked if he had anything to say why sentence of death should not be passed upon him. EOS The judge assumed the black cap, and the prisoner still stood with the same air and gesture. EOS A woman in the gallery, uttered some exclamation, called forth by this dread solemnity; he looked hastily up as if angry at the interruption, and bent forward yet more attentively. EOS The address was solemn and impressive; the sentence fearful to hear. EOS But he stood, like a marble figure, without the motion of a nerve. EOS His haggard face was still thrust forward, his under-jaw hanging down, and his eyes staring out before him, when the jailer put his hand upon his arm, and beckoned him away. EOS He gazed stupidly about him for an instant, and obeyed. EOS There was nobody there to speak to _him_; but, as he passed, the prisoners fell back to render him more visible to the people who were clinging to the bars:  and they assailed him with opprobrious names, and screeched and hissed. EOS He shook his fist, and would have spat upon them; but his conductors hurried him on, through a gloomy passage lighted by a few dim lamps, into the interior of the prison. EOS He sat down on a stone bench opposite the door, which served for seat and bedstead; and casting his blood-shot eyes upon the ground, tried to collect his thoughts. EOS After awhile, he began to remember a few disjointed fragments of what the judge had said: though it had seemed to him, at the time, that he could not hear a word. EOS These gradually fell into their proper places, and by degrees suggested more:  so that in a little time he had the whole, almost as it was delivered. EOS To be hanged by the neck, till he was dead--that was the end. EOS They rose up, in such quick succession, that he could hardly count them. EOS With what a rattling noise the drop went down; and how suddenly they changed, from strong and vigorous men to dangling heaps of clothes! EOS Some of them might have inhabited that very cell--sat upon that very spot. EOS It was very dark; why didn't they bring a light? EOS It was like sitting in a vault strewn with dead bodies--the cap, the noose, the pinioned arms, the faces that he knew, even beneath that hideous veil.--Light, light! EOS At length, when his hands were raw with beating against the heavy door and walls, two men appeared:  one bearing a candle, which he thrust into an iron candlestick fixed against the wall:  the other dragging in a mattress on which to pass the night; for the prisoner was to be left alone no more. EOS Then came the night--dark, dismal, silent night. EOS To him they brought despair. EOS The boom of every iron bell came laden with the one, deep, hollow sound--Death. EOS It was another form of knell, with mockery added to the warning. EOS The day passed off. EOS Day? EOS At one time he raved and blasphemed; and at another howled and tore his hair. EOS They renewed their charitable efforts, and he beat them off. EOS Saturday night. EOS He had only one night more to live. EOS And as he thought of this, the day broke--Sunday. EOS He had sat there, awake, but dreaming. EOS Now, he started up, every minute, and with gasping mouth and burning skin, hurried to and fro, in such a paroxysm of fear and wrath that even they--used to such sights--recoiled from him with horror. EOS He had been wounded with some missiles from the crowd on the day of his capture, and his head was bandaged with a linen cloth. EOS Eight--nine--then. EOS Another struck, before the voice of the previous hour had ceased to vibrate. EOS At eight, he would be the only mourner in his own funeral train; at eleven--  Those dreadful walls of Newgate, which have hidden so much misery and such unspeakable anguish, not only from the eyes, but, too often, and too long, from the thoughts, of men, never held so dread a spectacle as that. EOS The few who lingered as they passed, and wondered what the man was doing who was to be hanged to-morrow, would have slept but ill that night, if they could have seen him. EOS By degrees they fell off, one by one; and, for an hour, in the dead of night, the street was left to solitude and darkness. EOS The space before the prison was cleared, and a few strong barriers, painted black, had been already thrown across the road to break the pressure of the expected crowd, when Mr. Brownlow and Oliver appeared at the wicket, and presented an order of admission to the prisoner, signed by one of the sheriffs. EOS They were immediately admitted into the lodge. EOS 'Is the young gentleman to come too, sir?' EOS said the man whose duty it was to conduct them. EOS These few words had been said apart, so as to be inaudible to Oliver. EOS The man touched his hat; and glancing at Oliver with some curiousity, opened another gate, opposite to that by which they had entered, and led them on, through dark and winding ways, towards the cells. EOS 'This,' said the man, stopping in a gloomy passage where a couple of workmen were making some preparations in profound silence--'this is the place he passes through. EOS If you step this way, you can see the door he goes out at.' EOS He led them into a stone kitchen, fitted with coppers for dressing the prison food, and pointed to a door. EOS There was an open grating above it, through which came the sound of men's voices, mingled with the noise of hammering, and the throwing down of boards. EOS They were putting up the scaffold. EOS From this place, they passed through several strong gates, opened by other turnkeys from the inner side; and, having entered an open yard, ascended a flight of narrow steps, and came into a passage with a row of strong doors on the left hand. EOS The two attendants, after a little whispering, came out into the passage, stretching themselves as if glad of the temporary relief, and motioned the visitors to follow the jailer into the cell. EOS The condemned criminal was seated on his bed, rocking himself from side to side, with a countenance more like that of a snared beast than the face of a man. EOS ha! EOS ha! EOS cried Fagin. EOS Saw his head off!' EOS 'Fagin,' said the jailer. EOS 'That's me!' EOS cried the Jew, falling instantly, into the attitude of listening he had assumed upon his trial. EOS 'Here,' said the turnkey, laying his hand upon his breast to keep him down. EOS 'Here's somebody wants to see you, to ask you some questions, I suppose. EOS Are you a man?' EOS 'I shan't be one long,' he replied, looking up with a face retaining no human expression but rage and terror. EOS What right have they to butcher me?' EOS As he spoke he caught sight of Oliver and Mr. Brownlow. EOS Shrinking to the furthest corner of the seat, he demanded to know what they wanted there.
